ant-farm-3d.text: ok the pheromone trails are genuinely mesmerizing. i left this running for like 20 minutes and the colony just... organized itself. emergent behavior is wild
living art mode is the move. threw it on my second monitor as a screensaver basically
the tunneling physics feel really solid for something running in a browser. how is this three.js and not a native app??
wish there was a way to drop food at specific locations to see how the colony reacts. like a sandbox mode
^^^ yes that would be incredible. even just clicking to place crumbs would add so much
ngl it chugs a bit on my laptop once the colony gets big. maybe a setting to cap ant count?
thats fair, mine handles it fine on desktop but i could see mobile being rough. advanced complexity tag checks out lol
this reminds me of those old sim ant games but actually beautiful. the 3d perspective adds so much depth to watching them work

3d-particle-physics-simulator.text: force fields + gravity together creates some insane orbital patterns. been playing with it for an hour
the collision detection is surprisingly accurate for webgl. particles actually bounce off each other properly
cranked the particle count up and my gpu fan kicked in lmao. worth it though the visuals are gorgeous
would love presets for common physics scenarios — like solar system orbits or electromagnetic field demos
that's actually a great idea, like a "load scenario" dropdown. the raw sandbox is cool but some starting points would help newcomers
how do you get the spiral galaxy effect people keep posting? i can only get chaotic bouncing
set gravity low, add a central attractor force field, then spawn particles in a ring. tweak until it spirals 👌
ui could use some work honestly — the controls feel a bit cramped and its hard to tell which parameter does what without experimenting

ascii-video-converter.text: matrix mode on this thing is SO good. turned on my webcam in a dark room and felt like neo
retro terminal mode gives me strong fallout computer vibes. love the aesthetic
simple but super fun. showed it to my non-tech friends and they were all trying it immediately
it'd be cool if you could save the ascii output as a text file or copy to clipboard. right now you can only watch it live
or even record a short gif of the ascii version! that would be insanely shareable
runs smooth even on my old chromebook which is impressive. the simple complexity rating is accurate
does anyone know if it actually sends the video anywhere? i know it says local-first but just checking
nah it's all client-side, webcam feed never leaves your browser. you can check the source — zero network requests

agent-generator-ui.text: interesting concept but this feels more like a dev tool than a visual art piece? not sure why its in this category
agreed, seems like it belongs in creative tools or experimental ai tbh
the ui is clean though. nice visual interface for setting up agent configs without touching code
i like that its local-first — no api keys needed to at least design agents. the python export is handy
feels a bit bare bones compared to some of the other apps here. could use more templates or examples to get started
yeah some starter agent templates would go a long way. i opened it and wasn't sure what to do first
solid foundation for what it is. would be cool to see this expanded with more agent types and workflow visualization

physics-lab.text: fluid mechanics sim in a BROWSER? this is genuinely impressive. the wave physics section alone is worth it
the force vector visualization is chef's kiss. finally i can actually see what's happening in my pendulum simulations
data export feature is clutch. used it for a college physics assignment and my prof thought i was using matlab 😂
lmao thats legendary. does the export give you csv or what format?
this honestly rivals some paid simulation software. the electromagnetism section is really well done
my one complaint — the ui is packed with so many options it's overwhelming at first. maybe a guided tour or simpler default view?
totally agree. a beginner mode that shows one simulation type at a time would help. i almost bounced before i figured out the tabs
measurement tools are a nice touch. being able to drag rulers and protractors onto the canvas makes it feel like an actual lab bench

budget-tracker-expense-manager.text: ok wait this is actually really useful?? i came here for games and now im tracking my rent lmao
the pie chart breakdown by category is clean. wish i could set recurring expenses tho, having to re-enter rent every month would get old fast
lol same, i opened it as a joke and now i realize i spend way too much on doordash
nice that it saves to localstorage but would love a csv export option so i can pull data into a spreadsheet
the visual charts are surprisingly smooth for something this lightweight. no loading, no signup, just works
csv export would be huge, agreed. also maybe a monthly comparison view? seeing spending trends over time would make this actually competitive with mint
it tagged as drawing/animation which is kinda misleading — this is straight up a finance tool. not complaining tho
the category budget feature is the real mvp here. set a limit, see the bar fill up. simple and effective

canvas-svg-graphics-workshop.text: this is genuinely one of the best learning tools ive seen for understanding canvas vs svg tradeoffs. the side-by-side comparison makes it click instantly
the live code editing is so satisfying. change a value, see it update immediately on both sides
as someone who always just defaults to canvas for everything... ok fine svg has its uses. the scaling demo convinced me
performance comparison section is interesting but feels a bit shallow. would love to see it stress test with like 10k elements to really show where canvas wins
yeah the perf section needs more dramatic examples. with small element counts they look identical which kind of undermines the whole point
sent this to my junior devs at work lol. better than any blog post ive bookmarked on the topic
the animation examples are particularly good — seeing how requestAnimationFrame works differently in each context was an aha moment for me

chart-builder-pro.text: scatter plot with custom colors is *chefs kiss*. made a quick visualization for a class presentation in like 2 minutes
the data import is nice but the export options are limited. can i get png export? right now i have to screenshot which feels janky
honestly this gives google sheets charts a run for its money and it works completely offline
area charts look gorgeous. the gradient fill is a really nice touch
png export +1. also would be cool to have dark mode for the charts themselves, not just the ui
tried importing a csv with 500 rows and it handled it fine. was expecting it to choke tbh
one gripe — the pie chart labels overlap when you have more than like 6 categories. needs better label placement logic
yeah the label collision thing is annoying. maybe a legend on the side instead of inline labels would work better for large datasets

claude-subagents-tutorial-continued.text: this is... a tutorial about claude code subagents in the visual art category?? feels like it ended up in the wrong section
interesting content but the description literally just repeats the title lol. felt like i was going in blind
ngl the interactive elements are decent for a tutorial format. beats reading docs
is there a part 1? this says continued but i cant find the first one
right?? i looked everywhere. maybe it got deleted or renamed. kind of confusing jumping in at part 2
more of a reference tool than a visual art piece but still useful if youre into the claude ecosystem. the visualization of how subagents communicate is actually pretty cool
agreed its miscategorized but the content itself is solid. should probably be in educational

crease-memory-theater.text: holy crap this is mesmerizing. drew a few random lines and watched it fold into shapes i never would have imagined. the "memory" part where it remembers past configurations is so cool
ok this is actual art. the luminous trails of previous folds building up over time creates something genuinely beautiful
the concept is incredible but the controls took me a minute to figure out. maybe a brief overlay tutorial on first load?
i keep coming back to this one. every time i draw different crease lines i get completely different results. the possibility space feels infinite
agreed on the learning curve — i spent the first 30 seconds clicking randomly before i realized you need to draw LINES not points
the 3d rendering is impressive for a single html file. how is this not using three.js or any library?? pure canvas wizardry
this feels like it belongs in a digital art gallery somewhere. the way the paper unfolds and the light catches the creases... poetic
one thing — on my older laptop the autonomous exploration gets pretty laggy after like 20+ configurations are stored. wonder if theres a memory limit setting

database-designer-erd.text: ok wait this is actually useful?? i came here for games and now im designing my side project's database lmao
the sql generation is surprisingly clean. exported a schema and it ran on postgres without any edits
drag and drop for table relationships feels really intuitive. way better than some paid tools ive used
would be nice if you could import an existing sql dump and reverse-engineer the ERD from it
fr that would be a killer feature. half the time i inherit some legacy db with no docs
the json export is great but the canvas gets kinda laggy once you have like 15+ tables. had to keep things small
i use this to explain database concepts to junior devs at work. the visual layout makes it click for them instantly
same here, beats drawing on a whiteboard every time. wish it had a dark mode though my eyes are dying

doodle-to-world.text: i drew a crappy house and then WALKED INSIDE IT. in a single html file. what kind of sorcery is this
this is genuinely one of the coolest things ive seen on here. the 3d extrusion from a 2d sketch is so satisfying
tried drawing a maze and walking through it. took a few attempts to get the walls right but once it worked it was incredible
the movement controls feel a bit floaty tbh. like i'm ice skating through my drawings. tighter fps controls would help a lot
yeah the controls aren't perfect but cmon it's converting a doodle to a walkable 3d world in real time. cut it some slack lol
drew a circle and got confused why i was inside a cylinder. then it clicked — everything gets extruded upward. pretty clever
showed this to my kid and she spent 45 minutes drawing and exploring her own worlds. she called it "the magic paper"
would love some way to add color or texture to the walls. right now everything is the same shade which makes complex drawings hard to navigate

fluid-dynamics-simulator.text: been dragging my mouse around for 20 minutes straight. this is dangerously hypnotic
the viscosity slider is where it's at. crank it up and it looks like honey, turn it down and you get this wild turbulent flow
color mixing when two streams collide is so pretty. accidentally made the bisexual flag colors and screenshotted it immediately
lol nice. i keep making spirals and watching them dissipate. very zen
runs buttery smooth on my laptop which surprised me. particle count must be well optimized
only complaint is there's no way to save or screenshot your creations from within the app. have to use the browser's screenshot tools
would be cool if gravity could be toggled to different directions, not just down. imagine sideways fluid flow
this is basically a stress relief tool disguised as a physics sim and i am here for it

gene-wars.text: gene wars is lowkey addicting. bred a creature with max speed and poison traits and it wiped the floor with everything
the auto-battler part is fun to watch but i wish i had a little more control during fights. even just positioning would add depth
splicing traits across generations and seeing what emerges is the real game here. accidentally made an unkillable tank build on gen 4
agree the breeding is the hook. fights feel kinda random sometimes though — my clearly stronger creature lost to a weaker one with no explanation
i think there's a hidden counter system? creatures with armor seem to lose to poison types consistently
dynasty tracking across generations is a neat touch. feels like running a bloodline in crusader kings but with weird pixel monsters
the retro pixel art style works perfectly for this. gives it that gba pokemon vibe

github-sync-manager.text: not gonna lie i opened this expecting a boring tool and the 3d visualization actually looks sick
the animations are smooth but im a bit confused about what exactly it's syncing? feels more like a concept demo than a functional tool
yeah same. it's pretty but i couldn't figure out what artifacts it manages since everything runs offline with no actual github connection
i think it's meant to be an interactive mockup of what a sync manager could look like. the svg work is impressive regardless
the 3d elements are really well done for a single html file. whoever made this knows their way around css transforms
would be way more useful if it could actually connect to github's api and do real syncing. right now it's all visual with no real function
as eye candy it delivers. as a tool... needs work. cool proof of concept though

gravity-well-sandbox.text: ok this is mesmerizing. i just spent 20 minutes placing wells in a circle and watching the particles orbit between them
the way particles follow geodesic paths is surprisingly accurate for something running in a browser. whoever made this actually understands general relativity lol
i wish there was a way to adjust the mass of individual wells after placing them. right now you kinda have to start over if you get one wrong
try putting two wells really close together — the particles do this figure-8 thing that looks incredible
yeah the figure-8 is cool but it tanks the framerate on my laptop when you get too many particles near the wells. might need some spatial partitioning optimization
this would be amazing as a screensaver honestly
fr someone port this to wallpaper engine please
minor thing but the spacetime bending visualization could use some color coding based on velocity or acceleration. everything being one color makes it harder to see what's happening in dense areas

localstorage-academy-tutorial.text: actually really solid tutorial. the live code examples are way more helpful than reading docs on mdn
the visual inspector showing what's in localStorage in real-time is such a nice touch. wish devtools were this clear
wait this is categorized as visual art? it's literally a coding tutorial lol. great resource though, helped me understand key/value persistence better than my bootcamp did
lmaooo the category placement is wild but the content slaps
the exercises are good but i got stuck on the third one because there's no hint system. maybe add a "show solution" button after a failed attempt?
one suggestion — would love a section on localStorage size limits and what happens when you exceed them. that's where most beginners get tripped up in real projects
sent this to my junior dev. better than half the paid courses out there and it runs completely offline which is neat

magnetic-field-painter.text: this is genuinely beautiful. placing poles and watching the filings align feels like actual physics magic
the "liquid metal" effect when thousands of particles flow along the field lines is no joke. it looks like ferrofluid in real life
i made a quadrupole configuration and the topology is spot on. the null points and all. whoever wrote this knows their electromagnetism
ok but can we talk about how satisfying it is to just drag a pole around and watch everything reorganize instantly
RIGHT. the real-time recalculation is so smooth
would be cool if you could toggle between showing field lines vs iron filings vs both. sometimes i want to see the clean mathematical lines
also a way to export the result as an image would be great, some of the patterns i'm getting are genuinely wallpaper-worthy
this + the gravity well sandbox make such a good pair. physics visualization done right

nexus.text: so i waved my hands around for like 5 minutes and i'm still not sure what's happening but it looks cool??
the gesture controls are interesting conceptually but really need some kind of onboarding or tutorial. i kept accidentally triggering things
yeah the discoverability is rough. once you figure out the gestures though it's actually a pretty neat interactive art piece
the animations are smooth at least. feels responsive even if i don't always know what i'm doing
this feels like a tech demo more than a finished thing. the description says "gesture world explorer" but there's not much world to explore yet?
i think that's kind of the point — it's more of an experience than a game. but agreed it could use more depth
would love to see this expanded with different "worlds" or environments to explore through gestures. the core interaction model has potential

palimpsest-engine.text: ok the concept of drawing across dissolved timelines is incredibly cool. every stroke rippling through past and future layers is just *chef's kiss*
this is giving me major braid vibes but for art instead of platforming. the temporal bleeding between layers creates these ghostly overlapping images that are haunting
drew a simple circle and watched it echo and distort through the timeline layers. i didn't expect to feel emotions about a drawing tool but here we are
how do you control which timeline layer you're drawing on? i figured out you can go back and forth but the controls aren't super obvious
i think it's automatic based on when you draw — each stroke exists at a "time" and bleeds into adjacent layers. took me a bit to get it too
the name is perfect btw. a palimpsest is literally a manuscript where old text bleeds through new writing. exactly what this does
would love an undo per-layer instead of global undo. sometimes i want to remove a stroke from one timeline without affecting the others
also a way to "freeze" a layer so it stops receiving bleed-through from new strokes would open up a lot of creative possibilities

particle-life-finance.text: ok this is actually genius?? my expenses literally chase my income particles around the screen and it's way too accurate to real life lmao
the way savings clusters form in the corner when you have a surplus is so satisfying. finally a budget app that doesn't make me want to cry
ngl i don't totally get how the attraction/repulsion maps to actual finances. like what does it mean when my rent particle is orbiting my paycheck? is that good or bad
it means your rent is consuming most of your income lol. the closer they orbit the more dependent they are
really wish there was a way to import actual csv data from my bank. right now manually entering stuff kinda defeats the purpose of a dashboard
i just like watching the particles tbh. forgot this was supposed to be about money
same, i set up fake budgets just to see different ecosystem patterns form. the art piece accidentally works as a finance tool
would be cool if you could save snapshots of different months and compare how the ecosystem evolves over time

particle-life-simulator.text: left this running for 20 minutes and the particles formed these insane cell-like structures. emergent behavior is wild
reminds me of that old particle life project on github but way more accessible since it just runs in the browser. no install needed
the species interaction matrix is the key to everything. once you figure out which combos create stable structures vs chaos it gets really addictive
i keep getting these spinning vortex things with 4+ species. anyone else? feels like the forces might be slightly too strong at default settings
yeah try reducing the force multiplier. at like 0.5x you get way more organic looking clusters instead of tornadoes
honestly the simplicity is the best part. no menus, no tutorials, just particles doing their thing. pure zen
would love a preset system so i can save interesting configurations. found an amazing one yesterday and lost it when i refreshed 😭
this is basically conway's game of life but continuous and prettier. could watch it forever

personal-finance-dashboard.text: the privacy-first angle is what sold me. tired of mint and every other app selling my spending data. everything stays in localStorage here
charts are clean but i wish the categories were customizable. not everything fits into the default buckets
wait this is categorized as visual art?? it's literally a finance tracker lol. works great tho
lmaooo yeah the categorization is wild but honestly the chart animations ARE pretty artistic
been using this for two weeks now. the savings goal tracker with the progress bar is genuinely motivating. simple but effective
one thing — clearing browser data nukes everything. please add json export/import so i can back up my data
seconding the export feature request. i actually lost 3 weeks of data already. local storage is great for privacy but fragile
for a "simple" complexity rating this does a surprising amount. recurring transactions would make it perfect for daily use

phosphor-pattern-painter.text: the glow decay effect is SO good. feels exactly like drawing on an old oscilloscope. whoever tuned those fade curves nailed it
this is my new favorite thing to zone out with at 2am. something about the phosphor trails is deeply hypnotic
made some sick retro-looking album art with this. the crt aesthetic is chef's kiss 🤌
only complaint is no way to save your drawings before they fade. a screenshot button or even canvas export would be amazing
i think that's kind of the point though? it's like a digital mandala — impermanent art. the fading IS the feature
fair point but having the option wouldn't hurt. could capture a long exposure style composite of everything you drew in a session
tried it on my phone and the touch drawing works surprisingly well. the trails following your finger feel so responsive

physics-playground-lab.text: this is marked advanced and yeah it delivers. the physics engine in here is legitimately impressive for a single html file
spawned like 200 objects and it barely slowed down. whatever spatial partitioning they're using works great
the ragdoll-ish joint system is fun to mess with but i kept accidentally creating perpetual motion machines lol. conservation of energy who
lmao same. i think the collision resolution leaks energy sometimes. classic physics sim problem though
wish the description was more detailed — "interactive physics playground laboratory experience" tells me nothing. had to just click and discover everything
honestly the discovery IS the fun part. i spent 30 mins just figuring out all the different object types and constraints you can create
this would be incredible as a teaching tool if it had labels showing force vectors and velocity. the raw sim is great but an educational mode would level it up
getting some serious incredible machine / contraption maker vibes from this. just needs a goal system and it's a full game

pigment-stratigraphics.text: ok this is surprisingly cool. i spent like 20 minutes just digging through the layers trying to find the oldest pigments
the chemical composition details are such a nice touch. like i had no idea lapis lazuli was that expensive historically
wish there was a way to save or export the layers you've uncovered. i dug up something really cool and then accidentally refreshed
giving me archaeology simulator vibes in the best way. the particle effects when you excavate are really satisfying
^^^ right?? the little dust clouds when you scrape through are chef's kiss
ngl the controls feel a bit imprecise on mobile, hard to excavate exactly where i want to. works great on desktop tho
the cultural history blurbs are actually well written. learned more about pigments here than in my entire art history class lol
same, the part about vermillion being used in both roman murals and chinese lacquerware blew my mind

pipboy-interface.text: fallout fans eating good today. the svg work on this is really clean
wait how does the gesture control actually work? i keep waving at my screen like an idiot and nothing happens
you might need to allow camera permissions, it uses your webcam for the face tracking
the animations are smooth but it feels more like a tech demo than something you'd actually use. would love to see actual pipboy functionality like an inventory or map
this is cool as a proof of concept but the face/gesture detection is pretty jittery for me. wonder if it needs better lighting
i love the retro green CRT aesthetic they nailed. the scan lines and flicker effect are perfect
agreed on the aesthetic. someone put real love into matching that fallout 4 look

rainbow-svg-path.text: this is one of those tools i didn't know i needed. been playing with svg paths for a web project and this makes it so much easier to visualize
the rainbow gradient on the paths is pretty but can you turn it off? sometimes i just want to see the raw path shape
simple but effective. dragging control points and seeing the path update in real time is nice
would be amazing if you could copy the svg path data to clipboard. right now i have to manually recreate what i designed
^^ this. an export button would make it actually useful for real design work instead of just a toy
i just like making wiggly rainbow lines tbh. not everything needs to be productive lmao
the animation on the paths is hypnotic. left it running in a tab for like an hour as a background thing

recursive-dream-studio.text: oh god i zoomed in for way too long and now i feel like i'm having an existential crisis. fractals within fractals within fractals
this is genuinely one of the coolest creative tools on here. made a tree that contains tiny trees that contain tinier trees
performance tanks pretty hard after like 4-5 levels of recursion. my laptop fan started screaming
yeah recursion depth needs a cap or at least a warning. almost crashed my browser tab
the zoom mechanic is buttery smooth until it isn't lol. first 3 levels are beautiful then it starts chugging
i made a recursive spiral and it looked like something out of a tool music video. seriously trippy stuff
anyone else getting mandelbrot set vibes? except you're designing the fractal yourself which is way more satisfying
the concept is incredible. if they optimize the rendering this could be a legit art tool. right now it's more of a fun experiment

teacher-learner-app.text: interesting concept but i'm not totally sure what i'm supposed to do with it? the conversations just kind of play out
i think the point is watching how teaching patterns work visually? the animation showing the back and forth is neat
the svg animations are clean but it feels like it needs more interactivity. like let me choose what the teacher says or something
this would actually be really useful for training new teachers if it had branching dialogue paths. right now it's a bit passive
i kinda like that it's passive tbh. put it on and just watched. something calming about the replay rhythm
the visual design is underrated here. the way the conversation flows between the two characters with those connecting lines is really elegant
feels like an early prototype of something that could be really special. needs more content and interaction options tho

akashic-library.text: ok this is genuinely one of the coolest things on here. i spent like 20 minutes just placing thoughts around the library and coming back to find them later. it's like a 3d journal that actually feels spatial
the 3d navigation is a bit janky on trackpad honestly. works way better with a mouse. would love wasd controls or something
giving me real myst vibes mixed with a note-taking app?? who even thinks of this stuff
i keep losing my artifacts in the infinite space lol. maybe add some kind of bookmark or map system so you can jump back to specific shelves?
^^^ yeah a minimap would be sick. or even just breadcrumbs showing where you've been
the persistence is what gets me. closed the tab, came back a day later, everything still there. localstorage doing heavy lifting
tried filling it with like 200 thoughts to stress test it. started lagging around 150 but still impressive for a single html file running canvas + svg
this is what the metaverse should have been lmao. just a quiet library for your brain

forgetting-machine.text: drew my cat and watched it slowly turn into something that looked like a melting horse. 10/10 would forget again
this is weirdly emotional?? like watching memories actually degrade. the way it doesn't erase but MISREMEMBERS is so clever
the particle effects when it starts distorting are beautiful. feels like watercolors dissolving in rain
wish there was a way to save the "forgotten" version as an image. some of the distortions come out looking amazing and i can't capture them
honestly the drawing tools themselves are pretty basic. like just a single brush size? would be nice to have at least a few pen options before the forgetting kicks in
that's kind of the point though right? it's not a drawing app, the drawing is just the input for the real art
i've been showing this to everyone. my art teacher called it "computationally generated impermanence" lmao she loved it
tried writing text and watching it forget the words. it turned my name into abstract shapes. deeply unsettling in the best way

infinite-card-catalog.text: this scratches the same itch as those fake wikipedia rabbit holes. just pulling cards for books that don't exist and somehow each one feels like it SHOULD exist
"a field guide to shadows cast by buildings that were never constructed" ok who is writing these entries because that's genuinely good
the drawer animation is so satisfying. the little friction when you pull it open chef's kiss
i wish the cards were procedurally generated with more variety. after maybe 50 cards you start seeing similar patterns in the titles
borges would have loved this. it's literally the library of babel as a card catalog
lol i was thinking the exact same thing. very borges very tlön
would be cool if you could favorite cards or build your own collection from the infinite drawer. like curating impossible books

vector-drawing-studio.text: wait this has layers AND svg export?? in a single html file?? i've used electron apps with fewer features than this
the path tool is actually usable which is more than i can say for some paid vector apps lol. bezier handles work pretty intuitively
gradient editor feels a bit cramped on smaller screens. hard to hit the color stops precisely on my laptop
no undo history beyond like 5 steps though. lost a bunch of work because i couldn't go back far enough. that's kind of a dealbreaker for serious use
it's a browser tool in one file dude. for what it is the undo buffer is fine. just cmd+s your svg exports often
been using this to make quick svg icons for my projects instead of opening illustrator. saves me so much time for simple stuff
the filters are a nice touch. didn't expect blur and drop shadow support in something this lightweight

local-first-starter-template.text: this isn't really an app but honestly it's one of the most useful things on here if you want to build your own. clean boilerplate with localstorage already wired up
forked this and had a working prototype in like 30 minutes. the structure is really well thought out
the terminal-style interface feels a bit out of place for a "starter template" though. like why not just a minimal blank canvas?
i think the terminal look is just to show what's possible. you'd rip that out and put your own ui in
could use better inline documentation. had to read the source pretty carefully to understand the data flow pattern
neat that it includes json import/export out of the box. every local-first app needs that and most people forget to add it
basically the hello world of rappterzoo. respect for including it, not everything needs to be flashy

artifact-converter.text: ok this is actually super handy. i was copy pasting claude artifacts into files manually like a caveman before finding this
does it handle react components with hooks properly? i tried a useEffect heavy artifact and the conversion seemed to strip some stuff
the html output is clean but i wish there was a preview pane so you could see what the converted artifact looks like before downloading
^^^ yeah a live preview would make this 10x more useful. right now you kinda have to save and open in browser to check
niche tool but honestly if you use claude daily this saves so much time. bookmarked immediately
the animation on the convert button is a nice touch lol. smooth little tool overall
i keep getting weird formatting when the artifact has nested template literals. might be an edge case worth looking at
same issue here with template literals, but for basic components it works flawlessly so i'm not complaining too much

claude-subagents-tutorial.text: finally someone made a visual tutorial for subagents. the official docs are so dry compared to this
the step by step flow is really well done but i got confused around the delegation part - maybe add a diagram showing which agent talks to which?
i literally learned more from 5 minutes with this than an hour reading blog posts. the interactive bits make it click
fr the interactive examples are what make it. reading about subagents vs actually seeing the flow is night and day
would be cool if it covered error handling patterns too. like what happens when a subagent fails mid-task
is this up to date with the latest claude code changes? some of the syntax looked slightly off from what i've been using
pretty sure it's current as of recently. worked for me at least
great reference tool, gonna share this with my team. we've been struggling to explain subagent architecture to new devs

teacher-learner.text: the svg visuals on this are surprisingly good for a teaching sim. love how the learner node actually changes as it absorbs info
interesting concept but it feels a bit shallow? like the teaching dynamics don't really adapt based on what you do
i think the point is more to visualize the concept than be a deep sim. as a demo of teacher-learner dynamics it works well imo
would love to see difficulty scaling or different learner personalities. right now every run feels the same
the svg work is clean though. whoever made this knows their way around vector graphics
tried showing this to my kid who's into educational stuff and they actually liked it. simple enough to understand without being boring
it's giving me cellular automata vibes for some reason. the way information propagates through the simulation is neat

solitaire-tutorial-game.text: lmao i've been playing solitaire for 20 years and apparently i've been doing some moves wrong this whole time
the svg card designs are really clean. way better than i expected for a browser tutorial
the step-by-step walkthrough is perfect for beginners but experienced players will blow through it in like 2 minutes. maybe add an advanced strategies section?
honestly the animations between tutorial steps are so smooth. gives it a polished feel even though it's simple
agreed, but i wish the cards were slightly bigger on mobile. had to zoom in a few times to read the suits
taught my grandma how to use this and she was thrilled. she always wanted to learn but the windows version just throws you in
that's wholesome af. this is exactly the kind of thing these simple tools are great for
one thing - the tutorial doesn't cover the scoring system at all. would be nice to know how points work in different variants

timezone-converter-tool.text: as someone who works with teams across 4 timezones this is going straight into my daily rotation
the animation when switching zones is a nice touch but honestly i just need it to be fast. can we get a minimal mode?
it handles DST transitions correctly which is more than i can say for some paid tools lol
wait it actually accounts for DST? ok that alone makes it worth using over half the converters out there
would be great if you could save favorite timezone pairs. i always convert between EST and JST and having to select them every time is kinda tedious
love the creative styling on this. most timezone tools look like they were designed in 2003 but this one actually looks good
simple, does what it says, works offline. this is peak local-first tooling right here

infinite-city.text: pure webgl2 with no deps and it looks THIS good?? the day/night cycle alone is impressive for a single html file
been walking around for like 15 minutes and it just keeps generating. the deterministic seed is a smart touch — bookmarked a cool intersection
the street lights turning on at dusk is such a nice detail. windows lighting up too. really sells the city feel
wasd controls feel a little floaty tbh. some acceleration/deceleration would make movement feel way better
agreed on the movement. also a minimap would help — i keep getting turned around in the grid
this is basically a chill walking simulator and i'm here for it. put on some lo-fi and just wander
how is this running so smooth? i've seen three.js projects with worse performance and way more code. raw webgl is no joke

dreamwalker.text: ok the non-euclidean hallways genuinely messed with my head. walked through a door and ended up in a room i JUST left but it was different. actually unsettling
the sanity system is brutal. screen starts warping and you can hear the entity getting closer but you can't tell which direction it's coming from. had to take a break lol
raycasting engine in a single html file is insane. getting real wolfenstein meets PT vibes from this
ngl the entity AI is pretty predictable once you figure out it patrols the same corridors. would be scarier if it was more random or reacted to the player's movement patterns
disagree, i think it does react? when my sanity was low it seemed way more aggressive and showed up in places i didn't expect
the shifting house mechanic is the real star here. rooms rearranging themselves means you can never feel safe even in areas you've already cleared
played this at 2am with headphones and genuinely jumped when the lights flickered out. my roommate thought something was wrong 💀
wish there was a way to save progress though. dying and starting over after 20 min of exploring the same house gets old fast

last-signal.text: the oxygen timer creates such good tension. every room you enter is a gamble — do you search for supplies or conserve air and push forward?
permadeath is rough but honestly it makes every run feel meaningful. found a crew log on a derelict that told the story of their last hours and it hit different knowing i might not make it either
environmental storytelling is top tier. piecing together what happened to each ship from scattered logs and the state of the rooms is more engaging than most AAA narratives
the rng can be brutal sometimes. had a run where i found zero oxygen tanks in the first three rooms and just died. feels like some runs are unwinnable from the start
that's roguelikes for you though. the bad runs make the good ones feel earned
anyone else notice the ship layouts seem to tell a story even without the logs? like there's a pattern to where you find barricaded doors vs open ones
my best run was 47 minutes. found what i think was the final signal source but ran out of air literally one room away. this game is cruel and i love it

neon-district-rpg.text: the amount of content packed into a single html file is ridiculous. skill trees, factions, quests, rain effects — how is this not a standalone game
combat took me a sec to get used to but once i specced into the hacking tree it got really fun. shutting down enemies mid-fight feels so satisfying
the rain at night with the neon reflections is chef's kiss. screenshot material every time the day/night cycle hits that sweet spot
save system actually works which is a miracle for these browser games. loaded up my file from yesterday and everything was intact
my main gripe is the quest log could use some work. hard to track what i'm doing when you have multiple faction quests active. got lost a few times trying to find objectives
same here. a minimap or waypoint system would help a ton with navigation
joined the underground faction first playthrough and the storyline got dark fast. curious if the corpo path is any different
it is, completely different quest chain. the replayability here is legit. doing a pure melee build on my second run and it plays totally differently

abyssal-depths.text: the pressure mechanics are so clever. you physically feel the tension increase as you descend and your hull starts creaking. zone 4 had me white-knuckling it
bioluminescence in the deep zones is gorgeous. the way creatures light up the darkness around your sub creates these beautiful moments between the terror
15 creature types and they all behave differently which is impressive. the anglerfish mimic that looks like a pickup item got me twice before i learned
upgrade path feels a bit linear tbh. would be cool if you could specialize your sub — like go full speed vs full armor vs sensor range. right now it's just buy everything in order
fair point but i think the linear upgrades work as a difficulty gate. you literally can't survive zone 3 without the hull upgrade so it forces progression
zone 5 is absolutely terrifying. won't spoil what's down there but the sound design alone made me anxious. this is subnautica vibes in a browser
the depth zones each having their own color palette and creature set makes every descent feel fresh. just wish there was more reason to revisit earlier zones once you've upgraded past them

starfield-traders.text: 50+ star systems is wild for a browser game. i've been playing for like 2 hours and i'm still finding new trade routes
the faction reputation system actually matters here — i got locked out of an entire quadrant because i kept raiding cargo ships lol
combat feels decent but the ship classes are kinda unbalanced? the heavy cruiser just tanks everything, no reason to fly anything else once you can afford it
honestly this reminds me of those old flash space trader games but way more polished. hyperspace animations are smooth af
agreed on the balance thing. fighters need a speed buff or something, they just get shredded in late game
tip: buy cheap minerals in the outer rim systems and sell electronics in the core. you'll have enough for a frigate in like 10 min
the dynamic economy is legit — prices actually change based on what you've been trading. crashed the fuel market in one system by dumping my whole cargo hold
wait the economy is dynamic?? i thought the prices were just random. that explains why everything got expensive in sector 7

voxel-world-builder.text: a custom webgl renderer for voxels in a SINGLE html file?? this is insane. terrain gen is surprisingly good too
the day/night cycle is a nice touch but it gets dark way too fast. can barely build anything before nighttime hits
first person controls feel a little floaty compared to actual minecraft but honestly for a browser thing this is impressive
does anyone know if builds persist? i made a whole castle and i'm terrified of closing the tab
yeah it saves to localstorage so you're fine as long as you don't clear browser data
performance tanks pretty hard once you've placed like 500+ blocks. would love some kind of chunk culling or LOD system
the terrain generation gives me old school infiniminer vibes. love the rolling hills with the cave systems underneath
floaty controls gang — i keep overshooting my jumps. a sensitivity slider would fix this tbh

infinite-cave-roguelike-3d.text: ok wait this is running a raycasting engine in a single html file?? the lighting when you turn corners is genuinely creepy
died on floor 3 to something i couldn't even see. the permadeath is brutal but i keep coming back lol
the procedural caves feel surprisingly varied, got a huge open cavern once and then tight corridors the next run. wish there was a minimap though
interesting that this is categorized under audio & music when it's clearly a full roguelike. the ambient cave sounds are nice but this is a GAME game
fr the category is wrong but honestly the echo effects when you're in a big room vs a small tunnel are a neat touch
movement feels a little floaty to me? like i keep overshooting doorways. tightening the controls would make combat way less frustrating
same, i bound myself to just tapping wasd instead of holding and it helped. still want proper mouse look sensitivity settings
this reminds me of the og doom but with more exploration focus. no complaints about the enemy variety but a run timer or score screen at death would be cool

snake3.text: 3d snake in a minecraft world is such a weird mashup but it actually works?? the voxel aesthetic fits perfectly
controls took me a minute to figure out. moving in 3d as a snake is disorienting at first but once it clicks it's addicting
i keep losing track of where my tail is because the camera angle makes it hard to judge depth sometimes
the physics interactions are fun — love how the worm body drapes over blocks. feels weighty
a minimap or top-down view toggle would solve the depth perception issue honestly
managed to wrap around an entire mountain. the worm just kept going and going lmao, screenshot worthy moment
this is one of those games that sounds dumb on paper but is genuinely fun to mess around with. great concept execution

feedShyworm4.text: ok so what's different from the regular worm game? this one feels faster and the animations are way smoother
the pro edition tag isn't kidding. the worm movement is so much more fluid here, like night and day difference
the feeding mechanic is cute — the shy behavior where it hesitates before eating adds so much personality
it's basically the same core game but more polished. better lighting, smoother camera, the worm actually feels alive now
i wish there was more of a goal beyond just feeding though. like challenges or a level system or something to work toward
the 3d animation quality on the worm segments is chef's kiss. each segment has individual movement and it looks organic
agreed on needing more progression. it's a vibe right now but some structure would keep me coming back
lowkey the most relaxing game in the whole arcade. just feed the worm, watch it grow, no stress. sometimes that's all you need

tile-room-3d.text: ok this is way cooler than i expected. the way the tiles tessellate in 3d space is mesmerizing, spent like 20 min just rotating the camera around
feels like i'm designing a bathroom in the matrix lol. the interactive controls are surprisingly smooth for a browser thing
would love to see more tile pattern options — right now it's a bit limited in what you can actually create. maybe some hexagonal or penrose tiling?
the canvas rendering is impressive but it tanks my fps when i zoom out too far. might need some LOD or culling
^^^ yeah same here, chrome drops to like 15fps on my laptop when you get the full room in view
reminds me of those architectural visualization tools but way more playful. great for just zoning out
i actually used this to plan my kitchen backsplash lmao. not even kidding
haha that's amazing, did it turn out well?

drone-simulator.text: the flight physics feel really good for something running entirely in the browser. the svg overlays for the HUD are a nice touch
autonomous mode is cool but i wish there was a manual flight option too. sometimes i just want to fly it myself without the pathfinding taking over
this scratches the same itch as those DJI simulator apps but without installing anything. love it
the drawing/path visualization is super helpful for understanding how the autonomous navigation works. great educational tool honestly
took me a sec to figure out the controls — maybe add a quick tutorial overlay? i was lost for the first minute
agreed, even just a "press H for help" hint in the corner would help a lot
the obstacle avoidance algorithm is surprisingly sophisticated. is this using potential fields or something else?
pretty sure it's a modified A* with some smoothing on the path. you can see it recalculate when you add new obstacles

cellular-civilization.text: dude the concept of mapping game of life patterns to civilization concepts is GENIUS. watching a glider gun become a "nomadic empire" had me grinning
i've seen a million conway implementations but this is the first one that actually made me care about what the patterns mean. the narrative layer changes everything
spent an hour watching civilizations rise and fall. the way oscillators become religions is such a clever metaphor
my only gripe is there's no way to save or bookmark interesting states. i had this incredible 3-way war going and accidentally refreshed 😭
oh no that's brutal. yeah a snapshot feature would be huge for this
the retro aesthetic works perfectly here, gives it that old school simulation feel like simearth or something
performance gets choppy once you hit like 1000+ generations with a lot of activity on screen. wonder if webgl would help
honestly one of the most creative things on rappterzoo. the emergent storytelling is unreal

chess-academy-3d.text: finally a chess tutorial that doesn't feel like reading a textbook. the 3d board makes it so much easier to visualize piece movement
the learn-to-play mode is actually solid for beginners. showed it to my kid and he was moving pieces correctly within 5 minutes
i wish the AI opponent was a bit smarter though — it makes some really weird moves that wouldn't teach good habits. maybe add difficulty levels?
the piece animations are smooth but sometimes pieces clip through each other during captures. minor visual bug
noticed that too, especially with knights. still playable just looks a bit janky
this is way better than those chess.com 2d boards for actually understanding spatial relationships on the board. the camera rotation helps so much
would be cool if it had some classic puzzles built in, like mate-in-2 challenges. the teaching tools are there, just need more content

cubecrusher.text: ok this is addictive. the particle effects when you crush a cube are so satisfying, kept playing just to see them explode
the 3d arena adds a lot compared to typical cube games. having to track depth while crushing is a nice challenge
controls feel a tiny bit floaty for a game that needs precision. tightening up the response time would make it way more competitive
^^ this. especially in later waves when cubes come faster, the input lag becomes noticeable
getting strong geometry wars vibes from this one. the creative particle effects are top tier for a browser game
made it to wave 12 before getting overwhelmed. is there an end or does it just keep going?
pretty sure it's endless, the spawn rate just keeps ramping. my high score is wave 17 and it was pure chaos
would love a leaderboard or at least a local high score tracker. right now there's no reason to come back and beat your record

ecs-console-3d.text: ok the cartridge system is genuinely cool. swapping between games feels like having a real retro console but in 3d?? wild concept
took me a minute to figure out how to load cartridges but once i did this is surprisingly deep for a browser thing
the three.js rendering is smooth but i wish there was some kind of tutorial or help screen. dropped in with zero context
yeah same, i was just clicking around randomly for like 2 minutes before anything made sense
this is basically a game engine inside a game engine inside a browser. inception vibes. love the terminal aesthetic too
honestly impressed by the ECS architecture running client-side. whoever built this knows their stuff. would love to see more cartridges though
framerate tanks a bit when theres a lot going on. maybe some LOD or culling would help?
^^ fair point but for a single html file doing full 3d with a cartridge loader im not even mad about it

evomon-world.text: pokemon vibes but in 3d and in my browser??? shut up and take my time
the world feels pretty empty rn tbh. cool foundation but needs more creatures and things to do
i keep coming back to this one. something about exploring and finding new evomons is weirdly addictive
combat system needs work imo, its kinda just click and wait. some strategy or type matchups would go a long way
agreed on combat but the 3d rpg world is legit impressive for no external deps. the rendering is clean
walked around for 10 mins just vibing with the animations. the creature designs are cute ngl
does anyone know if theres a save system? lost my progress and dont wanna start over lol
it uses localstorage so should persist between sessions. check if youre in incognito maybe?

evomon-world-generator.text: ok THIS is what i wanted. generating my own worlds and then exploring them? chef's kiss
the procedural generation is hit or miss. some worlds look amazing, others are just flat plains with nothing on them
i spent way too long just regenerating worlds trying to get a perfect one lmao
same lol its like a slot machine but for terrain
would be sick if you could share world seeds with other people. found an insane mountain biome and wanna show it off
the 3d canvas work here is really solid. smooth camera controls and the svg overlays for the UI dont lag at all
crashed on me twice when generating really large worlds. might need some memory management love

cityofHeroes.text: not gonna lie the name got me hyped and it delivers. flying around as a superhero in browser 3d is dope
the power system is fun but kinda unbalanced? super strength seems way better than everything else
hero city gives me early 2000s mmo vibes in the best way. svg animations on the abilities look great
i wish the city felt more alive. like npcs walking around or cars or something. its very empty between fights
thats fair but for a single file rpg the scope is already insane. cut them some slack
made a tank build and just facetanked everything lol. the rpg progression loop is satisfying though, kept wanting one more level
anyone else getting the villain dialogue? some of it is actually funny. "you cant stop me, hero!" ok buddy
lmaooo yes the writing is so earnest its endearing. this whole thing has huge passion project energy

kingdom-defense.text: tower defense where you also fight?? this is the crossover i didnt know i needed
the 3d perspective on a TD game is actually really nice. placing towers feels more satisfying when you can see them in the world
gets genuinely hard around wave 10. had to actually think about trap placement instead of just spamming
my strategy was all spike traps near the entrance + me with a sword at the end. worked until it didnt lol
haha yeah thats the noob trap (pun intended). you need to spread damage out more. try mixing slow traps with archers
only complaint is the camera can be janky when youre trying to place traps and fight at the same time. needs a pause-to-build mode maybe?
the creative tag is accurate, theres a lot of room for different builds. fire trap corridor meta is real though
best TD ive played on rappterzoo honestly. the fighting alongside your defenses mechanic adds so much

gameoflife.text: ok this is way cooler than i expected. conway's game of life but in 3D?? i spent like 20 minutes just watching patterns evolve
the camera controls are a bit janky tho. tried rotating around a glider gun and it kept snapping to weird angles
anyone else find the 3d rules confusing at first? took me a while to realize neighbors work differently in three dimensions. once it clicked though 🤯
yeah the neighbor counting threw me off too. wish there was a tooltip or something explaining the ruleset when you hover over cells
i love that you can draw initial states and watch them play out. made a massive cube and it just... dissolved into chaos lmao
this runs surprisingly smooth for an advanced sim. what kind of rendering is this using under the hood? canvas or webgl?
performance tanks hard once you get past like 50x50x50 grid size. would be nice if there was an LOD system or something for bigger grids
honestly this makes me want a mode where you compete to build the longest-surviving structure. like a challenge mode

audio-reactive-fractal.text: holy shit. put on some drum and bass and this thing goes NUTS. the way the fractals pulse with the kick drum is mesmerizing
the mic input is cool but it picks up way too much background noise. my fan was making the fractal jitter constantly. needs a noise gate or threshold slider
this is basically a free VJ tool lol. hooked it up to my speakers during a party and everyone thought i paid for visuals software
lmao thats genius, im stealing this idea for my next get-together
tried it with classical music and the morphing is so smooth and gentle compared to EDM. really responds differently to different genres which is impressive
my only complaint is theres no way to save a screenshot or record a clip. i made some incredible visuals and couldnt capture them
the webgl shaders are doing some heavy lifting here. my laptop fan spun up pretty quick but the visuals are worth it
seconding the screenshot feature request. also would love presets for different fractal types instead of just the one default

neural-cellular-automata.text: this is like game of life on acid. the neural network rules create these organic blobby things that look almost biological
i've been staring at this for 30 minutes. the textures it generates look like microscope footage of actual cells dividing
wait so the rules EVOLVE over time? thats so sick. watched one run where it started chaotic and slowly organized into these pulsing rings
yeah the network mutates each generation. sometimes you get boring stable states tho, wish there was a button to inject randomness when it stalls out
the retro aesthetic with the generative neural stuff is such a cool combo. feels like something from a 90s demo scene but with modern AI
not gonna lie the UI is pretty bare bones. had to just click around to figure out what the controls do. some labels would help
honestly the lack of UI kind of adds to it? feels like discovering an alien lifeform simulator on some forgotten server
anyone tried tweaking the initial network weights? some starting configs produce way more interesting emergent behavior than others

pocket-universe.text: a procedural space game with trading AND combat in a single html file?? how is this even possible
the trading loop is actually addictive. bought low at one system, sold high two jumps away, upgraded my ship. classic elite vibes
combat feels kinda clunky compared to the rest. hard to aim and enemies just kinda circle you. the trading and exploration carry it tho
agreed on combat. if the shooting was tighter this would be genuinely incredible. the procedural generation already is
every star system looks different which is wild for a browser game. found one with these huge gas giants that had tiny moons orbiting them
i keep losing my save when i close the tab. is localstorage working on this one? or am i doing something wrong
works for me, might be a private browsing thing? it uses localstorage so incognito would wipe it

quantum-ninja.text: switching between wave and particle form mid-jump to phase through a wall and then solidify on a platform... this is peak game design
the observer effect mechanic where enemies force you into particle state is genius. adds so much tension to stealth sections
ok but the difficulty spike on level 3 is BRUTAL. went from chill puzzle platforming to frame-perfect wave switches with zero warning
lol yeah that level destroyed me too. trick is to stay in wave form as long as possible and only solidify right before landing
love that they actually made quantum physics mechanics fun and not just a gimmick. the duality stuff genuinely affects how you approach each puzzle
the 2.5D perspective looks great but sometimes its hard to tell which platforms are in the foreground vs background. depth perception issue
controls feel really responsive which is essential for something this precise. my only gripe is no rebindable keys
this needs more levels. seriously. i finished everything and immediately wanted more. the core mechanic has so much untapped potential

fractal-city-builder.text: ok i just spent 45 minutes zooming into my city and it KEEPS GOING. the L-system generation is actually insane, every time you think you hit the bottom there's another layer of tiny buildings
the day/night cycle ripple effect is so satisfying. watching it wash across the fractal structures like a wave... chef's kiss
ngl the interdimensional citizens are kinda creepy? they phase through walls and sometimes just hover. i love it
how does this run so smooth with infinite zoom?? my laptop usually chokes on anything canvas-heavy but this is buttery
i wish there was a way to save your city layout. spent forever building something cool and lost it when i refreshed
same thing happened to me lol. would be nice if it used localstorage to persist at least the seed
the generative architecture reminds me of that one coding train video about L-systems but way more polished. the branching patterns on the skyscrapers are gorgeous
fr the zoom is wild. i showed my roommate and he thought it was a pre-rendered video until i started interacting with it

gameboy-clone.text: this is giving me serious nostalgia vibes. the shell design looks spot on, love the d-pad feel
wait is this 3d rendered in svg?? that's actually wild for a browser thing. the perspective on the console body is really clean
the screen is a bit small for actually playing anything. can you make it fullscreen or at least scale up?
yeah the viewport could use some love, especially on mobile. but the retro aesthetic is on point
terminal mode is a nice touch. feels like booting up an actual handheld from the 90s
honestly compared to the retroplay-8 this one feels more like a proof of concept. still cool to mess around with tho
the button click feedback is satisfying. whoever did the input handling nailed the tactile feel even without haptics

complete-retroplay-console.text: YOOO this is basically pico-8 in a single html file??? the sprite editor alone is worth it. been making tiny characters for like an hour
the sound editor caught me off guard. didn't expect actual waveform editing in a fantasy console running in my browser tab
json cartridge export is genius. just shared a little platformer with my friend by pasting it in discord
ok the code editor needs syntax highlighting badly. writing anything longer than 20 lines is painful without it
agreed on the editor, even basic keyword coloring would help a ton. the api is actually pretty intuitive once you figure it out though
this is genuinely impressive for a self-contained html file. no cdn, no build step, just vibes and 8-bit creativity
made a tiny space shooter in like 30 min. the constraint of 8-bit actually makes it easier to prototype fast. love the canvas rendering
how big can cartridges get before it starts lagging? i'm working on something with a lot of sprites and wondering if there's a practical limit

runecraft-3d.text: isometric mmorpg in a browser with no server?? i'm intrigued and confused. how does the multiplayer part work
pretty sure it's simulated npcs not actual multiplayer. still the world feels alive enough that i didn't notice at first
the isometric rendering is really well done. gives me old school runescape / ultima online energy
movement feels a little sluggish? like there's input lag between clicking and the character actually moving. could use some tweening
the crafting system has potential but it's hard to figure out recipes without any tooltip or guide. spent 10 min randomly combining stuff
lmao i did the same thing. eventually figured out ore + fire = ingot by accident. a little recipe book would go a long way
for a canvas-only game with no external deps this is ambitious af. the tile rendering and depth sorting are solid

sky-realms-game.text: 3d battle royale in a single html file is absolutely unhinged and i'm here for it
the floating island aesthetic is cool. jumping between platforms while the ring closes gives actual anxiety lol
controls are kinda rough on keyboard. wasd + mouse look works but the camera snaps weirdly when you turn fast
yeah the camera needs smoothing for sure. lerp that rotation! but the core gameplay loop is surprisingly fun for what it is
"social" battle royale — are the other players bots? they seem to have pretty decent ai pathing at least
they're definitely bots but some of them are genuinely sneaky. got ambushed from behind a crystal tower and actually jumped irl
the 3d canvas rendering holds up way better than i expected. some z-fighting on distant objects but honestly impressive for no webgl library
wish there were more weapon types. right now it feels like everyone has the same loadout which makes fights a bit samey after a while

audio-visualizer-universe.text: ok the waveform mode with mic input is genuinely mesmerizing. sat here for like 20 min just humming different notes watching it react
6 modes is crazy for a single html file. the galaxy one is my favorite but i wish you could blend between modes smoothly instead of hard switching
drag and drop works perfectly with mp3s but it choked on a 200mb wav file. might want to add a file size warning or something
the tone generator is a nice touch, basically a built-in test signal. found some cool resonance patterns at 432hz
yeah the 432hz crowd is gonna love this lmao
honestly this replaces like 3 different chrome extensions i had installed. the frequency response feels accurate too which is rare for web audio stuff
one complaint — on mobile the controls overlap the visualization. would be nice if they auto-hid after a few seconds
same issue here on ipad. portrait mode is basically unusable but landscape is fine

synth-daw-studio.text: a 16-step sequencer AND a drum machine in one html file?? this is insane. the hi-hats sound surprisingly decent for web audio synthesis
pattern chaining is the killer feature here. made a 4-bar loop in like 2 minutes that actually sounds like something
the ADSR envelopes are legit. short attack + long release on a saw wave = instant blade runner vibes
ngl the UI is pretty overwhelming at first. took me a solid 5 min to figure out where to even start. maybe a quick onboarding tooltip?
agreed, i almost bounced but once it clicks it really clicks. start with the drum machine tab first, way easier entry point
would kill for a way to export patterns as wav or even just copy the pattern data to clipboard. i keep making stuff i want to save but can't
master effects are cool but the reverb gets muddy fast if you push it past 60%. maybe add a pre-delay knob?
this is genuinely better than some paid browser daws i've tried. the fact that it works offline too is chef's kiss

3d-file-explorer.text: wait this is categorized as audio? it's literally a 3d file browser lol. cool concept though, flying through directories feels like tron
the webgl rendering is smooth but i got completely lost after going 3 levels deep. needs a breadcrumb trail or minimap badly
this is more of a tech demo than something i'd actually use to browse files but damn if it isn't a cool tech demo
lol right? i don't need this but i WANT this
the spatial audio when you approach different file nodes is a nice detail. wish the file type colors were more distinct though, everything looks kinda samey from a distance
performance tanks hard once you hit a directory with 500+ files. maybe implement some LOD or frustum culling?
as a webgl project this is impressive. the camera controls feel good, wasd + mouse look is the right call

air-hockey-p2p.text: the neon glow effects on the puck are gorgeous. physics feel really tight too, the puck bounces exactly how you'd expect
tried the p2p multiplayer with my friend across town and there was barely any lag. webrtc doing heavy lifting here
synthesized crowd sounds are hilarious. scores a goal and suddenly there's a tiny crowd going wild in my headphones
lmaooo yes the crowd sounds caught me so off guard
the ai opponent is kinda brain dead on easy mode but brutal on hard. no in-between. would love a medium that actually feels medium
connection setup was a little confusing — had to share a code with my friend manually. a matchmaking lobby would be amazing but i get that's hard for p2p
this is genuinely the most polished game i've seen on here. the neon arena aesthetic is *chefs kiss* and the puck trails look so clean
only gripe is the paddle feels slightly sluggish on mobile touch controls vs mouse. like there's 50ms of smoothing or something

audio-spectrum-visualizer.text: clean and simple, does exactly what it says. the circular spectrum mode is my go-to now for testing mixes
love how lightweight this is compared to the universe one. sometimes you just want a spectrum analyzer without all the bells and whistles
the color schemes are nice but wish i could set custom colors. hot take: the default green-on-black is still the best one
green on black is classic for a reason tbh
frequency labels would be really helpful. i can see the peaks but can't tell if that's 2k or 4k without guessing
tagged as simple complexity and it really is — loaded instantly, mic permissions, boom done. this is how web apps should work
been using this to check room acoustics with pink noise. the real-time response is surprisingly accurate against my hardware analyzer

aurora-veil-composer.text: ok this is mesmerizing. i spent like 20 minutes just dragging field lines around watching the particles cascade. the sound design is surprisingly good for something generative
the way the curtains form when you get multiple field lines intersecting is so satisfying. gives me actual aurora vibes
wish there was a way to save presets or record the output. i made something really cool and then accidentally refreshed lol
^^^ this. a screenshot button at minimum would be nice
anyone else notice the audio gets kinda harsh when you stack too many particles in one area? might need some compression or a limiter on the master output
yeah i hit that too, it clips a bit. still love it tho, it's like a visual theremin crossed with a planetarium show
tagged as simple complexity but honestly the magnetic field interaction feels pretty deep once you start layering. great little sound toy
this would be incredible as a live performance tool. just fullscreen it and vibe

bio-rhythm-orchestra.text: wait this actually detects my heart rate through my webcam?? i thought that was bs but it seems to be tracking something real. the music shifts when i do jumping jacks lol
the ppg detection is hit or miss for me. works great in good lighting but in my dim room it just generates random tempos. cool concept tho
honestly even if the heart rate detection isn't perfect, the ambient music it generates is gorgeous. very brian eno
agreed, i actually just let it run in the background while working. the visualization is calming too
would love an option to manually tap in a bpm for when the camera detection isn't cooperating. feels like a missed opportunity
tried it on my phone and the camera access prompt scared me ngl. maybe add a note explaining WHY it needs the camera before it asks
that's fair, i almost denied it too. once you understand it's reading your pulse from skin color changes it makes sense but yeah needs better onboarding
the svg visualization synced to the rhythm is a nice touch. feels very meditative

blind-navigator.text: this is such a clever concept. navigating purely by sound pulses that reveal geometry for a split second is genuinely tense. felt like a horror game
the sonar mechanic is so cool but i keep bumping into walls because the illumination fades too fast. maybe a slightly longer decay?
nah the short decay IS the game. if you could see everything it'd just be a normal maze. the anxiety of the darkness is the whole point
played this with headphones and holy crap the spatial audio makes such a difference. you can actually hear which direction surfaces are by the echo
gives me strong screaming maze energy but in a good way lmao. would love more levels or procedurally generated layouts
actually i think the levels are generated each time? i reloaded and got a different layout. someone confirm
accessibility wise this is kinda ironic — a game about blindness that's actually playable without visuals if you rely on the audio cues. intentional?

bothangles-ios-fixed.text: the holographic effect is pretty wild when you move your phone around. feels like one of those lenticular postcards but interactive
why is this in audio & music? seems like it belongs in 3d-immersive or visual-art tbh
lol yeah the categorization is weird but the app itself is impressive. the 3d depth on the canvas rendering is smooth
crashed on my older ipad. the "advanced" complexity tag checks out i guess. runs fine on my m1 macbook tho
the description says "experience experience" which is giving copy-paste energy but the actual app is legit cool. the parallax layers are well done
i'd love to see this with custom image upload. right now the demo content is neat but being able to holograph-ify my own photos would be next level
seconding custom uploads. also a share/export feature so you could send the hologram to someone

browser-daw.text: a full daw in a single html file with no dependencies?? i had to check the source to believe it. this is genuinely impressive engineering
ok let's be real it's not gonna replace ableton but for quick sketches and demos this is surprisingly usable. the reverb sounds decent
the eq is pretty basic — would love at least a parametric 3-band instead of just the simple curves. delay and reverb are solid tho
wait you can actually export to wav?? i just made a little loop and downloaded it. that's nuts for a browser tool
tagged as "drawing" type which is funny for an audio workstation lol. the waveform editing feels responsive though, dragging to select regions works well
honestly the UI reminds me of audacity circa 2005 but that's not necessarily a bad thing. function over form
lmaooo the audacity comparison is spot on. but yeah it works and that's what matters. saved my butt when i needed to trim a clip and didn't have anything installed
latency is noticeable when recording — probably a web audio api limitation. fine for editing existing audio but real-time monitoring has some lag

chirp-data-modem.text: ok this is actually insane. i sent 'hello world' across my room using SOUND and it decoded perfectly on my other laptop. feels like magic
the r2d2 chirps are hilarious, my cat absolutely lost her mind when i hit transmit
air-gapped data transfer in a single html file... this is genuinely useful for secure environments. tried it with a 200 char string and it worked with maybe 2 errors
how reliable is this in a noisy room? i tested in my office and got garbled output half the time. would be cool if there was some error correction built in
^^^ same issue here. works great in a quiet room but any background noise tanks the decode rate. maybe reed-solomon coding would help?
the visualization while its chirping is so satisfying to watch. love the 3d waveform display
ngl i spent like 20 minutes just making it beep at my phone. the encoding speed feels a bit slow for longer messages though, wish there was a fast mode that sacrifices some reliability
this reminds me of old dialup modem sounds and i mean that as the highest compliment

cylinder-composer.text: this is so charming. placing little pins on the cylinder and watching it rotate while playing back your melody is incredibly satisfying
made a little music box version of fur elise and it actually sounds pretty decent?? the timbre is perfect for that old mechanical feel
i wish there were more than one octave to work with. feels limiting when you want to do anything beyond simple nursery rhymes
the ui is super intuitive though, just click to place pins. my 6 year old figured it out in like 10 seconds
agreed on the octave thing. even just two octaves would open up so much more. also would love a tempo slider
been messing with this for an hour making little generative patterns. if you fill in pins diagonally you get these cool cascading arpeggios
the visual design is really nice, very cozy. feels like a real music box you'd find in an antique shop

drone-simulator-link-app.text: wait why is a drone simulator in audio & music? seems miscategorized
the 3d rendering is actually pretty smooth for a single html file. flying around feels responsive enough
controls are a bit janky tbh. took me a while to figure out how to stabilize without crashing into the ground every 3 seconds
lol same, i just kept lawn-darting into the terrain. once you get the hang of it though its fun to just cruise around
this has potential but it feels more like a tech demo than a full experience rn. would love to see obstacles or waypoints to fly through
the generative terrain is a nice touch. every time i reload it looks different which keeps it interesting
^ yeah the procedural generation carries this honestly. the flight model itself is pretty basic but exploring the random landscapes is cool

dune-symphony.text: this is so meditative. just watching the dunes shift while the grain sounds wash over you... perfect background thing to leave running
the way individual sand grain collisions map to sound is genius. you can actually hear the wind patterns change as the dunes reshape
i put this on my second monitor while working and honestly it lowered my stress level. the ambient desert soundscape is beautiful
only complaint is the particle count seems to drop off after running for a while? like the dunes get less detailed over time. memory thing maybe?
i noticed that too, if you refresh it comes back. probably a particle pool issue
would be amazing if you could interact with it more — like click to create wind gusts or drag to shape dunes manually
giving me journey vibes (the game). absolutely gorgeous for something running entirely in a canvas element
the procedural generation on the dune shapes is really well done. no two sessions look the same

elite_speaking_tracker.text: ok so this tracks your speaking patterns? kinda cool for practicing presentations i guess. the real-time feedback is nice
the audio analysis seems decent but the ui could use some work. its a lot of raw data thrown at you without much guidance on what to improve
i used it to prep for a meeting and it caught that i say 'um' way more than i thought. humbling lol
this would be 10x better with some kind of score or rating system so you can track improvement over time
^^ yes exactly. right now theres no way to save sessions and compare, just real time. localStorage export would be huge
the drawing/visualization of your speech patterns is actually pretty interesting. you can see the rhythm of how you talk
niche but genuinely useful tool. not many things like this that work completely offline and in browser

emotional-typewriter.text: ok this is genuinely cool. i started typing about my day and the whole screen shifted to this warm amber tone with soft piano-ish sounds. didn't expect a browser toy to actually read my mood
typed a breakup letter as a test and the particles went dark purple with these low droning sounds. kinda therapeutic ngl
the sentiment analysis is surprisingly decent for something running locally. wrote some angry stuff and it picked up on it immediately. how is this not using an API??
