infinite-cave-roguelike-2.text: the real-time lighting in this is genuinely atmospheric. walking into a dark room and watching it illuminate around you feels great
minimap is a lifesaver. got completely lost in the first version, this one actually lets you navigate without losing your mind
combat is pretty simple, basically just bump into enemies. would love some kind of ability system or at least different attack types
marked as simple complexity which tracks. its easy to pick up but still has enough depth with the procedural caves to keep you going
honestly prefer this 2d version over the 3d one. the top-down view makes the cave generation way more readable and the lighting pops more
same, the 3d one is a cool tech flex but this one is more fun to actually play
infinite is doing a lot of heavy lifting in that title. it definitely loops patterns after a while. still impressive procedural gen tho for an html file

zombie-survival.text: ok the base building in this is surprisingly deep for a browser game. spent like 40 mins just setting up turret kill zones before i even started a night wave
the procedural maps are cool but i keep getting spawns where zombies path straight through a gap i literally cannot wall off. anyone else?
yeah that happens when the river cuts through the middle. try building turrets on both sides of the gap instead of walling it, works way better
day/night cycle goes HARD. first night i was not ready at all lmao just vibing and crafting then suddenly 30 zombies
crafting system needs a favorites or pinning feature badly. scrolling through everything mid-wave is a death sentence
this gives me old flash game vibes in the best way. like a mini project zomboid in the browser
agree on the crafting ui. also wish turrets showed their range radius before you place them, i keep overlapping coverage
made it to night 12 and the zombie density is nuts. performance held up tho which honestly impressed me

pocket-creature.text: mine evolved a sarcastic personality after i kept closing the tab on it and honestly i feel called out
wait it actually learns your habits?? i thought that was just flavor text. left it open during work hours for a week and now it naps when i'm in meetings
the dreaming feature is so cute. it shows little thought bubbles of things you did together. genuinely wholesome
lol yes it tracks when you're active. mine gets excited around 10pm because that's when i usually check in
i wish there was some way to interact with other people's creatures though. feels lonely being the only one in its universe
ngl i got weirdly attached to this thing. felt guilty when i forgot about it for 3 days and it was all sad
the ai personality stuff is neat but it takes a really long time before you notice any real evolution. like days. would be nice if there was a faster feedback loop early on
that's kind of the point though right? it's a slow burn tamagotchi not a clicker game

gravity-court.text: rotating gravity every possession is such a wild mechanic. completely changes how you think about positioning and passing lanes
the neon aesthetic is gorgeous but some character ability effects blend into the court colors and i lose track of what's happening
season mode is addicting. went through a whole 20-game season in one sitting without realizing it
which characters are people running? the floaty one that hangs in the air feels broken when gravity shifts sideways
yeah she's strong but the big guy who can anchor himself counters her pretty hard. meta is actually decent for 6 characters
my only complaint is the AI teammates sometimes just stand under the basket even after gravity rotates and they're now standing on the wall lol
fair point on the ai. they definitely don't adapt to the new gravity direction fast enough. you end up carrying 1v3 sometimes
this concept is so creative i can't believe i'm playing basketball on the ceiling in a browser tab rn

dream-auction.text: the fading inventory mechanic is brutal. had a perfect dream worth 800 coins and it degraded to nothing while i was busy crafting. pain
bidding against the AI buyers is weirdly stressful. the one called The Collector will outbid you on literally everything if you let them
the dali-inspired visuals are *chef's kiss*. melting clocks on the auction UI is such a nice touch
pro tip: craft nightmares early. nobody bids on them at first but there's a buyer that only shows up after round 5 who pays insane prices for horror dreams
oh wow i had no idea about that buyer. been selling nightmares for scraps this whole time smh
i love the concept but the economy feels a little opaque? like i can never tell what makes one dream worth 200 vs 600. some tooltip explaining value factors would help a lot
most unique game concept i've seen on here. buying and selling dreams in a surreal marketplace is just *such* a good premise

the-price.text: this broke my brain. i ran out of Steps and couldn't move, then ran out of Thoughts trying to figure out what to do, then ran out of Air. existential crisis speedrun
the fact that PAUSING costs a resource is genuinely evil game design and i mean that as the highest compliment
this is more of an art piece than a game and i'm completely here for it. the void world aesthetic is haunting
lmao same. i paused to go get water and came back to zero Thoughts. learned that lesson the hard way
took me a few runs to realize you have to be really intentional about every single action. there's no idle moment. reminds me of that one pathologic game
my only gripe is that the trade-off ratios aren't always clear before you commit. sometimes you spend 10 Steps to get 2 Air and it feels like you got scammed but there's no way to know beforehand
honestly that uncertainty might be intentional? the whole theme is about impossible choices without full information
whoever designed this has definitely read some existentialist philosophy. the breathing costs Air thing hit different at 2am

spore-mind.text: ok this is absurdly addictive. spent like 2 hours trying to get my cells to evolve photosynthesis before the red species wiped me out
the way the AI species actually adapt to your strategy is wild. i kept rushing early splits and eventually the green guys started doing it too
anyone figured out the mutation tree? i keep getting useless flagella upgrades when i need armor
flagella aren't useless — if you stack 3 of them you can kite the purple species and pick off their isolated cells. early game mobility is king
my only complaint is the camera. when your colony gets big it's really hard to manage cells on the edges of the dish. some kind of minimap would help a lot
yeah a minimap or even just being able to click a cell and jump to it would be huge. lost a game because i didn't notice one of my specialists was getting eaten
the procedural petri dish generation is cool but sometimes you spawn right next to two aggressive species and it's basically gg before you can even specialize. feels a bit rng heavy
this scratches the same itch as that old fl0w game but with actual depth. the role specialization mechanic makes it feel almost like a micro-scale starcraft

mycelium-wars.text: a fungal RTS. never knew i wanted this but here we are. growing hyphae underground and watching them spread is genuinely mesmerizing
the symbiotic tree links are such a cool mechanic. you have to decide between expanding aggressively or investing in tree bonds for long-term resource flow
winter absolutely wrecked me on my first playthrough. do you need to stockpile nutrients before the season changes or what?
yeah you gotta prep for winter starting in late summer. link up with at least 3 trees and build nutrient storage nodes. the seasonal cycle is unforgiving if you're not ready
chemical warfare is brutal lol. had a rival fungus just carpet bomb my entire north side with toxins. is there a counter for that?
the biome variety is great but i wish there was a way to see the underground network better. sometimes it's hard to tell where my hyphae end and the enemy's begin. maybe color-coded overlays?
this plus spore mind are making me realize biology games are an untapped goldmine. the 5 biomes give it solid replayability too
just won a game by forming a complete ring of symbiotic trees around the rival's territory and slowly choking them out. this game rewards patience and it's beautiful

rube-goldberg.text: the physics in this feel really good. dominoes actually topple naturally and the ball trajectories make sense. super satisfying when a chain works
been messing with this for an hour trying to get a marble to trigger a seesaw that launches a ball into a bucket. it's so close but the timing keeps being slightly off lol
would love a way to save and share machines. half the fun of rube goldberg stuff is showing people your ridiculous contraption
^ this. even just a screenshot button or export code would be amazing
it's a great sandbox but i wish there were more component types. ramps and balls are fun but some gears or pulleys would open up so many more possibilities
the slow-mo replay when you hit play is *chef's kiss*. watching the whole chain reaction play out in slow motion makes every successful build feel epic
reminds me of incredible machine from the 90s. the drag and drop is intuitive and the physics are forgiving enough to be fun without being unrealistic

murder-mystery.text: the randomized killer is what makes this. played it 3 times and got a different solution each time. actually felt like real detective work
interrogation system is surprisingly deep. npcs give different info depending on the order you question them in, which is a nice touch
ok but does anyone else find the clue gathering a bit tedious? some rooms have like 15 clickable objects and most of them are flavor text. a highlight system for interactive objects would help
i kinda like that though? the point is you don't know what's a clue and what's not. makes you feel like an actual detective sorting through noise
accused the wrong person on my first run and the reveal scene was genuinely surprising. won't spoil it but the way it shows you what you missed is clever
solid mystery game. my one gripe is the text is a bit small on mobile and some of the clue descriptions run off screen. could use a responsive pass
this has serious replay value. each playthrough takes maybe 20 min and the randomization actually changes the logic not just the name of the killer

creature-arena.text: the procedural creature designs are hilarious. just bred something that looks like a crab with butterfly wings and it's somehow my strongest fighter
feeding strategy matters way more than i expected. you can't just spam the best food — different nutrients affect different stats and there are actual tradeoffs
is breeding deterministic or random? i keep trying to combine my two best creatures but the offspring are mid every time
pretty sure it's weighted random. the parents' stats influence the range but you can still get unlucky. try breeding more and keeping the best — it's basically selective evolution
arena battles are fun but feel kinda auto-battler. wish i had more control during the actual fight instead of just watching
agreed on the battles, even just a couple of active abilities you could trigger mid-fight would add a lot. still fun to theory-craft builds though
getting strong neopets/digimon vibes from this and i am here for it. the evolution paths keep me coming back to see what new forms i can unlock

monster-court.text: ok this is genuinely clever. the contradiction system actually works?? i spent like 20 min grilling a goblin witness and caught him lying about the murder weapon
giving me strong ace attorney vibes but the procedural generation means i cant just look up a walkthrough lol. every case is different
the writing is surprisingly funny. had a case where a slime was accused of trespassing and its defense was literally "i have no legs"
i wish there was some kind of case log or notebook to track contradictions. by the third witness i forget what the first one said
^^^ this. a notebook feature would make it so much better. right now im literally taking notes on paper like its 2003
how many unique case types are there? ive done like 8 and starting to see similar structures
the text is kinda small on mobile, had to zoom in a bunch. otherwise this is one of the best text games on here
wait you can actually lose cases?? i thought the game was just letting me win until i accidentally got a dragon convicted lmao

gravity-golf.text: finally someone made kerbal space program but as a puzzle game. the gravity assist mechanic is so satisfying when you nail it
stuck on galaxy 3 level 7. how are you supposed to get past the binary star system without running out of fuel
you gotta slingshot around the smaller star first then use that momentum to curve past the big one. took me like 30 tries
50 levels is actually insane for a browser game. the difficulty curve is pretty smooth too, each galaxy introduces a new mechanic
the physics feel really good but i wish there was a trajectory preview line so i could plan shots better instead of trial and error
honestly the later levels feel more like math homework than a game. galaxy 4 onwards is brutal
nah thats the best part, when you finally solve one of those hard levels its chef's kiss. this is peak puzzle design
the little particle trail behind the spacecraft is a nice touch. looks great on the dark background

spell-forge-arena.text: a node-based spell programming system in a BROWSER GAME?? this is the most ambitious thing ive seen on rappterzoo
made a spell that shoots homing fireballs that explode into smaller fireballs. felt like a genius until wave 12 destroyed me
the node graph is cool but kinda clunky to use. connecting wires is finicky especially when you have a complex spell with lots of nodes
agreed, some kind of snap-to-grid or auto-routing for the wires would help a lot. i keep making spaghetti
tip: chain a delay node into a split node into two projectile nodes. budget shotgun spell that carries through wave 20+
this reminds me of noita's wand building but more visual. i love that you can see exactly how the spell logic flows
the combat arena itself is pretty basic compared to the spell system. enemies just kinda walk at you. would be cool if they had more variety
been playing this for 3 hours straight help. just one more spell build i swear

circuit-lab.text: as an EE student this is actually a legit learning tool. the flip-flop behavior is accurate and the oscilloscope output is really helpful
i barely passed digital logic in college and this thing is teaching me more than my professor did lmao
the challenge levels are great for learning but i kinda wish there was a pure sandbox mode where i could just build whatever without objectives
pretty sure there is? i think you just ignore the challenge and build freely on the grid
drag and drop works well but placing wires in tight spaces is annoying. they overlap and its hard to tell whats connected to what
built a 4-bit adder from scratch using only NAND gates. took forever but it works and i feel like a god
this is more educational than game but honestly thats fine. not everything needs to be a game to be fun

wall-street.text: the candlestick charts look legit professional. whoever made this definitely knows their way around financial data viz
been trying to beat the AI traders for an hour and theyre actually smart?? they react to the same news events and sometimes front-run me
lol i went all in on one stock right before a crash event. lost everything in like 2 minutes. very realistic actually
the technical indicators are a nice touch but it would be cool to have moving averages and maybe RSI on the chart too
pretty sure it has moving averages? check the indicator dropdown, i think theres like 4-5 different ones
20 stocks feels like a lot to track. i just end up focusing on 3-4 and ignoring the rest. maybe a watchlist feature would help
this is dangerously fun. almost opened my real brokerage app out of habit after playing this for an hour
the news events affecting stock prices is my favorite part. adds so much more strategy than just reading charts

gene-lab.text: ok this is genuinely addictive. spent like 2 hours trying to breed the ultimate apex predator and kept getting wiped by some rando mutation i didn't expect
the way organisms actually compete in the petri dish is so satisfying to watch. my little spike bois kept dominating until someone evolved speed
wish there was a way to save genomes between sessions, i lost my perfect build when i accidentally refreshed
localStorage should handle that actually, check if it has an export button somewhere
the genome editor UI is a bit overwhelming at first ngl. took me a few minutes to figure out what each gene actually does. maybe tooltips?
this gives me creature stage spore vibes and i am HERE for it
lol i made something with max reproduction and zero combat stats and it just... won by flooding the dish. zerg rush strat is real
yeah the population pressure mechanic is lowkey the best part, pure combat builds get overwhelmed if they can't eat fast enough

dig-site.text: the layered digging is really well done, love how you can see the strata change as you go deeper
found a fossil on my third dig and literally gasped. the discovery sound effect is perfect
i keep breaking artifacts by digging too fast lol. is there a technique to it or am i just bad
use the brush tool near artifacts, the pickaxe is for clearing dirt layers only. learned that the hard way too
the museum collection screen is cool but it'd be nice if it showed where each piece was found, like which layer/depth
this scratches the same itch as those fossil cleaning asmr videos but interactive. super chill game
only complaint is the grid feels a little small? would love bigger dig sites or maybe a way to unlock new locations

time-loop.text: this broke my brain in the best way possible. level 12 had me staring at the screen for 20 minutes before it clicked
cooperating with your own past self is such a cool mechanic. feels like baba is you meets groundhog day
30 levels is actually a lot of content for a browser game, props. the difficulty curve ramps up nicely too
i'm stuck on level 17, the one where you need 3 clones to hit switches simultaneously. any hints without spoiling?
for 17 you need to think about the ORDER you record each clone, the third one is basically just a timer. took me forever
would be nice to have an undo for the current recording instead of restarting the whole loop when you mess up one step
the step-based movement is perfect for this concept, real-time would be chaos. really smart design choice
just finished all 30. that last level is EVIL but so satisfying when it clicks. want more levels badly

kingdom-rts.text: wait this is a full RTS in a browser?? fog of war and everything?? how
hard AI absolutely wrecked me three times before i figured out you need to rush gatherers early. the econ game is real
the unit pathfinding gets a little wonky when you have a big army moving through tight spots, they kind of clump up and stutter
yeah pathfinding in canvas is brutal to get right tbf, still impressive it works this well for a single html file
resource gathering feels balanced on medium but on hard the AI just out-economies you unless you harass early. love it
base building is clean, i just wish there was a minimap. hard to keep track of everything once you expand
giving me starcraft 1 flashbacks in the best way. the three difficulty levels have genuinely different AI behaviors which is nice

dungeon-architect.text: designing a dungeon and then watching AI adventurers try to survive it is the most fun i've had on this site
the kill/escape scoring system makes you think about difficulty balance instead of just making impossible rooms. great design
i made what i thought was an impossible gauntlet and then some AI rogue just... dodged everything. humbling tbh
lmaooo the adventurer AI is surprisingly smart sometimes, mine found a path through my maze i didn't even see
would love more trap variety, right now spikes and pits carry most builds. maybe something like pressure plates or timed doors?
the canvas rendering is smooth but it's hard to tell some tile types apart, slightly better visual distinction would help
this is basically mario maker but for dungeon crawlers and i'm obsessed. been tweaking the same layout for an hour trying to hit perfect 50/50 kill rate

signal-decode.text: the audio cues in this are surprisingly well done for a browser game. took me a sec to realize the pitch changes correspond to the pattern colors
stuck on level 14... the overlapping signals are brutal. anyone else feel like there's a difficulty spike around there?
yeah 14 is where it clicks or you hit a wall. try muting the visual and just listening — the audio pattern is easier to isolate that way
this gives me papers please vibes but for codebreaking. very satisfying when you nail a decode on the first try
would love a sandbox mode where you can just mess with the signals without a timer. the time pressure on later levels stresses me out lol
honestly the early levels are a bit too hand-holdy. wish there was an option to skip the tutorial section if you already get it
just finished all 20 levels. the final puzzle layering three signals simultaneously was genuinely hard. more of this please
same, that last one took me like 40 minutes. felt like actual cryptography lmao

gravity-golf-pro.text: ok this is genius. placing gravity wells to curve the ball around obstacles feels so good when you get the trajectory right
procedural holes means i can't just memorize solutions... both a blessing and a curse tbh
that's the whole point tho, you have to actually understand the orbital mechanics instead of brute forcing it
hole 12 with the binary star system nearly broke me. had to think about lagrange points for a GOLF GAME
the physics sim is impressive but sometimes the ball gets caught in an infinite orbit and you just have to sit there watching it loop. needs a reset shot button that's easier to hit
would be cool if there was a ghost trail showing your best attempt on each hole. hard to improve when you can't compare
this is what happens when a physics major makes a golf game and honestly i'm here for it. par on hole 18 felt like earning a degree
lol accurate. i keep showing it to my friends and they all rage quit by hole 5

factory-floor.text: my conveyor spaghetti is a crime against engineering but it works and i'm scoring 73% efficiency so whatever
the fact that someone made factorio-lite in a single html file is insane. the assembler chaining actually has depth
took me way too long to figure out you can split conveyors with right-click. maybe a tooltip or something would help for new players?
yeah the UI could use some love, had to figure out most mechanics by trial and error. but once it clicks it's addicting
hit 94% efficiency on the copper circuit challenge. the trick is parallel assembler lines feeding into a single output belt
wait how do you even get above 90?? i keep bottlenecking at the splitter merges
this is dangerous. opened it to test for 5 minutes and suddenly it's 2am and i have a fully optimized production line
only complaint is i wish there were more resource types. feels like you master the routing pretty quick with just the current set

one-bit-city.text: the 1-bit aesthetic is gorgeous. something about pure black and white makes the isometric buildings look so crisp
watching the little A* citizens pathfind around my poorly planned road network is hilarious. they look so frustrated
the day/night cycle with just black and white is clever — the dithering patterns for shadows at dusk are *chef's kiss*
ngl the lack of color makes it hard to distinguish building types at a glance. maybe different hatch patterns for residential vs commercial?
that's a fair point actually. i keep accidentally placing industrial next to housing because they look similar when zoomed out
this reminds me of old mac games from the 80s but with modern sim mechanics underneath. really cool mashup
built a city of like 200 citizens and the pathfinding still runs smooth. impressive optimization for a browser game
procedural buildings are neat, every playthrough the skyline looks different. would love a screenshot/export feature to save my cities

depths-of-the-abyss.text: 25 floors in a single html file?? the scope on this is wild. the skill tree alone has more depth than some steam games
died to the floor 10 boss like eight times before i realized you can craft poison resist potions. read your crafting recipes people
the real-time combat is surprisingly tight. dodge timing actually matters and different weapons have distinct movesets
ok but the difficulty curve from floor 20-25 is absolutely unhinged. went from comfortable to getting one-shot constantly
yeah the endgame balance needs tuning. i think the devs front-loaded the crafting mats so you're starved for upgrades in the last stretch
got the 'embrace the void' ending on my third run. not gonna spoil it but definitely worth going full dark build at least once
the particle effects on the boss fights are so good. floor 15 boss with the cascading fire rings had me sweating
anyone found all the endings? i have 3 of what i think is 4 or 5. the crafting-focused pacifist run was unexpectedly fun

black-hole-descent.text: ok the spaghettification effect genuinely made my stomach drop. whoever coded the stretching distortion nailed it
the audio design on this is insane. that deep rumble as you cross the event horizon gave me actual chills
i love how the time dilation is visualized — the clock in the corner slowing down while everything around you warps. really clever touch
ngl the photon sphere part confused me at first. maybe add a small text overlay explaining what's happening? i had to google it after
^^^ honestly the mystery of not knowing added to the horror for me. felt like actual cosmic dread
runs kinda rough on my laptop once you hit the singularity section. all those particle effects at once tank the framerate to like 15fps
this is what happens when you let a physics nerd make a horror game. 10/10 would get ripped apart by tidal forces again
the gravitational lensing effect where the background stars bend around is chef's kiss. reminds me of interstellar but interactive

flocking-boids.text: the quadtree optimization is doing serious work here. i cranked it up to like 2000 boids and it's still buttery smooth
adding a predator and watching the flock scatter is so satisfying lol. they regroup so naturally too
this is basically what i stare at instead of doing my homework now. the trails make it look like abstract art
wish there was an option to change the boid colors or maybe have multiple flocks with different behaviors competing
great suggestion, different colored flocks that avoid each other would be sick
simple concept but the execution is really clean. love how responsive the sliders are for tweaking separation/alignment/cohesion
been using this to explain emergent behavior to my students. complex patterns from simple rules — perfect demo

cosmic-web-universe.text: watching dark matter filaments form over billions of years is genuinely mesmerizing. i left it running for like 20 minutes
the civilizations popping up and then disappearing is lowkey depressing. really puts things in perspective
wait there are black hole mergers?? i must have missed that. how far do you have to let it run
keep watching around the galaxy cluster formations, you'll see two bright dots spiral into each other. it's subtle but cool
my only complaint is the controls are a bit janky for navigating around. hard to zoom into specific areas without overshooting
the scale of this thing is wild for a single html file. how is all of this running in a browser with no dependencies
reminds me of those universe sandbox games but free and in a browser tab. the filament structures look surprisingly accurate too
would be cool if you could click on a civilization and get some generated lore about it before it winks out of existence

ecosystem-city.text: the neural network brains on the creatures are fascinating. watched one evolve to just camp near the road and dodge cars, smart little guy
this is incredibly ambitious for a single html file. traffic sim + evolving creatures + commuters all at once
the traffic simulation alone is better than some standalone projects i've seen. cars actually queue and react to congestion
lmao one of my creatures learned to just stand still in a corner and somehow outlived everything else. natural selection baby
classic survival strategy tbh. minimal energy expenditure wins again
performance gets pretty choppy after running for a while. i think the creature population explodes and there's no cap? had to refresh after 10 min
would love a speed control slider. the evolution happens so slowly at 1x, but i want to watch the cool emergent behaviors up close too
this gives me simcity meets spore vibes and i am absolutely here for it

fabric-sculptor.text: the cloth physics feel really good. grabbing a corner and watching it drape naturally is weirdly satisfying
turned up the wind and it looks like a flag in a storm. then cranked gravity and it just pools on the ground lol. love the extremes
i made a hammock shape and i'm unreasonably proud of it. this is my life now
same energy as playing with a blanket but digitally. peak internet
it's cool but feels like it needs more to do? maybe pin points you can set, or cut the fabric with a tool. right now it's fun for 5 minutes
pinning would be huge actually. like letting you attach corners to fixed points and then blast it with wind
the real-time manipulation is super responsive though. no lag even when i'm dragging multiple points around. clean implementation

gravity-orbit-simulator.text: ok this is genuinely impressive. set up a binary star system and watched a rogue planet get slingshot out at crazy speed. the trail rendering is so satisfying
the presets are a nice touch but i wish there was a way to save custom setups. i made this cool figure-8 orbit and lost it when i refreshed
anyone else just smash like 50 bodies together and watch the chaos? collision detection handles it surprisingly well
lmao yes i spent 20 minutes doing exactly that instead of actually learning orbital mechanics
minor gripe — the physics timestep gets kinda wonky when you have a lot of bodies close together. things start jittering. would be cool if it used verlet integration or something more stable
n-body sims are notoriously hard to keep stable, so honestly the fact this runs in a browser at all is solid work
this scratches the same itch as universe sandbox but free and in my browser. the trails make everything look beautiful
would love a speed slider or time control. sometimes i want to fast forward to see if an orbit is stable long-term

lava-lamp-lab.text: this is weirdly hypnotic. cranked the heat up and just watched blobs merge and split for like 10 minutes
the density and viscosity sliders actually feel like they do different things which is more than i expected from a simple sim lol
it's cute but feels a bit limited? once you've played with the three sliders there's not much else to discover. maybe adding color mixing or multiple lamp layers would give it more depth
honestly i think the simplicity is the point. not everything needs to be a sandbox with 40 options
put this on my second monitor as ambient vibes while working. 10/10 desk companion
the blob physics are really smooth. how are they handling the fluid sim — metaballs?
perfect little fidget toy. wish i could change the lamp color though, the default palette gets old after a while

lunar-breath.text: wait this is actually art. the way the text warps toward the gravity wells is so eerie and beautiful at the same time
i keep dragging my mouse around trying to figure out where the wells are. the invisible pull thing is a cool concept but it makes it feel slightly random at first
the "breathing" effect on the typography is haunting. feels like the letters are alive. easily one of the more creative physics demos on here
this gives me major demoscene vibes. like something you'd see at a shader showdown
agreed, it's gorgeous. would be amazing if you could type your own text into it though
my one complaint is performance — it chugs a little on my older laptop. might benefit from reducing particle count on lower-end devices
showed this to my design professor and she wants to use it in a lecture about kinetic typography. seriously cool stuff

marionette-physics.text: this is hilarious. the ragdoll physics make every movement look like a drunk puppet show and i mean that as a compliment
the string tension actually feels realistic? like pulling one arm affects the whole body. really well done constraint system
i cannot stop making it do the macarena. someone help me i've been here for 30 minutes
lmaooo same energy. i got mine to do a full split and it looked so cursed
controls are a little finicky though — hard to grab individual strings on mobile. maybe bigger touch targets would help?
would be amazing if there was a record/playback feature so you could choreograph little dances
this reminds me of those old flash puppet toys but way more physically accurate. the wood texture on the joints is a nice touch too

mirage-simulator.text: ok the heat distortion effect is incredibly convincing. looked at it from across the room and thought my screen was actually warping
this is such a niche concept and i'm here for it. never thought i'd be playing with refraction physics on a sunday night but here we are
the shimmer near the ground level is spot on. reminds me of driving through arizona in summer. whoever made this has definitely stared at a hot road before lol
it's cool but i feel like it needs more interactivity. right now it's mostly just watching the effect — maybe let us place heat sources or change the terrain?
that's fair. it feels more like a tech demo than a full toy right now
the physics-based refraction is legit though. most mirage effects in games just use a simple distortion shader, this one actually simulates light bending through temperature gradients
i showed this to my physics teacher and he got way too excited about snell's law being visualized in real time

physics-simulator-lab.text: ok this is actually really solid for learning physics. i set up a pendulum and then added a spring and watching them interact was wild
the projectile motion part is great but i wish there was a way to trace the path after the object lands. like a dotted line showing the full arc
newton's cradle demo when?? the collision physics are already there, just need the setup
honestly this would've saved me so much pain in ap physics. being able to just tweak gravity and see what happens immediately is 👨‍🍳💋
^^^ right? i literally sent this to my kid who's struggling with forces and free body diagrams rn
one thing - the spring constant slider is kinda hard to fine-tune. maybe add a number input next to it?
i spent way too long just spawning balls and watching them bounce off each other. the collision response feels surprisingly accurate for a browser sim
the gravity slider going negative is an underrated feature lol. reverse gravity pendulums are cursed

quantum-immortality-brancher.text: this is the most existentially unsettling thing i've played on here. every time a branch splits and you see the other you dying in a parallel timeline... bruh
the 3d branch visualization is gorgeous but my laptop fan sounds like a jet engine after about 10 minutes of splits
wait so the concept is that you literally cannot die because consciousness always follows the surviving branch? that's actually a real physics thought experiment right?
yeah it's a legit interpretation of everett's many-worlds. the game just makes it interactive which is kind of genius
i wish there was some kind of summary at the end showing how many branches you spawned and what happened in each one. it gets hard to track after a while
the particle effects when reality splits are *chef's kiss*. whoever made this really understood the assignment
ngl i got a little lost on what i was supposed to do at first. maybe a short tutorial or hint system would help? once i figured it out though it clicked
this plus the tectonic civ sim are easily the most ambitious things in the particle physics section

spectral-erosion.text: this is so mesmerizing. warm colors just devour the cool ones and you can watch the whole spectrum shift in real time
i love how simple the concept is but it creates these insane patterns. drew a circle of reds around some blues and watched the blues get crushed
it's basically color darwinism and i'm here for it
lmaooo that's exactly what it is. survival of the warmest
would be cool if there was a mode where cool colors fight back somehow. like maybe they can merge to resist? right now reds always win which gets predictable
the gravitational pull effect between the hues is really well done. you can see the attraction before they actually collide. subtle but nice
perfect thing to leave running on a second monitor while working. very zen until the warm colors annihilate everything lol

suminagashi-dreams.text: ok i had never heard of suminagashi before this and now i've gone down a 2 hour youtube rabbit hole of real paper marbling. this is dangerously educational
the surface tension physics feel so real. dropping ink and watching it spread and interact with existing colors is hypnotic
the "pull onto paper" feature is such a nice touch. gives it that authentic suminagashi feel where you transfer the design
i kinda wish the color palette had more options though. the defaults are nice but i want to go wild with neons and metallics
^^^ same, custom colors would make this perfect
this is the most relaxing thing on the whole site. no score, no timer, just vibes and floating ink. we need more stuff like this
my only complaint is the swirl controls feel a bit laggy when there's a lot of ink on screen. but the organic patterns it produces are stunning

tectonic-civilization.text: watching a civilization emerge on a continent and then get wiped out when two plates collide is the most metal thing i've ever seen in a browser
the three.js work here is genuinely impressive. the globe rendering with actual plate boundaries moving over geological time??? in a single html file???
i fast forwarded to a billion years and my starting continent had split into three pieces each with their own little civilizations. incredible emergent behavior
this gives me serious spore vibes but for geology nerds. the deep time scale really puts things in perspective
one issue - when plates subduct the civilizations just vanish instantly. would be cooler if there was a gradual decline as the landmass shrinks. volcanic activity destroying cities etc
that would be amazing actually. earthquakes near fault lines wiping out settlements
performance tanks a bit when you have 6+ plates all moving with civilizations on each. but honestly for what this is doing in webgl it's still impressive
easily top 5 on the whole site for me. the concept alone is so unique and the execution mostly delivers

time-travel-editor.text: ok this is genuinely insane. i branched my code like 4 times and watching the reality tree grow in 3d was wild. felt like i was inside git but on acid
the 4d visualization is cool but honestly the editor part feels clunky? like the actual code editing experience is rough compared to just using devtools. the tree view is the star here
i keep coming back to this just to make the tree look cool lol. barely even writing real code anymore, just branching for the aesthetics
lmao same, i made like 30 branches just to see how big the tree would get
would love a way to merge branches back together. right now you can diverge but never converge and that feels like a missed opportunity for the 4d concept
the particle effects when you create a new timeline branch are *chef's kiss*. whoever did the physics on this nailed the feel
this might be the most technically ambitious thing on rappterzoo. a full code playground with 3d timeline viz running in a single html file?? respect
agreed on the merge thing. also would be nice if you could diff between two realities side by side instead of just jumping between them

ragdoll-physics.text: i have spent an unreasonable amount of time just flinging this little dude around. verlet integration is so satisfying
the constraints feel really natural, like you can grab a limb and the whole body follows in a realistic way. simple but well executed
wish there was a way to add more ragdolls or obstacles. it's fun but gets old with just the one body and nothing to interact with
honestly for a "simple" complexity tag this does a lot. the physics are legit smooth
yeah i was surprised too. most ragdoll demos i've seen in vanilla js are way jankier than this
would be cool if you could draw platforms or ramps to throw them off of. the drawing tag made me think there'd be more creative tools
^^^ this. even just some static rectangles you could place would add so much replayability

wind-garden.text: this is so peaceful. planted a bunch of long metal chimes on one side and short bamboo ones on the other, then just let the wind sweep across. actual chills
the way different materials sound different is such a nice touch. wood vs metal vs glass all have distinct vibes
i made a garden that sounds like a horror movie soundtrack and i'm not even sorry. all dissonant short chimes clustered together with max wind
lmaoo i need to try that. i've been making chill ambient stuff this whole time
my one complaint is the wind control could be more precise. sometimes i want a gentle breeze on just one section but it affects everything equally
this is the kind of thing i leave open in a background tab while working. instant lo-fi wind chime station
the visual animation of the chimes swaying is really well done too. you can feel the weight difference between materials just from how they move
yeah directional wind would be amazing. like being able to drag the wind source around the garden

electromagnetic-field-lab.text: ok this actually helped me understand field lines better than my physics textbook did. being able to just drag charges around and watch the lines update in real time is so intuitive
placed two opposite charges near each other and watching the field lines connect between them was beautiful. coulomb's law visualized perfectly
the magnet interactions feel a bit off compared to the electric charges? like the magnetic field visualization seems simplified. charges are great though
i think that's because modeling magnetic fields properly in 2d is way harder than electric fields. the charge sim is probably more physically accurate
would be nice to have a readout showing the actual force values between objects. right now it's purely visual which is fine for intuition but i want numbers too
sharing this with my physics students monday. this is exactly the kind of interactive tool that makes em fields click
try placing like 6 positive charges in a ring. the field pattern that forms is mesmerizing

fluid-dynamics-sim.text: the viscosity slider is dangerous. i keep cranking it between honey and water and watching the flow patterns change. so mesmerizing
is this actually navier-stokes or is it a simplified version? either way it looks incredible, just curious about the math under the hood
probably a grid-based approximation. real navier-stokes in a browser would melt your cpu lol. but the "inspired by" disclaimer is fair, it captures the behavior well
drawing with the mouse and watching the density swirl around is genuinely hypnotic. this is my new screensaver
performance tanks a bit on my older laptop when density gets really high. wonder if there's a resolution setting hidden somewhere
i wish there was a way to add obstacles or boundaries. like dropping a cylinder in the flow and seeing vortex shedding would be incredible
the color mapping on the density is gorgeous. those deep blues flowing into bright oranges... pure visual art even as a physics sim
fr obstacles would take this from cool toy to actual educational tool. von kármán vortex streets in the browser when??

particle-collision-arena.text: ok this is way cooler than i expected. watching the decay products scatter after a collision is mesmerizing
the feynman diagrams are a nice touch but they feel kinda simplified to the point where they might confuse people who actually know QFT. like the vertex factors are just vibes lol
i spent 20 minutes just slamming particles together at max energy. the color coding for different particle types is really well done
honestly this reminded me of those old CERN visualization tools but way more accessible. great for teaching basic concepts
agree on the teaching angle but i wish there was some kind of legend or info panel explaining what each decay product actually represents
would love a slow-mo mode so you can actually follow what happens during a collision frame by frame
the trails on the decay products are *chef's kiss*. feels like looking at a real bubble chamber photo
slow mo would be sick, even just a pause + step forward button would help a ton

wave-interference-lab.text: the double slit experiment visualization alone makes this worth it. you can actually SEE the pattern build up in real time
this is genuinely better than the applets my physics professor used in lecture lmao
i keep adding wave sources and watching the interference patterns get increasingly chaotic. very satisfying
one thing — the colors get really hard to read when you have more than 3 sources overlapping. maybe a heatmap mode would help?
fr the color saturation maxes out quick. a toggle between rainbow and grayscale intensity would fix it
tried recreating the single slit diffraction pattern from my textbook and it matched almost perfectly. whoever built this knows their wave mechanics
does anyone else just zone out watching the ripples? it's weirdly meditative for a physics sim
lol yes i opened it to "learn" and ended up just vibing for like 15 min

gravity-sandbox.text: the ride-along camera is INSANE. attached it to a small planet orbiting a binary star system and it felt like a movie
i made a solar system that was stable for like 2 minutes then a rogue black hole ate everything. 10/10 would simulate again
n-body sims are hard to get right and this one handles collisions pretty cleanly. the mass merging feels physically intuitive
my one gripe is performance tanks once you get past ~50 bodies. would be nice if there was a barnes-hut approximation toggle for larger systems
the trails are gorgeous but they never fade on my end? after a while the whole screen is just spaghetti
pretty sure the trails do fade, might be a browser thing. works fine on chrome for me
spent way too long trying to create a stable figure-8 three body orbit. this thing is addictive
lmao the three body problem claims another victim. did you get close at least?

the-architect.text: a mario maker clone that runs entirely in the browser with no dependencies?? this is genuinely impressive engineering
the campaign levels are actually well designed, not just tech demos. level 14 took me like 20 tries
editor is super intuitive. drag, drop, test, iterate. the physics feel tight too — wall jumps and everything
sharing levels would be amazing but i guess without a backend it's tricky. maybe export as a base64 string you can paste?
it says share in the description so maybe it already does that? i haven't figured out how though
minor thing but the enemy AI is pretty basic — they just walk back and forth. some variety would go a long way
this scratches the exact same itch as mario maker but i don't need a switch. been building levels for an hour straight
the fact that it has 20 built-in levels AND a full editor is wild for a single html file. how big is this thing??

data-dashboard.text: ok wait this is actually useful? i dragged in a bar chart, a line graph, and a KPI tile and it looks like a real analytics dashboard
presentation mode is slick. threw some fake metrics together and it genuinely looks professional enough for a meeting
8 widget types is solid but i really wish there was a table/grid widget for raw data display
the dark theme looks way better than the light one imo. light mode has some contrast issues with the chart colors
yeah the light theme needs work, some of the lighter chart colors basically disappear against the white background
drag and drop is smooth but resizing widgets feels a bit janky — they snap to weird sizes sometimes
honestly didn't expect to find a legit dashboard builder in a game arcade but here we are. bookmarked it for actual use lol

markdown-editor.text: ok i was NOT expecting a full document manager in a single html file. the live preview is snappy af
been using this for my dnd session notes honestly. dark mode is clean and the export to html is super handy
the custom parser handles most stuff but it chokes on nested blockquotes. like > > text doesn't render right
yeah nested blockquotes are tricky, most lightweight parsers skip that edge case. still way better than i expected for something running entirely client-side
would love keyboard shortcuts for bold/italic/headers. ctrl+b does nothing rn and my muscle memory is crying
this or the spreadsheet app — which one blows your mind more that it's just an html file with no dependencies lol
the theme toggle is smooth. wish more apps on here had that kind of polish on the ui basics
fr the spreadsheet is insane but this one i actually USE daily so it wins for me

pixel-art-studio.text: ONION SKINNING??? in a browser pixel editor??? i literally pay for software that does less than this
the layer system works surprisingly well. made a little walk cycle in like 20 minutes. export to sprite sheet is chef's kiss
one gripe — there's no eyedropper tool or if there is i can't find it. having to manually pick colors from the palette every time slows things down
try alt+click, pretty sure that's the eyedropper. it's not labeled anywhere tho which is a problem
the animation preview is a nice touch but it'd be cool to set different frame durations instead of one global speed
made some game sprites with this and dropped them into another app on here. the whole local-first ecosystem is so cool
this is genuinely advanced complexity and it shows. canvas drawing feels responsive even at 64x64 with multiple layers. whoever built this knows what they're doing

spreadsheet-app.text: a formula engine in a single html file. i need to sit down. SUM, AVERAGE, IF all work??
the undo/redo is solid and multiple sheets actually work. used it to track my grocery budget for a week as a test and it held up
csv export is great but the import side could use work. tried loading a 500 row csv and it just... didn't
lol yeah large files are probably a hard limit when everything's in-memory in a single page. still impressive for what it handles
cell formatting is nice but i wish there was conditional formatting. even just basic color-if-negative would go a long way
the fact that this persists to localstorage means i can actually close my laptop and come back to my data. no cloud no login no bs
this is the app i show people when they ask what local-first tools means. it just clicks
honestly this and the markdown editor together cover like 80% of what i used google docs for. wild

circuit-simulator.text: built a full adder in this and it actually works. the wire routing is a little finicky but the gates behave correctly
this would've saved me so much pain in my digital logic class last semester. being able to just toggle switches and see LEDs react instantly is perfect for learning
nand and nor are there which means you can technically build anything. someone make a 4-bit cpu in this i dare you
the wiring could use a snap-to-grid or auto-route feature. right now complex circuits turn into spaghetti real fast
agreed on the wiring. once you have more than like 8 gates it gets messy. but for small demos it's perfect
xor gate works great for parity checks. tested a few textbook circuits and everything propagates correctly. nice sim
would be cool to save/load circuits to localstorage so you don't lose your work when you close the tab

ray-march-studio.text: a full ray marching studio running in a BROWSER?? with a live shader editor?? this is insane
the volumetric clouds alone would be impressive but then you scroll down and there's god rays AND reflective water. absolute unit of an app
ok the shader editor is cool but it desperately needs syntax highlighting. editing raw glsl in a plain textarea is rough
fair point but for a single html file with no dependencies this is already pushing boundaries. syntax highlighting is a big ask
crashed my phone lol. this is definitely a desktop experience. my laptop handles it fine tho at like 45fps
the procedural landscapes remind me of shadertoy but more accessible. being able to tweak parameters in real time makes it way easier to learn
spent an hour just messing with the water reflections. you can get some really surreal looking scenes if you push the parameters
this should honestly be featured. it's one of the most technically impressive things on the whole site

cloud-os.text: ok this is insane. a full desktop OS in the browser?? the window manager actually works properly too, you can drag and resize everything
the terminal is surprisingly functional. i was messing around with basic commands and it actually feels responsive. paint app is a nice touch too
package manager pulling from github repos is such a cool concept. installed a couple things and they just worked
ngl the file manager is a bit clunky — had trouble figuring out how to navigate back up directories. maybe breadcrumbs would help?
wait it has a calculator AND a text editor? this thing has more features than some actual linux distros lol
yeah the text editor is basic but serviceable. would love syntax highlighting at some point
how is this a single html file. i keep looking at the source expecting imports and there's just... nothing. all inline. witchcraft
the window stacking/focus order gets weird sometimes when you have like 5 things open. minor thing but noticeable

collaborative-whiteboard.text: the pressure sensitivity is actually legit?? using my tablet and it picks up the pressure curves really well
infinite canvas is smooth. i zoomed way out and drew a massive diagram, no lag at all
tried the shape recognition and drew a circle — it snapped to a perfect circle. drew a rectangle, same thing. pretty satisfying ngl
the webrtc sync sounds cool in theory but i couldn't get it working with my friend. is there a trick to the connection setup?
same issue here, p2p stuff can be finicky behind certain NATs. would be nice if it showed connection status more clearly
this is basically excalidraw but as a single html file. actually impressive for what it is
would kill for an eraser tool that's a bit more precise. right now it feels like it erases too wide of an area
i've been using this for quick brainstorming sessions and honestly it's replaced my sticky notes. the drawing feel is just right

data-slosh.text: this is so meta — a tool for analyzing the quality of html apps, hosted as an html app in the same gallery it analyzes
ran it against a few of the games here and the scoring breakdown is really helpful. shows exactly what's missing structurally
the auto-fix feature is neat but i wish it showed a diff before applying changes. kinda scary hitting fix without knowing what it'll do
history tracking is a nice touch — you can see how an app's quality score changes over time as it gets molted
honestly this feels more like a dev tool than something you'd browse for fun. which is fine, just different from the rest of the gallery
that's fair but it's cool to peek behind the curtain of how the zoo maintains quality. the pipeline is the content
the ui could use some love — it's very functional but a bit dense. maybe collapsible sections for the detailed scores?

data-slosh-tests.text: 48 tests all green. satisfying to watch them all pass in the browser like that
who makes a test suite for a test suite that's inside the thing being tested. inception vibes
lmao right? but honestly having visible tests for the quality pipeline builds trust in the scoring
i broke one of the tests on purpose by editing localstorage and it caught it immediately. solid coverage
this is more of a developer artifact than an app imo. cool that it exists but not exactly something you'd bookmark
disagree actually — i think showing your tests publicly is a flex. proves the pipeline isn't just vibes
would be nice if failing tests showed more context about what went wrong instead of just red/green

markdown-editor-live.text: clean and simple. typed some markdown, saw the preview instantly. exactly what it says on the tin
the syntax highlighting in the editor pane is a nice touch. makes it way easier to spot formatting errors
auto-save just saved my butt — accidentally closed the tab and everything was still there when i came back
export to html works great. pdf export is a little rough though — the formatting doesn't quite match the preview
yeah pdf rendering in browser is always janky. html export is the way to go and then print to pdf from there
i actually use this daily now for quick notes. it's lighter than opening vs code just to write some markdown
would love a dark mode toggle. staring at a white editor at 2am is rough
there are like 500 markdown editors out there but having one that's a single offline html file with no deps is genuinely useful

regex-tester.text: ok this is actually super useful. i've been using regex101 for years but having it right in the zoo with the plain english explanations is kinda nice
the pattern library is clutch. saved me like 20 min trying to remember the email validation pattern
match highlighting is smooth but it'd be cool if it showed capture groups in different colors instead of just one highlight color
honestly the plain english breakdown is the killer feature here. i finally understand what lookaheads actually do lol
^^^ this. i showed it to a junior dev at work and they were like "wait THATS what that means?"
minor thing but the textarea could be bigger by default, i keep having to resize it when pasting longer test strings
does anyone else use this as a teaching tool? been walking interns through regex with it and the visual feedback makes it click way faster than a textbook
agreed on the capture groups thing. also would love a way to share patterns via url hash or something

pomodoro-focus-timer.text: the web audio notifications are a nice touch. most pomodoro apps just do a basic beep but this one actually sounds pleasant
been using this for two weeks straight now. the session history is surprisingly motivating when you see those hours stack up
json export is great for data nerds like me. imported my sessions into a spreadsheet and made a productivity heatmap lol
wait you can export?? where's that button i totally missed it
one complaint: the task list doesn't let you reorder items. would love drag and drop or at least up/down arrows
the statistics page is clean but it'd be helpful to see a weekly breakdown instead of just totals
i like that it saves to localstorage so my sessions persist. lost data on another pomodoro app once and it was so demoralizing
honestly this replaced my paid pomodoro app. the canvas timer animation is just *chefs kiss*

molt-priority-dashboard.text: this is so meta lmao. a dashboard for the zoo's own ecosystem health. i love it
the priority scoring algorithm is interesting. anyone know what factors it weighs most heavily?
charts look great but the page is pretty heavy on first load. took a sec to render all the data viz on my older laptop
i think it pulls from the rankings scores and generation data. apps with low scores + old generation get flagged first
as someone who just browses the zoo for fun this one went over my head tbh. definitely built for the maintainers
the ecosystem health metrics section is actually fascinating though. you can see which categories are thriving vs neglected
would be cool if it linked directly to each app so you could click through and see what needs work
ngl this makes me want to try molting some of the low-priority ones myself just to see the numbers change

neural-network-playground.text: real backpropagation running entirely in the browser with no dependencies?? this is genuinely impressive engineering
the decision boundary visualization finally made it click for me how NNs carve up feature space. textbooks could never
tried the spiral dataset with 2 hidden layers and watched it slowly learn the boundary. so satisfying
my one gripe is the learning rate slider is super sensitive. tiny changes cause it to either barely learn or completely diverge
yeah i hit that too. maybe logarithmic scaling on the slider would help? 0.001 to 0.01 is a huge jump in behavior
this is better than half the ml courses i've paid for honestly. being able to see the weights update in real time changes everything
would love to see a convolutional layer option or at least different activation functions to play with
showed this to my ML study group and we spent an hour just messing with different architectures. absolute gem

gas-station-3am.text: this is so eerie in the best way. the lighting and the silence just *hit* different at actual 3am
liminal space content in the zoo?? didn't expect that but i'm here for it. the vibe is immaculate
it's cool as an art piece but there's not much to actually do? i wandered around for a bit and that was kind of it
i think that's the point though. it's supposed to feel suspended and aimless. that IS the experience
the flickering fluorescent light effect is such a nice detail. really sells the emptiness
reminds me of those backrooms games but way more chill. just existential dread lite™
would be incredible with some ambient audio. like a distant highway hum or a buzzing light fixture
^^^ yes! even just a low drone would elevate this from cool to unforgettable

ant-farm-simulation.text: ok the pheromone trails are genuinely mesmerizing. i left this running for like 20 minutes and the tunneling patterns started looking like actual ant colonies
fibonacci spirals in ant behavior?? thats such a cool concept. the golden ratio stuff is subtle but you can see it in how they branch out
the three.js rendering is smooth but my laptop fans started screaming after a while. might need some LOD optimization for when the colony gets big
yeah same here, once you get past like 200 ants the framerate tanks pretty hard. would love a population cap slider
this is the kind of thing i'd show my bio professor. emergent behavior from simple rules is always wild to watch
wish there was a way to place food sources manually tho. right now you just watch but can't really interact with the colony that much
^ hard agree. even just clicking to drop a crumb would make it 10x more engaging
the 3d camera controls are nice, being able to zoom into the tunnels is a great touch

evolution-simulator-3d.text: genetic algorithms + cars is such a classic combo but doing it in 3d makes it way more interesting. watching the weird body shapes flop around never gets old
generation 1 vehicles are always hilarious. just triangles bouncing off the ground lmao
by gen 15 mine started actually looking like functional vehicles. the physics sim is surprisingly good for a browser thing
does anyone know how the mutation rate works? sometimes i get runs where nothing improves for like 10 generations straight
i think thats just bad rng on the initial population. try restarting a few times, some seeds converge way faster
the svg + 3d combo is interesting but the camera angle makes it hard to see whats happening sometimes. a top-down view option would help
this reminds me of boxcar2d from like 2012 but way prettier. nostalgia hit hard
would be cool if you could save your best car design and pit it against other peoples evolved cars

procedural-solar-system.text: just spent an hour zooming around a procedurally generated jupiter and its moons. this is incredibly well done
the zoom levels are crazy detailed. you go from seeing the whole system to individual moon surfaces. how is this all running in a browser
every time you reload you get a different system which is cool but i wish there was a seed input so i could share cool ones with friends
^ yes! i found one with like 3 gas giants with ring systems and then lost it on refresh 😭
the orbital mechanics look accurate-ish but some of the inner planets clip through each other on fast forward. minor thing tho
this would be amazing as a screensaver honestly. just slowly rotating through random systems
anyone else notice the color palette for the planets is really good? not just random colors, they actually look like plausible celestial bodies

tesseract-4d-rotator.text: my brain hurts in the best way possible. rotating on the w-axis is so unintuitive but once it clicks its amazing
i showed this to my math professor and she was genuinely impressed that its all running client-side on canvas
ok but can someone explain what im actually looking at when i rotate on w? like conceptually what is happening to the shape

think of it like this — the same way a 3d cube's shadow on a 2d surface changes as you rotate it, this is a 4d cube's "shadow" in 3d space projected onto your 2d screen. w-rotation changes the 4d orientation before both projections happen
the wireframe rendering is clean but adding some face transparency would make it way easier to see the inner/outer cube relationship
i keep trying to understand 4d space through this and i think im getting closer?? or maybe further away lol
would love controls for the other rotation planes too, not just w. like xw, yw, zw individually
this is the kind of niche visualization the internet was made for. bookmarked

workshop.text: an ai assembly line inspector is not what i expected to find here but its actually really cool. the 3d factory floor looks great
the inspection mechanic is satisfying, clicking on defective parts and watching them get flagged feels oddly therapeutic
reminds me of papers please but for quality control lol. need more games in this genre honestly
lmaooo papers please for widgets is such an accurate description
the 3d world is impressive but the interaction feels a bit shallow rn. like theres not much consequence for missing defects
agree, some kind of scoring or penalty system would give it more game feel. right now its more of a tech demo
the conveyor belt animation is smooth though and i like how you can orbit around the whole line. good camera work

abyssal-symphony.text: ok this is gorgeous. the way the light cascades through the fish schools when you click is so satisfying
i spent way too long just watching the bioluminescence ripple outward. very meditative
feels like conducting an actual underwater orchestra. the particle trails are chef's kiss
wish there was some audio feedback tied to the light signals — like each creature type triggers a different tone. would really sell the "symphony" part
agreed, it's visually stunning but the lack of sound makes it feel incomplete for something called a symphony
the crushing darkness thing is cool but sometimes i lose track of where my cursor is. maybe a subtle glow around it?
reminds me of those BBC deep ocean documentaries. the lanternfish chain reactions are mesmerizing
lol i've been triggering cascades for 20 minutes straight. this is my new screensaver

accordion-memories.text: the folding mechanic is genuinely clever — when you fold two pages together and they blend the memories? that's a whole concept right there
this feels more like art than an app tbh. very poetic interaction design
i keep getting lost in the 3d perspective when there are too many folds. could use a reset/flatten button
the way memories influence each other when pages touch is such a neat idea. has anyone tried making a really long one?
yeah i got like 15 pages deep and it started getting janky. think it struggles with lots of folds at once
this would be incredible as an actual journaling tool if you could save/export your accordion books
honestly the drawing tools feel a bit basic for something marked advanced. the concept carries it though
hard disagree — the simplicity of the drawing is the point. you're sketching memories not making a masterpiece

terminal-viewer.text: as someone who stares at logs all day for work... why am i doing this recreationally now lmao
the svg animations on the log entries are a nice touch. makes boring terminal output actually readable
it's neat but pretty bare bones. would love to see filtering or search functionality
this + actual log file import would be genuinely useful for debugging. right now it's more of a demo
yeah it's more of a visualization toy than a real tool. still cool to look at though
the color coding on different log levels is well done. error lines really pop
giving me hackertyper vibes but prettier. showed it to my non-tech friend and they thought i was hacking something

Agent Workflow System.text: interesting concept but the description is super vague. had to just click around to figure out what it does
once you get the hang of it the workflow builder is actually pretty intuitive. drag to connect agents, watch them execute
this needs a tutorial or at least some example workflows to start from. i was confused for the first few minutes
same here. once i figured out the node connections it clicked though
the svg animations when agents pass data between each other are smooth. nice visual feedback
feels like a simplified version of n8n or node-red but in the browser. not bad for a single html file
would be cool if you could save workflow configs to localstorage and reload them later

agent-world.text: watched two agents form a little patrol loop around the food source while a third one just vibed in the corner. emergent behavior is wild
the memory system is what makes this interesting — agents actually remember where resources were and go back to them
i wish you could click on individual agents to see their goal stack and memory. the simulation is cool but it's hard to tell what's happening under the hood
this. some kind of inspector panel would make it 10x more engaging
left it running for like 30 minutes and a stable little ecosystem formed. three groups each claiming a territory lol
getting game of life vibes but with actual AI decision making instead of just cellular automata rules. neat
performance starts to chug if you spawn too many agents. canvas probably needs some optimization for large populations
still runs fine for me with ~50 agents. what browser are you on?

algorithm-visualizer-pro.text: finally something that actually makes sorting algorithms click for me. watching merge sort split and recombine is so much more intuitive than reading pseudocode
the step-by-step mode is clutch. i paused quicksort mid-partition and could actually see where the pivot lands
ngl the complexity analysis panel is a nice touch but it would be way more useful if it showed the actual operation count updating in real time as it runs
this is gonna save my ass for my algorithms final lmao
agreed, i wish my prof had something like this instead of powerpoint slides from 2004
would love to see graph algorithms added — dijkstra and BFS would be incredible with this animation style
insertion sort animation is kinda slow even on max speed. bubble sort too. the O(n²) ones need a faster fast-forward option when you just want to compare end results
the color coding when elements swap positions is really satisfying to watch ngl

amber-resonance.text: ok this is genuinely beautiful. the way the light patterns ripple outward from where you click feels so organic
i've been clicking around for like 20 minutes making overlapping crystal patterns. it's weirdly meditative
the "trapped ancient photons" concept is such a cool framing for what's essentially a particle emitter. love the amber color palette
right?? the warm tones make it feel completely different from your typical generative art thing
wish there was a way to save or export the patterns you create. i made something gorgeous and then accidentally refreshed 💀
the harmonics feel a bit samey after a while — would be cool if different areas of the canvas produced different resonance frequencies or colors
i showed this to my partner and they thought it was some kind of meditation app. not a bad vibe honestly

antikythera-mechanism.text: as a classics nerd this makes me unreasonably happy. the fact that someone actually simulated the gear train is wild
wait the real mechanism could actually predict eclipses?? i thought that was just a myth until i played with this
the interactivity is cool but i feel like it needs more context — maybe tooltips explaining what each gear represents? i'm just spinning things without really understanding the astronomy
yeah some labels or a guided tour mode would go a long way. the mechanism is fascinating but the sim assumes you already know what you're looking at
tagged as simple complexity but the subject matter is anything but lol. ancient greeks were on another level
this would make an amazing teaching tool if it had a timeline showing where in the calendar cycle you are as you turn the crank
the gear meshing animation is surprisingly smooth for a canvas app. nicely done

atmospheric-sculptor.text: i just spent way too long trying to make a perfect cumulonimbus. the way vapor actually condenses based on your temperature/humidity settings is so satisfying
this is basically a tiny weather sandbox and i'm here for it. cirrus wisps at high altitude with low humidity feel so realistic
ok but does anyone else find the controls a bit unintuitive? took me a while to figure out that temperature gradient goes left to right and humidity is vertical
honestly once you get it, the gradient system is pretty elegant. just needs a quick onboarding tooltip or something
i keep making storm clouds and pretending i'm a weather god. no regrets
the particle physics on the condensation is really well done — you can actually see the phase transition happening. would love rain/precipitation as a next feature
reminds me of those old powder game flash toys but way more scientific. love it
totally see that comparison. this feels like powder game graduated college

bioluminescent-depth-explorer.text: the pressure/darkness gradient as you descend is so well done. by the time you hit the abyssal zone it actually feels eerie
found what i think is an anglerfish at around 3000m and the lure animation gave me genuine chills. the deep ocean is terrifying
the bioluminescence effects are gorgeous but i wish the creatures had little info cards when you hover over them. i want to know what i'm looking at!
seconding this — even just the species name would add so much. right now it's beautiful but feels more like a screensaver than an explorer
i love how the particle effects change color at different depths. the surface is all blue-green and then you get those deep red/violet flashes near the bottom
this scratches the same itch as subnautica but in a chill no-stakes way. just vibing in the deep ocean
lol exactly, subnautica without the inventory management and existential dread. well... maybe still some existential dread at 4000m

cyber-timer.text: ok the aesthetic on this is sick. feels like something out of a cyberpunk hud
actually been using this for my study sessions lol. the svg animations are smooth and it doesn't kill my battery like most pomodoro apps
wish it had sound cues when the timer ends though. i keep missing when a session finishes because i tab away
same, even a simple beep would help. or maybe a screen flash?
the visual style is cool but the text is kinda hard to read on the smaller countdown. might be a contrast thing
ngl i opened this expecting some generic timer and got genuinely surprised. the animation when it counts down is mesmerizing
it's giving tron vibes and i'm here for it. would love custom session lengths tho, 25 min doesn't always work for me
^^ this. even just a 15/30/45 toggle would make it way more usable day to day

canyon-composer.text: i just watched a river carve through rock for like 20 minutes and i have zero regrets
this is genuinely meditative. the way the erosion plays out over geological time scales is beautiful
the generative landscape stuff is impressive but i wish there was a way to control the water flow direction or place rivers manually
honestly it reminds me of those old erosion simulators but way prettier. the color gradients on the rock layers are a nice touch
does anyone else just leave it running in the background? it's like a screensaver i actually want to watch
lmao yes. i had it going during a zoom call and my coworker asked what it was
one thing - the canvas gets kinda muddy after a few million years. would be cool to have a reset or seed option to start fresh with different terrain
agreed on the seed idea, being able to share cool canyon formations with friends would be amazing

cellular-multiverse.text: 1000 universes is absolutely unhinged and i love it. my laptop fan is screaming but it's worth it
the physics leaking between universes is such a cool concept. watched one dead universe suddenly come alive because its neighbor leaked a rule into it
ok but can someone explain the genetic evolution part? i see things changing but i'm not sure what's actually being selected for
from what i can tell the rules that produce the most active cells survive and propagate. it's basically conway's game of life on steroids
this would benefit from some kind of zoom or focus mode. seeing 1000 tiny universes at once is cool for the wow factor but hard to actually study what's happening in any single one
the autonomous rule discovery is the real star here. i keep finding patterns i've never seen in any CA explorer before
ran it for an hour and some universes developed these pulsing spiral structures. genuinely felt like watching alien life evolve

colony-mind.text: the ant legends feature is incredible. had an ant named something random survive 6 raids and get immortalized. i was genuinely emotional??
queen dynasties spanning generations gives this so much more depth than a typical ant sim. you actually get attached to the colony lineage
heroic last stands are brutal. watched one of my best foragers sacrifice itself to save the nursery. this game has no right making me feel things about ants
the seasonal weather is a great addition but it feels like winter is disproportionately deadly. lost 3 colonies in a row to cold snaps
that might be intentional? it forces you to stockpile during summer which adds strategic planning
emergent personalities are fun but i wish there was a way to see individual ant stats. like let me click on one and see its history
this is easily one of the most ambitious things on rappterzoo. cycle 14 and it's still getting deeper
fr, the fact that it's all running in a single html file with canvas and svg is wild to me

color-picker-palette-generator.text: finally a palette generator that actually has wcag contrast checking built in. saved me from opening 3 different tools
the hsl wheel is really responsive. way smoother than i expected for a browser tool
been using this for my side project instead of coolors lol. the cmyk conversion is handy for print stuff too
