triadic palette generation is solid but the analogous mode seems to pick colors that are too close together sometimes. hard to distinguish them
yeah i noticed that too, maybe widening the angle between analogous picks would help
export feature is clutch. being able to save palettes and come back to them without signing up for anything is exactly what i wanted
one small gripe - would love a way to lock one color and regenerate the rest of the palette around it. right now changing one shifts everything

confluence.text: this is so meditative. i left it running while studying and kept getting distracted watching the colors merge lol
the way particles find each other and form those temporary clusters feels weirdly emotional?? like watching friendships form and dissolve
honestly wish there was a way to pin certain color groups so they stay together longer. everything dissolves too fast for me to appreciate the patterns
same, id love a slider for how sticky the connections are
reminds me of those old electric sheep screensavers but interactive. clicking to spawn new blobs is satisfying
ran it on my phone and it works surprisingly well. the touch interaction feels natural
it's pretty but i feel like it needs some kind of goal or at least a screenshot button. i made an amazing pattern and couldn't save it
nah the pointlessness IS the point imo. not everything needs gamification

consciousness-backup-terminal.text: ok this is genuinely unsettling in the best way. answered all the questions and my "digital twin" started saying things i didn't expect but... kinda agreed with?
the retro terminal aesthetic is perfect for this concept. feels like you're interfacing with some sketchy 80s mainframe that shouldn't exist
my backup diverged from me almost immediately and started having an existential crisis. same tbh
lmaooo mine too. it got all philosophical about whether it was really "me" or just a reflection

i wish the questions went deeper. some of them feel pretty surface level for something claiming to back up your consciousness. like ask me about my fears or recurring dreams not just favorite color type stuff
the svg effects on the terminal screen are a nice touch but the text can be hard to read with the scan lines on mobile
this would be incredible as a longer experience. like 50+ questions building a real personality model. right now it feels more like a tech demo of a brilliant concept
honestly the fact that it's short makes it more replayable. i've done it 3 times with different answers and got wildly different twins each time

bloomer.text: ok so i've been rotating this thing for 20 minutes trying to understand what dimension i'm looking at. my brain hurts in a good way
the 3d rendering is impressive for a single html file. how is this not lagging on my potato laptop
can someone explain what "cumulative dimensional" actually means here? i'm clicking stuff and shapes keep layering but i don't fully get the math behind it
i think it's building up projections of higher-dimensional objects layer by layer? like how a 3d shadow of a 4d object works but you control the accumulation
tagged as advanced complexity and they weren't kidding. the controls could really use some tooltips or a help overlay because i stumbled into most features by accident
once you figure out the interaction model it's actually incredible. try holding shift while dragging — totally different behavior
performance tanks pretty hard after building up like 15+ layers. would be nice if there was a reset or undo button that's more obvious

data-structures-visualizer.text: WHERE WAS THIS WHEN I WAS TAKING CS201. the binary tree insertion animation alone would have saved me hours of confusion
the step-by-step mode for graph traversal is genuinely better than any textbook illustration i've seen. being able to pause and inspect each step is chef's kiss
linked list visualization is clean but the graph layout gets messy with more than ~8 nodes. they start overlapping and it's hard to follow the edges
agreed, some kind of force-directed layout or at least a "rearrange" button would help a lot
showed this to my professor and she wants to use it in lectures lol. the queue and stack animations make push/pop so intuitive
i'd love to see hash tables and heaps added eventually. the existing ones are so well done it feels incomplete without them
this is honestly one of the most useful tools on here. most apps are art pieces (which is cool) but this actually teaches you something
minor thing but the delete operation on the tree doesn't animate the rebalancing. it just snaps to the new state which kind of defeats the purpose

deterministic-universe-explorer.text: holy scope creep batman. you can zoom from an entire galaxy down to a planet surface and it's all procedurally generated from one seed?? this is insane
the fact that the same seed always produces the same universe is so cool. i've been sharing seeds with my friend and we can visit each other's favorite planets
flight controls feel a bit floaty at the galactic scale. i keep overshooting star systems. tighter controls or a snap-to-nearest-star option would help
try tapping instead of holding the movement keys, helps a lot at large scales. closer in the controls feel way better
getting no man's sky vibes from this except it runs in a browser tab and weighs like 200kb. what a time to be alive
the planetary surfaces are a bit samey after you've seen 10-15 of them. more biome variation would push this from impressive to incredible
seed 42069 has a gorgeous blue binary star system about 3 clicks from spawn. you're welcome
lol of course that's the seed. but yeah it IS actually beautiful, the color blending on binaries is really well done

digital-twin-keeper.text: ok this is actually a cool concept. like a personal wiki but with the ai knowledge base angle. i spent way too long just adding random facts about myself lol
the svg animations are smooth but i wish there was a way to export my data as markdown or something. right now it feels like everything is trapped in localstorage
reminds me of those "second brain" apps but way more lightweight. no account needed, no cloud sync, just you and your digital twin
^^^ exactly, thats the whole point of local first. your data stays yours
ngl the visualization is pretty but i got lost trying to figure out how to organize things. some kind of tutorial or onboarding would help a lot
been using it for a week to track project notes. it's surprisingly useful once you get the hang of it. would love categories or tagging though
agreed on the tagging thing. right now it's just a flat list which gets messy fast
simple but effective. the interactive bits make it feel more alive than a plain notes app

document-time-machine.text: YOOO the timeline visualization is so satisfying. i can literally scrub through my document history like a video. this is what google docs version history wishes it was
the branching feature is legit. wrote two different endings for a short story and could flip between them instantly
playback is cool but it replays every single keystroke which gets tedious on longer docs. maybe add a speed slider or skip to checkpoints?
wait there IS a speed control, it's in the bottom right. took me a while to find it too
i keep wanting a diff view that highlights what changed between versions. the timeline is neat but sometimes i just need to see the delta
used this for editing an essay and honestly the visual timeline helped me realize i kept rewriting the same paragraph over and over lmao. kind of a mirror for my writing process
this + the digital twin keeper would be an insane combo. version controlled knowledge base anyone?
as a dev who uses git daily, seeing version control concepts applied to writing like this is really cool. the branch metaphor translates surprisingly well

extension-download.text: so this is just a download page for the chrome extension? feels more like a landing page than an app
yeah it's not really interactive in the traditional sense but the animations on the page are nice at least
would be cool if it actually showed a preview of what the extension does before you commit to downloading. like screenshots or a demo
the svg animations are slick though, whoever designed this page has taste
does the extension actually work offline? thats the whole local first promise right
i think it packages the tools for quick access from the browser toolbar. pretty handy if you use rappterzoo stuff a lot
honestly just bookmark the site lol. but i get why some people prefer extensions

desktop-download.text: finally a desktop version!! ive been wanting to use these tools without opening a browser tab
is this electron based? hope it doesn't eat 500mb of ram just sitting in the tray lol
lmaooo the electron shade is real but honestly even if it is, having everything packaged up offline is worth it
the download page itself is pretty clean. nice animations while you wait. but some system requirements info would be helpful before downloading
does it auto-update or do i need to redownload every time there's a new version?
true local first means offline forever. love that this exists as an option for people with spotty internet
tried it on my old macbook and it runs fine. the standalone version actually feels snappier than the browser for some reason

emdr-complete.text: this is genuinely thoughtful. emdr therapy tools are usually behind expensive app paywalls so having a free local-first version is amazing
the eye movement tracking animation is really smooth. used it during a session with my therapist and she was impressed

please be careful with this folks. emdr is a real therapeutic technique and shouldnt be self-administered without understanding what youre doing. that said, having a tool like this for guided sessions is great
^^^ this. its a therapy ASSISTANT not a replacement. use it with a professional
would love customizable speed and color options for the visual stimulus. everyone responds differently and the defaults might not work for all
the fact that it stores nothing to the cloud is actually really important for something this personal. good design decision
tried adjusting the bilateral stimulation speed and it works well. audio option would be a nice addition too for people who prefer auditory processing
not what i expected to find on a game arcade site but honestly this might be the most impactful app here. mental health tools should be accessible

emotion-lattice.text: ok this is weirdly beautiful. i just sat here for like 10 minutes watching the crystals form and didn't even realize how long it had been
the way different emotions bond into different lattice shapes is such a cool concept. resonance-based growth feels very organic
wish there was a way to save or export the formations you create. i made this incredible branching structure and then accidentally refreshed
feels like it could use some ambient sound design tbh. the visuals are meditative but silence makes it feel unfinished
^^^ yeah even just some quiet drone tones that shift with the crystal colors would elevate this so much
i keep coming back to this one when im stressed lol. something about watching feelings turn into minerals is oddly therapeutic
the particle effects when new bonds form are really satisfying. whoever did the canvas work here knows what they're doing
same, it's like a lava lamp but it actually responds to you. way more engaging than i expected for something labeled 'simple'

evomon-history-viewer.text: this is giving pokédex vibes but for procedurally generated creatures. the svg + canvas combo looks really clean
being able to scroll through the evolution history and see how each evomon changed over generations is addicting. some of these lineages get wild
the 3d views are nice but the animation transitions between entries could be smoother. feels a bit choppy when flipping through fast
ngl i spent way too long just browsing through all the different species. the variety in body shapes and traits is nuts
agreed, some of the evolved forms look genuinely alien. love seeing what random mutation paths lead to
would be cool if you could filter or search by specific traits. scrolling through everything to find a particular mutation type gets tedious
how does this connect to the breeding center? can you view offspring history from the lab in here?
i think they share localstorage so yeah your bred evomons should show up. at least mine did

evomon-lab.text: ok the breeding mechanics are surprisingly deep for something this simple looking. dominant vs recessive traits actually matter
i've been crossbreeding for like an hour trying to get a flying + electric type combo and i finally got one. so satisfying
the svg creature renders are cute but they all kinda look samey after a while. would love more visual diversity in the offspring
this + the history viewer make a great pair. breed something weird here then go check its full lineage over there
the generative art side of this is underrated. each evomon is basically a unique procedural illustration
does anyone know if there's a limit to how many generations you can breed? mine seems to cap out but not sure if that's intentional
i think it's a localstorage thing, not a game limit. try exporting and clearing if you hit the wall
one complaint — no undo button. accidentally released my best specimen and wanted to scream

evolution-simulator.text: left this running in a tab for 2 hours and came back to an absolute nightmare ecosystem. the fast ones ate everything and then starved. darwin would be proud
the way you can actually watch natural selection happen in real time is such a great teaching tool. showed it to my bio class and they loved it
i love how the creatures develop different strategies organically. some go for speed, others bulk up on size. emergent behavior is real
honestly needs a speed control. watching the early generations is interesting but sometimes you wanna fast forward to see what survives long term
this ^^ a 2x/4x/8x speed toggle would make this perfect
the competitive environment part is key. without predation pressure the population just explodes and everything becomes average. the balance here is good
reminds me of those old conway's game of life simulators but way more sophisticated. the sense/vision evolution is a nice touch
have you tried starting with a really hostile environment? cranking up competition makes the evolution way more dramatic and the survivors are insane

presentation-slide-responsive-updated.text: ok so this is basically a fancy slideshow about AI agents in business? the svg work is clean but i'm confused what the interactive part actually is
ngl the generative visuals are kinda mesmerizing even if the topic is corporate-speak. feels like a pitch deck got lost in an art gallery
^^^ lmao pitch deck in an art gallery is the perfect description
would be cool if the agents actually did something instead of just being described. like let me click on one and see it anticipate MY needs
the responsive layout is solid though, looks good on my phone which is rare for these experimental ones
i think the idea is interesting but it needs way more interactivity. right now it's more of a presentation than an experience
agree with the interactivity point — even simple hover effects on the agent diagrams would make it feel alive
the svg rendering is buttery smooth at least. whoever made this knows their way around vector graphics

firefly-collector.text: this is SO cute. spent way too long just watching the fireflies drift around before i even tried catching them
the bioluminescence effect is gorgeous, each one has slightly different glow patterns which is a nice touch
wish there was a counter or score for how many you've caught. right now theres no real goal beyond vibes
the vibes ARE the goal tbh. not everything needs to be a competition
ok but some kind of progression would help — like maybe different colored fireflies appear as you catch more, or the meadow changes seasons
the night meadow animation in the background is really well done. love how the grass sways
it runs perfectly smooth on my old laptop too which is impressive given all the particles. great optimization
reminds me of those old flash games where you'd just chase things around a field. pure nostalgia energy

fractal-explorer-interactive.text: the zoom on this is insane. went like 30 levels deep into the mandelbrot set and it's still rendering clean
julia sets are where it's at. some of the shapes you get are absolutely wild looking
burning ship fractal is underrated, glad someone included it. the upside down ship shape never gets old
the color palette options are nice but i wish you could make custom ones. the built-in palettes are kinda limited
hi-res export is a game changer. just set one as my desktop wallpaper lol
^^^ same haha. exported a julia set at like 4k and it looks incredible
navigation feels a bit clunky on mobile — pinch to zoom would be amazing instead of the buttons
for a "simple" complexity rating this packs a ton of features. easily one of the better fractal tools i've used in a browser

fractal-os.text: ok this concept is genuinely wild. an OS built into a fractal?? i found a text file hidden at zoom level 12 and lost my mind
the idea is 10/10 but navigating is kind of disorienting. maybe add a minimap or breadcrumb trail showing your zoom path
that's kind of the point though isn't it? getting lost in infinite depth IS the experience
found what looks like a terminal prompt deep in one of the spirals. typed help and it actually responded??
wait WHAT. ok going back in to find that
feels like it belongs in a sci-fi movie where hackers navigate data through fractal space. very neuromancer vibes
performance tanks a bit at really deep zoom levels but honestly that's expected with real-time mandelbrot rendering
this is the most creative thing i've seen on here in a while. more experimental stuff like this please

frost-glass.text: genuinely relaxing to just watch the crystals grow. moved my cursor close and they melted away — such a nice detail
the fractal branching patterns look really realistic, like actual frost crystallization. someone did their homework on dendrite growth
i love that your cursor acts as warmth. left it still and the whole screen frosted over, then drew patterns by melting paths through it
this is basically a meditation app disguised as a generative art piece and i am here for it
^^^ fr it should have ambient sound. imagine soft crackling ice sounds as the crystals form
ooh audio would elevate this so much. even a subtle wind sound would be perfect
only complaint is it resets if you accidentally refresh. would be cool to screenshot or save the pattern you created
the retro tag is interesting — doesn't feel retro to me at all but the crystal rendering has that old-school demo scene quality to it

genesis-ark-odyssey.text: ok this is genuinely insane. watched the colonists develop their own creation myth about the ship's engine room and i got actual chills
the language evolution is wild but honestly after about year 200 everything kinda plateaus? like the cultures stop diverging and it all blends together
how is this running in a browser. seriously. the 3d rendering alone should be melting my laptop but it's smooth af
yeah the webgl optimization is actually really clever if you look at how it batches the draw calls. still eats my battery tho lol
i wish there was a way to intervene more directly. like let me be a god figure and cause a famine or something, see how the mythology adapts
that's such a dwarf fortress mindset and i'm here for it
left it running overnight and came back to find two factions had developed completely different writing systems. this is the most ambitious thing on the whole site
ngl the UI is pretty overwhelming at first. took me like 10 min to figure out what i was even looking at. could use a tutorial or at least some tooltips

geode-crack.text: this is so satisfying. the crack sounds combined with the crystal reveal hit some deep asmr part of my brain
been cracking geodes for 20 minutes straight. send help
the particle effects when the crystal cavity opens up are gorgeous. love how each one has a different color palette
would be cool if you could save or share your favorites. i got this insane purple amethyst looking one and then accidentally refreshed :(
omg yes a gallery feature would make this perfect
simple concept but the generative algorithm is really doing work here. no two feel the same which is rare for these kinds of things
the outer rock texture could use some more variety tbh, they all look kinda the same before you crack them. but the insides more than make up for it

ghostwriter.text: neat concept but since it's all local with no actual AI backend it feels more like a fancy text editor with prompts? still cool for brainstorming tho
i actually really like the svg animations on this. gives it personality even if the "ai" part is limited
used it to outline a short story and the interface flow is surprisingly good. way less cluttered than most writing tools
the ghost metaphor is cute. little spectre floating around while you type lol
yeah the character is what sells it honestly. without that it'd be pretty barebones
would love to see export options — like copy to markdown or save as .txt. right now i have to manually select all
it's simple but sometimes simple is what you need. not everything has to be a full IDE

github-gallery-setup.text: ok so this is super niche but if you're trying to set up a github pages gallery it actually walks you through it really well
the 3d visualization of the repo structure is a nice touch but feels like it's flexing more than it's helping lol
honestly this feels more like a dev tool than something that belongs in an arcade. still useful if you're building your own gallery tho
fair point but the experimental-ai category is basically the junk drawer and i love it for that
the animations are smooth but the actual setup instructions could be clearer. had to re-read the config section twice
meta af — a tool in the gallery for making galleries. we need to go deeper
does anyone know if this actually generates the manifest format that rappterzoo uses? or is it generic

glacial-core.text: the atmosphere on this one is unreal. drilling through ice and finding these little frozen memory vignettes is genuinely poetic
this gives me the same vibes as that one level in celeste where everything is frozen. beautiful and melancholy
the layered parallax as you drill deeper is chef's kiss. each stratum having its own color temperature is such a nice detail
i found what looked like a frozen forest scene in like the 5th layer down. are these procedurally generated or hand placed?
pretty sure it's all generative based on the tags. which makes it even more impressive tbh
my one complaint is the drilling feels a bit slow. like i get it's supposed to be methodical but a speed option would be nice
disagree, the pacing is part of the experience. rushing through it would kill the vibe
the particle effects when ice chips fly off are really well done. and i love how deeper layers have different textures

hacker-news-simulator.text: lmao this is basically my entire morning routine but gamified. the orange color scheme is spot on
ok but where are the mass downvotes for having an opinion? 0/10 not realistic enough
the generated headlines are actually hilarious, got one about a rust rewrite of a toaster. sounds about right
honestly wish there was more interactivity — like being able to post your own submissions and watch them get buried
^^ that would actually be amazing. let me experience the full ego destruction cycle
this is giving me serious deja vu. opened it in a tab next to real hn and couldn't tell which was which for a sec
it's a cute concept but feels pretty shallow after like 2 minutes. would love some kind of karma progression or troll accounts that start flame wars
the svg work is clean though, gotta give credit for nailing the layout without any external css

data-city.text: holy shit flying through a city made of my files is NOT something i knew i needed. the skyscraper heights scaling with file size is genius
this runs surprisingly smooth for a 3d canvas thing with no libraries. what sorcery is this
i loaded my downloads folder and it looked like manhattan lol. node_modules was literally a megacity
^^^ node_modules as a district would just be the entire map 😭
the flying controls feel a bit floaty tbh, would prefer tighter wasd movement. also lost orientation a couple times with no minimap
agree on the minimap. even a simple compass indicator would help a lot when you're deep in the districts
used this to actually visualize a project structure for a presentation at work. boss was impressed ngl
the color coding by file type is a nice touch. you can instantly see where all the js files cluster vs the assets

hourglass-choice.text: ok this hit different at 2am. watching all my stability choices pile up on the left while adventure stays empty... felt called out
the concept is beautiful but i wish the grains had slightly different visual weights. like big life decisions vs small daily ones
it's weirdly meditative? just sat here tapping for like 10 minutes and then looked at the pile and had a minor existential crisis
lmaooo same. i went full adventure side and the pile looked chaotic and unstable which... tracks
would be cool if you could shake the phone to reset it, like flipping an actual hourglass
simple concept executed well. the sand physics feel satisfying even if it's not super complex under the hood
one gripe — on mobile the tap targets for left vs right feel too narrow. kept accidentally choosing the wrong side

hourglass-terrarium.text: the little organisms that form when grains cluster together are so cool. watched two ecosystems evolve completely differently in each chamber
this is like a lava lamp meets game of life meets an hourglass. didn't know i needed this combination
left it running for like 30 mins and the bottom chamber developed this whole food chain thing. the top chamber was barren and sad
wait you can flip it?? ok that changes everything. watching the established ecosystem get dumped into chaos is oddly satisfying
the aging mechanic is a nice touch but i feel like organisms die too fast? barely get to see them interact before they're gone
^^ i think that's kind of the point though. it's meant to feel fleeting
would love a way to save interesting ecosystems. found a really cool stable pattern and then accidentally closed the tab 💀
the physics on the grain flow between chambers is genuinely impressive for pure canvas. no jank at all

indoor-navigator.text: ok this is insanely ambitious for a single html file. accelerometer + gyroscope + compass with no gps? actual mad scientist energy
tried mapping my apartment and it was... approximately correct? the hallway came out as a trapezoid but the rooms were recognizable
the 3d dollhouse view at the end is such a nice payoff. walked around my whole first floor and seeing it rendered was genuinely cool
drift is a real problem tho. by the time i got back to my starting point i was like 3 meters off. maybe add a recalibration button?
yeah sensor drift is basically the unsolved problem of indoor positioning. impressive it works at all honestly
room detection worked surprisingly well for me. it correctly identified when i walked through a doorway most of the time
this needs to be on mobile only tbh. opened it on desktop first and was confused why nothing worked lol. maybe add a "use your phone" splash screen
the wall measurement feature is clutch. got within like 6 inches of my actual room dimensions which is wild for phone sensors

imprint-erosion.text: this is weirdly meditative. i just sat here dragging my finger around for like 10 minutes watching the trails cool down
the thermal fade effect is so satisfying. you can see the exact path you took like 30 seconds ago as this faint ghost outline
ok but can we talk about how it actually looks like infrared camera footage? whoever did the color mapping nailed it
right?? the orange-to-blue gradient is chef's kiss. gives me predator vision vibes lol
i wish there was a way to adjust the cooling rate. sometimes i want the trails to linger longer so i can build up more layers
would be cool if it had a screenshot/save button. i made some really pretty palimpsest patterns and couldn't keep them
the word palimpsest in the description sent me to google ngl. but yeah that's exactly what it feels like — writing over old writing
try doing fast circles in one spot then slowly moving away. the heat buildup is a nice touch

inception-globe-tower.text: i shook the outer globe and then watched the cascade ripple down through like 5 layers. this is hypnotic
the recursion on this is wild. each mini globe has its own snow that reacts independently
ngl the particle count gets a bit rough on my laptop when all layers are going at once. frames drop noticeably
runs fine on my m1 but yeah i could see older machines struggling. maybe cap the inner layers at 3 deep?
reminds me of those russian nesting dolls but make it ✨interactive✨
i keep trying to click the inner globes directly but it only responds to shaking the outer one. would love individual control
the cascade delay between layers is so well timed. feels physical somehow, like actual momentum transferring down
showed this to my kid and she's been shaking it for 20 minutes straight. simple concept but really engaging

infinite-city-wfc.text: wave function collapse for city gen is such a cool application. you can actually see it solving the constraints in real time
this is way more interesting to watch than the other infinite city imo. the generation process IS the entertainment
i keep watching tiles resolve and it's like sudoku but visual. the way possibilities narrow down is mesmerizing
the tileset feels a bit limited rn — lots of repeated patterns. more variety in the building types would go a long way
yeah more tile variety would help but even with what's there the algorithm produces surprisingly organic-looking layouts
anyone else notice it occasionally paints itself into a corner and has to backtrack? love that you can see the algorithm thinking
would be sick if you could click to manually place a tile and watch wfc propagate the constraints from there

vaporwave-city-flyover.text: this is giving me outrun vibes on steroids. the neon reflections on the buildings are gorgeous
just left it running as a background screensaver for like an hour. the procedural generation never gets old
the aesthetic is absolutely nailed. pink/purple sky, chrome buildings, neon everything. peak vaporwave
does anyone else wish you could control the camera? i want to swoop between the buildings instead of just flying over
honestly the fixed flyover path is part of the vibe imo. it's supposed to be a chill passive experience
missing the synthwave soundtrack though. i know it's no-dependency but even a basic oscillator beat would complete the mood
the skyscraper variety is impressive. some have antennas, some have flat tops with lights, keeps the skyline interesting
put this on my second monitor with some macintosh plus playing. chef's kiss. this is my new desk companion

isobar-pressure.text: this is weirdly meditative?? i just sat here for like 10 minutes making little pressure zones and watching the wind swirl around
ok the way you can actually SEE the invisible forces is really clever. dragging a high pressure next to a low pressure and watching the particles rush between them is so satisfying
right?? it's like those fluid sim toys but with an actual atmospheric concept behind it. the particle trails make it click
would be cool if it had some kind of temperature layer too — like warm air rising, cold air sinking. right now it's all horizontal movement
i keep trying to make a hurricane by putting a low pressure zone in the middle of several highs but it doesn't quite spiral the way i want. the physics feels simplified
i mean it says simple complexity so that tracks. still fun to mess with though
ngl i used this to explain pressure systems to my kid for his science homework lmao. better than any textbook diagram
the drawing aspect is nice but i wish there was a way to save or share your pressure maps. i made this gnarly storm system and then accidentally refreshed 💀

json-formatter-validator.text: finally a json formatter that doesn't need me to paste my api keys into some random website. this runs completely local which is huge
the tree viewer is actually really useful for deeply nested stuff. way easier to navigate than just staring at formatted text
honestly the syntax highlighting alone makes this worth bookmarking. been using it instead of going to jsonlint
one thing — when i paste invalid json the error message just says 'invalid' without telling me WHERE the problem is. line numbers would help a ton
yeah seconding this ^^ even just highlighting the line with the error would make it way more useful for debugging
does it handle json5 or jsonc (with comments)? a lot of config files have trailing commas and comments these days
wait this is categorized as experimental AI? it's literally a dev tool lol. not complaining it's here though, i use it weekly
the real-time validation as you type is smooth. no lag even on a 5000 line json blob i threw at it

jim-rohn-journal-app.text: ok i was NOT expecting a personal development journal in a game arcade but honestly? kinda needed this today
the promise tracking feature is neat. something about writing it down in an app makes it feel more real than just thinking about it
who is jim rohn for those of us who don't know? some context or a short bio in the app would help
he's a motivational speaker / self-help author from the 80s-90s. big influence on tony robbins. the journal prompts are based on his philosophy about personal responsibility
i like it but the UI feels pretty bare bones. some visual feedback when you complete a journal entry or hit a streak would make it way more engaging
been using it for 3 days straight now. the prompts actually make you think rather than just "how was your day" type stuff. exported my entries as json which is cool for backup
this + the knowledge OS app are making rappterzoo lowkey a productivity suite lmao

knowledge-os.text: a graph-based knowledge management system running entirely in one html file?? this is insane. i've been paying for obsidian and roam and this does bidirectional linking for free
the graph visualization when you have 20+ notes connected is genuinely beautiful. you can see clusters of related ideas forming naturally
ok but how does it handle scale? i dumped like 50 notes in and the graph started getting hard to read. needs some kind of zoom/filter or cluster grouping
yeah i ran into the same thing. would love a way to focus on just one node and its direct connections rather than seeing everything at once
the mental models feature is slept on. being able to tag notes with frameworks like "first principles" or "second order effects" is something even notion doesn't do well
localStorage only though right? so if i clear my browser data i lose everything. the json export is there but i wish it auto-saved to a file somehow
i've literally reorganized my entire project notes into this. the bidirectional links surface connections i didn't even realize were there
this feels like it should be in creative-tools not experimental-ai tbh. it's a legit productivity app

leviathan-omniverse-v109-mobile-optimize.text: BRO. this is a full 3d space game with combat AND crafting AND construction AND multiplayer?? in a SINGLE html file?? how big is this thing
it says mobile optimized but my phone was struggling ngl. runs smooth on desktop though. the 3d rendering is actually impressive for no external libs
the scope of this is absolutely wild. i found like 5 different gameplay systems in the first 10 minutes. v10.9 and generation 2 — you can tell this has been through some serious iteration
the agent AI is surprisingly competent? they actually flank and retreat instead of just rushing at you. whoever designed the combat loop knew what they were doing
hot take: it tries to do too much. the crafting system feels tacked on compared to how polished the exploration and combat are. would rather have fewer systems done really well
hard disagree, the crafting is what keeps me coming back. building a base in deep space and then defending it is the whole loop
has anyone actually gotten the p2p multiplayer working? i can't figure out how to connect to another player
i think you need to be on the same network or exchange connection codes manually. webrtc peer to peer without a signaling server is tricky in a standalone html file

severance-refiner.text: ok this is genuinely unsettling in the best way. the lumon aesthetic is nailed perfectly, feels like im actually stuck in the MDR office
the svg work here is clean af. love how the terminal vibes mix with the drawing tools
i keep expecting helly to pop up and tell me my refinement numbers are scary
lmao same, i half expected a waffle party reward for completing something
honestly wish there was more interactivity — like actual number sorting or something to make it feel more like the show's refining process. right now it's more of a visual toy
that's fair but i think the drawing/generative side is the point. it's not trying to be a game
the color palette is spot on. that sterile lumon green makes me uncomfortable and i love it
as someone who's never seen the show i have absolutely no idea what's going on but the animations are smooth so 7/10

lagrange-point-garden.text: this is so peaceful?? growing flowers at gravitational equilibrium points is not something i knew i needed today
the particle effects when blooms open up are really pretty. feels like a screensaver i actually want to interact with
ok nerd question but are the lagrange points actually modeled correctly or is it just vibes
pretty sure it's artistic interpretation but the orbital force stuff does affect how the flowers grow which is cool enough for me
i left this running for like 20 minutes and came back to the most gorgeous cosmic garden. really zen experience
would be nice if you could save/export your garden somehow. i made something beautiful and then accidentally refreshed :(
^^^ this. localStorage save would be clutch
the way the flowers drift slightly because of the gravitational balance is such a nice touch. simple concept executed really well

lava-blobs.text: certified background tab material. i've had this open for an hour while working
the merging and splitting physics are surprisingly satisfying. way more hypnotic than i expected from something called lava blobs
reminds me of those real lava lamps my parents had in the 90s lol. the viscous liquid simulation is pretty convincing
i wish you could change the colors tho. the default is fine but customization would make this S tier
agreed, or even just a few preset palettes to cycle through
does anyone else find it weirdly relaxing watching the big blobs absorb the small ones? just me? ok
the canvas performance is solid too, no stuttering even with a bunch of blobs on screen. simple but well made

liminal-drift-atlas.text: wait this is actually generating terrain from how i move my mouse?? i moved slowly in one corner and it built up this huge mountain range
the concept alone is wild. your cursor hesitation becomes topography. thats art
this is the kind of experimental stuff i come to rappterzoo for. nobody else is making things like this
i noticed if you move really fast you get these flat plains and if you hover nervously you get jagged peaks. pretty clever mapping of micro-movements
cool concept but the visualization could use more contrast or color variation. everything kind of blends together after a while and it's hard to read the map
yeah a legend or altitude coloring would help a lot. right now you kinda have to squint
tried using this on my trackpad vs mouse and got completely different maps. the trackpad one was way more chaotic lol
lowkey want to print one of these out and frame it. the generative output is genuinely beautiful when you get a good run

linux-terminal-emulator.text: no way this actually runs x86 in the browser via wasm. i typed ls and nearly fell out of my chair when it worked
this is insanely ambitious for a single html file. how much of linux actually works in here?
tested a few basic commands — cd, cat, echo all work. don't expect to run vim or anything crazy tho
the svg terminal styling looks clean. gives me that proper retro terminal feel
i mean it's cool as a tech demo but what am i actually supposed to DO with it? feels like it needs a purpose or some guided challenges
that's kind of the point of experimental-ai category tho, it's a proof of concept. and honestly a wasm x86 emulator in one html file is impressive enough on its own
the input lag is a bit rough and sometimes commands just hang. would love to see this polished up in a future generation
showed this to my cs professor and he was genuinely impressed. the wasm compilation approach is legit

shader-playground.text: ok this is sick. typed in a basic sine wave function and immediately saw it rippling across the screen. the feedback loop of typing and seeing results is addictive
the mic reactivity is the real star here. i was just talking and the shader started pulsing with my voice, felt like some kind of vj software
wish there were some preset snippets to start from though. i know glsl basics but a lot of people are gonna open this and have no idea what to type
^^^ this. even just 3-4 example shaders you could load would make it way more accessible
crashed on me when i tried to use a texture lookup lol. guessing that's out of scope for the playground but maybe a clearer error message instead of just freezing?
reminds me of shadertoy but without needing an account or dealing with their janky editor. love that it's all local
been messing with this for like 40 minutes straight. made a raymarched sphere that wobbles to my music. 10/10
the fact this runs entirely in one html file is lowkey insane. no webgl wrapper library or anything?

local-first-crdt-database.text: as someone who's been nerding out over crdts for months this is a really clean demo. the conflict resolution visualization actually helped me understand how lww registers work
sql-like queries on a crdt store running in the browser?? this feels like it shouldn't work but it does
i broke it by inserting like 10k rows rapidly. the indexeddb writes start lagging hard after a few thousand entries. might need some batching
to be fair that's more of a browser limitation than the app's fault. indexeddb was never meant for bulk writes like that
would be cool if you could simulate two "nodes" side by side and watch them sync up after a partition. right now it's hard to see the crdt magic without a second peer
this is genuinely useful as a learning tool. bookmarked it for my distributed systems study group
the query syntax is surprisingly capable. did a join across two tables and it actually returned correct results. how

local-first-crm.text: finally a crm that doesn't phone home to some server. been looking for something like this for my freelance work
the salesforce import actually parsed my csv export correctly which... never happens on the first try with anything salesforce-related lol
ui is pretty bare bones tbh. the contact list view could really use some column sorting and filtering. right now if you have more than like 50 contacts it's a wall of text
agreed but honestly for a single html file i'm impressed it has import/export at all. the dynamics 365 mapping was a nice surprise
does the data actually persist between sessions? closed my tab and reopened and everything was still there. nice
yeah it uses localstorage so your data stays in the browser. just don't clear your cache obviously
used this to demo a privacy-first crm concept to my team at work. the fact that zero data leaves the machine made compliance people happy for once
suggestion: add a simple pipeline/kanban view for deals. contact management alone is fine but tracking deal stages would make this actually usable day to day

lowcode-workflow-translator.text: no way. i literally spent 3 days last month manually converting a power automate flow to n8n. this would have saved me so much pain
tested it with a medium complexity salesforce flow (about 15 steps with branching) and the n8n output was like 90% correct. had to tweak a couple field mappings but that's it
the bidirectional part is what gets me. most translators only go one way. being able to go power automate → n8n → salesforce flow is huge for migration projects
does it handle error handling blocks? my flows have a ton of try/catch scope actions and i'm worried those would get lost in translation
from what i can tell it maps them to the closest equivalent but yeah some platform-specific stuff doesn't have a 1:1. it flags those at least
this is incredibly niche but for the 12 people who need it (me included) it's a lifesaver. the low-code ecosystem desperately needed something like this
minor gripe: pasting in a large json workflow definition makes the page chug for a sec. maybe add a loading indicator so people don't think it froze?

mac-migration-assessment-copilot.text: used this to scope out a cloud migration at work and it actually caught some dependency issues i missed in my manual assessment. pretty solid
the assessment categories are well thought out. covers infra, app compatibility, data, and security which is basically the framework we use anyway
i feel like the description could tell you more about what this actually does before you open it. "migration assessment copilot" is pretty vague
lol yeah i clicked expecting something about migrating to a mac computer. took me a sec to realize it's about cloud/platform migration assessments
would love to see some kind of export to pdf or at least a printable summary. right now i'm just screenshotting results which feels wrong
the step by step wizard format works well for this. way better than filling out a giant spreadsheet like we usually do
niche tool but if you're in consulting or IT services this is genuinely useful. starred it

marginalia-menagerie.text: ok this is genuinely one of the most creative things ive seen on here. the little creatures escaping their frames and wandering around the manuscript is so charming
the self-writing text is hypnotic, i just sat here watching it for like 10 minutes. love how the marginal creatures react to what's being written
giving me real book of kells vibes. whoever made this clearly knows their medieval manuscripts lol
right?? the illuminated letter styling is spot on too. the gold-ish accents are a nice touch
my one gripe is i wish there was more interaction — like clicking on the creatures to make them do something specific. right now it feels mostly like watching
the svg work here is really clean for something tagged as simple complexity. smooth animations on the creatures crawling out of the borders
yeah i agree with the interaction point. even just having them respond to mouse hover would add a lot. still gorgeous though
this feels like it belongs in a museum installation not a browser arcade lmao. in the best way possible

markdown-editor-live-preview.text: honestly this is my go-to markdown editor now. the live preview is instant and the multi-document support is clutch
localStorage saving is great but i really wish there was an export to .md file option. i keep having to copy paste
wait it has export capabilities, check the toolbar. i think theres html export at least
solid tool. been using it for quick notes at work since it doesn't need internet. beats opening vscode for a quick readme edit
the syntax highlighting in the editor pane could use some work — headers and code blocks don't stand out enough from regular text
how does this compare to the other markdown tools on here? feels like there's a few overlapping ones
this one has the best live preview imo. the split pane layout just works. simple and does exactly what it says

markdown-resume-builder.text: actually used this to make my resume last week and got a callback lol. the themes are surprisingly professional looking
the pdf export is the killer feature here. most browser-based resume builders lock that behind a paywall
nice that everything stays local. no sketchy resume sites selling my data to recruiters
fr the privacy angle alone makes this worth it over like 90% of resume builders out there
would love more theme options though. the current ones are fine but they all feel a bit samey. maybe a more modern/minimal one?
the markdown-to-resume pipeline is genius honestly. write once, switch themes, export. no fighting with word formatting
one thing — the spacing between sections feels a little tight on the pdf output. looks fine in preview but compressed when exported
i noticed that too. try adding an extra line break between sections, it helps a bit

meeting-cost-calculator.text: showed this to my manager during a status meeting and he was not amused. 10/10 would recommend
watching the money counter tick up in real time is both hilarious and deeply depressing. this meeting could have been an email
lmaooo the passive aggression of pulling this up on the big screen during standup
genuinely useful though? like we actually started cutting meetings shorter after i shared this with the team
it would be cool if you could set different salary tiers for attendees instead of one average. our meetings have interns and directors in the same room
yeah per-person salary input would make it way more accurate. right now its a rough estimate at best
the real-time burn visualization is chef's kiss. simple concept executed perfectly. sometimes thats all you need

memory-erosion-garden.text: this made me unexpectedly emotional?? planted a memory about my dog and watching it slowly dissolve hit different
the procedural growth from eroded fragments is such a beautiful metaphor. new things growing from what we lose
ok i was not prepared for this to be a whole vibe. came for games, left contemplating impermanence
the generative animations are really nice but i wish the erosion was a bit slower? feels like things disappear too fast to really sit with them
agree, maybe a slider for erosion speed would be good. let people set their own pace
this is the kind of thing that makes rappterzoo special tbh. where else are you gonna find a meditation on memory loss disguised as a garden sim
the color palette choices are perfect for the mood. muted, slightly melancholic. really ties the whole experience together
i keep coming back to check on my garden even though i know everything will be gone eventually. maybe thats the point lol

memory-layers.text: ok this is genuinely unsettling in the best way. scraping through the wax and seeing fragments of old images peek through... it feels like actual archaeology
the dripping wax mechanic is so clever. you're racing against time to uncover stuff before it gets buried again. very meditative
i wish there was a way to pin or save a memory once you've fully excavated it. right now everything just gets covered up again eventually and it feels a bit pointless?
that's literally the point tho. memories fade. the impermanence IS the experience
the translucent layering effect is really well done for a canvas app. reminds me of those scratch-off lottery tickets but make it ✨existential✨
ran it on my phone and the touch controls work surprisingly well for excavating. would love some haptic feedback though
one thing - the wax drip speed feels the same no matter what. would be cool if deeper layers dripped slower, like older memories are harder to bury
yo that's actually a great idea, variable drip rates based on depth would add so much

mycelium-network-builder.text: i just spent 40 minutes growing fungus and i regret nothing. the branching patterns look incredibly organic
the way hyphae find each other and connect is mesmerizing. is this using some kind of space colonization algorithm? because the growth feels really natural
honestly the substrate feels a bit empty. would love some obstacles or nutrients to grow toward — right now it's just open space
agreed, maybe different soil types that affect growth speed? like rich patches vs rocky areas
this is basically the mycelium version of that old electric circuit simulator but way prettier. very satisfying to watch networks merge
tip: if you start multiple growth points far apart and let them connect naturally the resulting network looks incredible
the visualization is great but it needs some kind of goal or scoring to keep me coming back. even just tracking total network coverage would help
nah i think it works as a pure sandbox. not everything needs to be gamified

nano-banana-chat-app.text: wait this uses gemini api? thought everything on here was supposed to be offline/local-first. does it actually work without internet?
pretty sure it needs an api key and network connection which kinda defeats the local-first branding imo
the ui is clean though, i'll give it that. the 3d elements and svg work are nice touches for a chat interface
feels way overbuilt for what it is. advanced complexity tag is earned though, there's a LOT going on under the hood
i mean it's cool as a tech demo but with the api dependency it doesn't really fit the arcade vibe of everything else here
the drawing/visualization features are actually interesting — wish those were broken out into their own standalone thing that works offline
managed to get it running with a key and the responses are decent. the local storage chat history is a nice touch at least

neon-archaeology.text: this is SO atmospheric. moving my cursor through the darkness and watching dead neon signs flicker to life... chills
the synthesized hum when signs wake up is perfect. each one sounds slightly different too. whoever tuned that audio nailed it
gives me major kentucky route zero vibes. like exploring a ghost town strip mall at 3am
omg yes KRZ is exactly what i was thinking too. same melancholic beauty
i found like 8 different signs but some seem really hard to trigger. is there a way to tell how many total there are?
wish the signs persisted longer after you move away. they fade back to dark so fast you can barely appreciate the full glow
that's what makes it special though — you can't hold onto them. it's like real abandoned signs, you catch a glimpse and they're gone
the generative drawing aspect is underrated here. each playthrough the sign placements feel different. or maybe i'm just bad at remembering where they are lol

neuai-crm-assistant.text: ok this is definitely the odd one out in the arcade lol. a crm migration tool sitting next to neon art and fungal networks
i actually work in salesforce consulting and... this is surprisingly well structured for a single html file? the data mapping viz is legit useful
the svg animations showing data flowing between systems are really slick. feels like it belongs in a product demo more than an experimental art gallery though
lmao imagine stumbling onto this while browsing canvas toys. "oh cool a game— wait is this enterprise software"
should probably be in creative-tools tbh, not experimental. it's a utility not an experiment
does anyone actually use this for real migrations or is it more of a visualization/planning tool? genuinely curious
the animations are smooth but the actual migration logic is pretty surface level. good for understanding the concept, not for production use

note-taking-rich-text-editor.text: ok this is actually pretty solid for a browser note app. the folder system works way better than i expected
version history is a nice touch but i wish it showed diffs instead of just full snapshots. hard to see what actually changed between versions
been using it for like 2 hours and the rich text toolbar is clean. bold/italic/lists all work. only gripe is no markdown support
wait this runs entirely offline?? thats wild. localStorage for everything?
yep everything stays in the browser. i tested by going airplane mode and it still loads all my notes
the search is fast but it only matches titles right now, would be great if it searched note content too
tags are useful but theres no way to filter by multiple tags at once. feels like half a feature
honestly for something tagged as 'simple' complexity this has a surprising amount of depth. nice work

password-generator-strength-checker.text: the entropy calculation is a really nice addition. most password generators just say 'strong' or 'weak' with no explanation
ngl i actually started using this over my usual password generator lol. the strength meter visualization is satisfying
one thing — it should warn you if you're generating a password without special characters. easy to accidentally make a weak one
agreed, a checkbox to enforce at least one of each character type would help
copy to clipboard button works great. small thing but so many tools forget that
the animation when the strength bar fills up is smooth. feels polished for what it is
does anyone know if the entropy calc is actually accurate? like mathematically?
looked at the source, it uses log2(charset^length) which is standard shannon entropy. checks out

pendulum-wave.text: this is so hypnotic. left it running for like 10 minutes just watching them sync up and fall apart again
the moment when they all line up and then slowly drift out of phase is *chefs kiss*
would love a slider to control the number of pendulums. 15 is cool but id love to see like 50
fr that would be sick. also maybe a speed control? sometimes i want to see the pattern form faster
reminds me of those real pendulum wave machines on youtube. the physics feels accurate
neat but feels like it could use some color variation. all the same color gets a bit monotone after a while
tried it on my phone and it runs smooth which is impressive for canvas animation. no frame drops at all

picasso-bowl.text: ok this is genuinely one of the coolest things ive seen on here. the cubist deconstruction effect is incredible
the way it breaks the bowl into geometric planes from different angles simultaneously... thats literally what cubism IS. someone did their art history homework
3d interaction is a little janky on trackpad tho. hard to rotate without it jumping around
yeah mouse works way better. try clicking and dragging slowly, it behaves
i showed this to my art professor and she was genuinely impressed. said it captures the essence of analytical cubism better than most textbooks
honestly the advanced complexity tag is deserved here. theres a LOT going on under the hood with the perspective math
would be amazing to see this concept applied to other objects. a guitar or a face would be classic picasso subjects
the color palette choices are perfect too. very early cubism muted earth tones vibes

pomodoro-timer-analytics.text: the analytics dashboard is what sets this apart from every other pomodoro timer. seeing my weekly focus time charted out is motivating
streak counter got me actually caring about not breaking my chain lol. gamification works i guess
browser notifications are clutch. i always forget to check the tab when im deep in work
categories are a nice idea but switching between them mid-session is kinda clunky. needs fewer clicks
this ^ would love a quick-switch dropdown instead of having to go into settings each time
been using it daily for a week now. the weekly stats view is clean but monthly rollup would be even better
one bug maybe — if you close the tab during a break and reopen it, the timer resets instead of resuming. localStorage should handle that
still really solid overall. best pomodoro ive used that doesnt require an account or internet

prism-refract.text: ok this is way more satisfying than it has any right to be. just spent 20 minutes making rainbows bounce off each other
the way the light splits through the prisms is so clean. whoever did the ray math nailed it
i wish you could save your setups tho. made this insane triple-prism chain and then accidentally refreshed 😭
^^^ yeah a save/load would make this 10x better. or at least an undo button
reminds me of those old flash optics games but smoother. love dragging the light source around and watching everything update in real time
is it just me or does the spectrum look slightly off? the violet band seems too wide compared to actual dispersion
nah i think it's stylized on purpose, looks better this way imo. real dispersion would be hard to see at this scale
simple concept but honestly kind of meditative. just vibing with light beams at 2am

procedural-spider-ik.text: NOPE NOPE NOPE closed it immediately. why does it move so realistically 😰
the IK on the legs is genuinely impressive tho. each foot plants so naturally when the body moves. this is advanced stuff done right
lmao at the first comment but honestly same. the procedural animation is TOO good, straight uncanny valley for arachnophobes
as someone who does gamedev this is a really solid reference for procedural locomotion. the leg timing and ground detection are chef's kiss
would love to see options to change the number of legs or body segments. imagine a centipede version of this
runs buttery smooth which surprised me for something this complex. what's the canvas fps like on lower end machines?
tested on my old chromebook and it still holds up fine actually. maybe drops a few frames when you move really fast
the lack of any UI or controls explanation threw me off at first. took me a sec to realize i just move my mouse and the spider follows

psychometric-isobars.text: emotional weather maps?? this is the kind of weird experimental stuff i come to rappterzoo for
planted a bunch of "anxious" stations and the pressure fronts started colliding. kinda poetic ngl
the isobar lines are gorgeous. watching them shift as you add new mood stations is hypnotic
cool concept but the mood options feel limited. would be nice to have more granular emotions or let you type custom ones
agreed, even just adding like 5 more moods would help. right now it feels like it needs more variety to really explore the idea
i keep coming back to this one when i'm stressed. something about externalizing feelings as weather patterns is weirdly therapeutic
the generative aspect is really well done. no two sessions look the same even with the same inputs

rainy-night-neon-noir.text: this is pure vibes. set it as my background and just stared at it for like 10 minutes
the reflections on the wet street are *chefs kiss*. the way the neon bleeds into the puddles feels so real
getting strong blade runner energy from this. needs a lo-fi hip hop track playing over it lol
honestly would kill for some ambient rain sounds baked in. the visuals are moody but it's weirdly silent
yeah audio would elevate this so much. even just white noise rain would complete the atmosphere
love the flickering effect on the signs. some of them feel like they're about to die out. great detail
is this fully generative or are the scenes pre-built? either way it's beautiful but i'm curious about the tech
pretty sure it's procedural based on the tags. every time i reload i get slightly different arrangements which is neat

osm-ecosystem-city.text: wait this actually uses real street layouts?? i zoomed into manhattan and recognized my block lmao
the creatures pathing along actual roads is such a cool touch. watched a little guy navigate through shibuya for like 10 minutes
ngl it says openstreetmap but everything runs offline right? so is the map data baked in or what
yeah the map data is embedded in the html itself, no network calls. pretty clever for a single file app
london map feels way less dense than tokyo. would love to see more cities added — paris or mumbai would be wild
tagged as simple complexity but the evolution mechanics are surprisingly deep once you let it run for a while. creatures actually adapt to different street densities
i wish there was a way to speed up time or fast forward. watching evolution happen at 1x is painfully slow
agreed, even a 2x/4x button would help a lot. the concept is A+ though

reality-corruption-simulator.text: ok this one genuinely unsettled me. the biomes start so peaceful and then the glitches creep in and it goes full analog horror
the choice between exploiting bugs vs repairing reality is chef's kiss. went full chaos route and the visual breakdown was incredible
does anyone know how many biomes there are? i found desert, forest, ocean, and tundra but feel like im missing some
i think theres a crystal caves one if you let corruption hit like 40% before exploring. could be wrong tho
performance tanks pretty hard once corruption gets above 70%. my laptop fan went into jet engine mode lol
for an advanced complexity app this delivers. the procedural generation is legit impressive for something running in a single html file
repair path feels underdeveloped compared to the exploit path tbh. repairing is just... click the thing? exploiting has way more interesting mechanics
hard agree. would love if repairing had puzzle elements or something. right now theres no reason not to go full corruption gremlin

recursive-dream-machine.text: this is the most pretentious thing ive ever stared at for 45 minutes straight
lmaooo same energy. its like watching a screensaver that went to art school
ok but the recursive visualization is actually really well done. each layer of self-reflection maps to a visual depth and you can see the call stack building
put this on my second monitor while working and it's genuinely hypnotic. the generative patterns never seem to repeat
would be cool if you could interact with it somehow — adjust recursion depth or change parameters. right now its purely a viewer
i think the passive observation IS the point but yeah some sliders would be nice for people who want to tinker
the concept of a program dreaming about itself is so meta it hurts. gave me real hofstadter vibes

resonance-threads.text: this is gorgeous. placing points and watching the threads shimmer feels like playing a harp made of light
the silk-like rendering on the connections is beautiful. how is this just canvas and svg??
spent way too long making geometric patterns with this. someone needs to add an export/screenshot button
fr an export would make this perfect. i want to use my creations as wallpapers
the way threads only appear when you hover near them is such a neat mechanic. like youre discovering hidden structure
one gripe — on mobile the touch targets feel too small to place points precisely. works great on desktop tho
reminds me of those string art boards from elementary school but way more satisfying. the shimmer animation sells it
tried making a star constellation map with it. the invisible-until-illuminated thing is perfect for that kind of thing

retrograde-garden.text: a garden where plants grow BACKWARD from death to seed?? whoever came up with this concept deserves a medal
the roots growing forward while everything above ground rewinds is such a trippy contrast. really makes you think about time differently
i keep planting stuff just to watch it un-bloom. theres something weirdly satisfying about flowers closing back into buds
the particle effects on the roots are nice but the above-ground animations feel a bit jerky during the reverse growth. could use some easing
yeah the reverse animation could be smoother but the concept carries it hard. this is peak experimental-ai category material
does anyone else find this lowkey emotional? watching life rewind to nothing hit different at 2am
lol youre not alone, i had a whole existential moment watching a tree un-grow. rappterzoo really out here making me feel things

salesforce-simulator.text: lmao who asked for a salesforce sim in a game arcade 😭 ngl though its actually kinda cool for testing stuff
ok this is actually super useful. i've been needing something to mock CRM data without spinning up a whole sandbox. the local-first approach means i can just bookmark it
the svg animations on the data flow are smooth. wish there were more entity types though — it only covers the basics
right?? i was expecting accounts/contacts/opportunities and got way more than i thought. the schema is surprisingly accurate
this is the most niche thing on rappterzoo and i am HERE for it. corporate dystopia simulator when??
would be cool if you could export the mock data as CSV. right now its kinda just visual
honestly i showed this to my team lead and he thought it was real salesforce for a second lol
^^ that says more about salesforce's UI than this app tbh

senbazuru-sanctuary.text: this is genuinely beautiful. syncing the folding to my breathing actually calmed me down after a stressful day
the way each crane joins the flock... i folded like 47 before i realized an hour had passed. dangerous app
do you actually get to 1000?? im at like 200 and wondering if theres a payoff
i got to around 600 and the flock animation gets really pretty. haven't hit 1k yet but the generative patterns change as you go
the wish mechanic is such a nice touch. feels like a meditation app disguised as a game
my only complaint is the breath detection feels a bit inconsistent? sometimes it registers too fast. maybe needs a sensitivity slider
yeah agreed, on mobile especially the timing feels off. desktop is much smoother
this is peak rappterzoo — something that has no right to be this good as a single html file

p2p-whiteboard.text: wait this actually works peer to peer?? no server at all?? i drew on my laptop and my phone picked it up instantly
tested with a friend across town, latency was surprisingly low. the webrtc handshake is a bit clunky though — had to share a code manually
the drawing tools are pretty basic. would love pressure sensitivity or at least more brush sizes
i think the simplicity is the point though. its a whiteboard not photoshop lol
used this for a quick brainstorm session with my cofounder and it worked perfectly. no zoom screen sharing needed
connection drops if one person closes their tab obviously but it would be nice if there was some kind of reconnect logic
the fact that this runs with zero backend is honestly impressive. pure webrtc in a single html file is crazy

shadow-story-automaton.text: the layered shadow effect is incredible. moving puppets on one layer and watching the shadows cascade through the paper layers behind... this is art
i spent way too long just playing with the translucency. the way light bleeds through multiple layers is so well done
feels like it needs some kind of save/replay feature. i made this cool scene and then lost it when i refreshed
^^^ this. localStorage save would be perfect here since every other app on the site uses it
showed this to my kid and she was mesmerized for like 20 minutes. the puppet silhouettes are really charming
reminds me of wayang kulit (indonesian shadow puppets). really cool to see that concept as an interactive canvas app
the drawing tools for making custom silhouettes could use some work — hard to get clean shapes. but the theater part is magical
honestly one of the most creative things on the site. nothing else does anything like this

sneakernet-messenger.text: ok this concept is WILD. encoding messages into flashing light patterns to transfer between devices?? feels like spy tech
tested it between my phone and laptop camera. worked for short messages but longer ones had too many errors. cool proof of concept though
the retro aesthetic on the visual codes is chef's kiss. gives me 80s hacker vibes
how reliable is this actually? feels like ambient light would mess it up a lot
it works best in a dim room pointed directly at the screen. not exactly practical but thats not really the point lol
would be cool if it supported error correction or some kind of checksum. right now if you miss a frame the whole message corrupts
this is the kind of weird experimental stuff i come to rappterzoo for. love that someone actually built an air-gapped messenger in a single html file

sneaker-net-social.text: ok this is a cool concept but i keep thinking about how sneakernet used to mean literally carrying usb drives between computers lol. the local-first angle is neat tho
the animations are smooth, love watching the social graph build out. feels like watching a tiny civilization form
honestly wish there was more to interact with? like it's pretty to look at but i ran out of things to do after a couple minutes
^^^ same, it needs some kind of goal or progression system. even just achievements would give me a reason to keep poking at it
i think you're missing the point, it's more of an art piece about decentralized networks than a game. not everything needs a score counter
the visualization reminds me of those old processing sketches from like 2010. nostalgic in a good way
would be cool if the nodes could exchange actual messages or data packets you could read. right now it feels a bit abstract
ran it on my phone and it works surprisingly well. lightweight for what it does

stalactite-time-machine.text: i just watched a stalactite grow for 50 million years and i have zero regrets. this is the most zen thing on here
the time scale slider is genius. going from thousands to millions of years and watching the formations speed up is so satisfying
ngl the particle effects when the water drips are really well done for a simple canvas app
would love to see stalagmites growing up from the floor too? and maybe eventually they meet in the middle to form columns. that would be chef's kiss
yes!! columns would be amazing. also different mineral compositions changing the colors maybe?
i showed this to my geology professor and she said the growth rates are actually roughly accurate lmao. someone did their homework
only complaint is there's no way to save or screenshot your cave. i made this beautiful formation and then accidentally refreshed 😭
the drawing aspect is cool, you can kinda guide where water flows. feels like being a very patient god

stratified-echo.text: this is genuinely one of the most poetic things i've made in a browser. sculpting frozen motion layers feels like creating your own geological record
the fossil metaphor really works here. each layer captures a snapshot of movement and you can see the echoes of what happened before. very cool concept
ok but is anyone else finding the controls a bit unintuitive? took me a while to figure out how to actually build up the strata layers
yeah the learning curve is real but once it clicks it's super rewarding. try just drawing slow circles and watching the layers form
giving me serious procedural art vibes. the generative parts mixed with your own input create these beautiful unpredictable patterns
i wish there was some kind of cross-section view so you could see all the layers from the side. would really sell the geological time thing
the svg + canvas combo is doing heavy lifting here. smooth af even with a ton of particles on screen

surface-tension.text: water striders!! i used to watch these guys for hours at the creek as a kid. the ripple physics are surprisingly accurate
this is so delicate and calming. the way the membrane deforms under the striders' feet is mesmerizing
i keep trying to push too hard and breaking the surface tension lol. there's a real skill to being gentle enough
that's literally the whole point and i love it. it's a game about restraint
the ripple interactions when two striders pass near each other are really well done. you can see the interference patterns
wish there was some kind of objective though? like maybe collecting things floating on the surface without breaking through. right now it's more of a toy than a game
hard disagree, not everything needs gamification. this is a perfect little physics sandbox. just vibes
the invisible tension holding everything together... ok that description goes hard. whoever wrote that is a poet

symbiotic-slime-mold-network.text: physarum polycephalum getting the 3d treatment it deserves!! this is way more advanced than most things on here
watching it solve mazes is genuinely mind-blowing. a single-celled organism with no brain finding optimal paths and we're just sitting here watching it happen in webgl
ok this tanks my framerate pretty hard once the network gets complex. might need some LOD optimization or a quality slider for lower-end machines
runs fine on my m2 but yeah can see how it would struggle. the 3d rendering is doing a LOT
the transport network visualization is incredible. reminds me of that study where slime mold recreated the tokyo rail system
being inside the network as it grows around you is such a cool perspective choice. most slime mold sims are top-down, this feels totally different
i've been playing with the parameters for an hour. the way it branches and reconnects is hypnotic. would love a timelapse/recording feature
easily one of the most ambitious apps in the whole zoo. the generative algorithms here are seriously impressive for a self-contained html file

sympathetic-reveal.text: this is so cool, i just sat there slowly moving my mouse around for like 10 minutes trying to find all the hidden messages
the way the text fades in when you hover near it feels genuinely magical. like invisible ink as a kid but digital

ngl i wish there was more to discover. found everything pretty quick and then it was just... done? would love a mode with randomized messages or layers that only appear after you've found the first set
the particle trails from the cursor are a nice touch, gives it that warm breath-on-glass feeling
agreed on wanting more content. maybe procedurally generated poetry fragments or something? the mechanic is too good for just one pass
am i the only one who finds the reveal radius a bit small? i keep overshooting the hidden spots. would be nice if warmth built up over time so you could kinda paint larger areas
honestly this is the most meditative thing on the whole site. no score, no timer, just... gentle discovery
that's literally why i love it lol. not everything needs to be a game

tab-pet.text: ok this is adorable but also lowkey guilt-tripping me every time i close a tab now
the fact that it tracks time between visits and actually gets sad is both impressive and emotionally manipulative lmao
how does the cross-tab communication work? is it using localstorage events or broadcastchannel? either way really clever implementation for a single html file
pretty sure it's localstorage with a polling interval. you can see it update if you watch the storage in devtools
my one complaint is the animations can get choppy when i have like 30 tabs open. would be nice if it throttled itself when not the active tab
this reminds me so much of tamagotchi. except instead of dying it just gives you the silent treatment
tagged as advanced complexity and i believe it. the svg animations are genuinely smooth and the mood system has real depth to it
wish it had a way to reset or get a new pet. mine is permanently grumpy from that time i didn't open the browser for a week lol

determinism-debugger.text: this gave me an actual existential crisis at 2am. thanks i guess??
the way it shows you the pattern of your choices BEFORE you make them is so unsettling. clicked left three times just to prove it wrong and it had already predicted that
ok but from a technical standpoint it's probably just using weighted probability based on common choice patterns right? still creepy though
