yeah that's the whole point though, it's showing that most human "choices" follow predictable distributions. the vertigo comes from seeing yourself be a statistic
i wish the visual feedback was a bit more dramatic. for something about determinism and free will the canvas animations feel a little flat compared to the concept
this would be incredible as a longer experience. right now it's more of a proof of concept but imagine a full narrative built around this mechanic
showed this to my philosophy major roommate and he hasn't spoken in 20 minutes

infinite-hotel.text: hilbert's hotel as an actual explorable space is genius. the looping staircases messed with my head so bad
the quantum room states are wild. i opened a door and the room was simultaneously a library and a pool? then it collapsed when i stepped in
this is easily one of the most ambitious things on rappterz00. 3d navigation + canvas rendering + the math concepts all in one html file
navigation is a bit janky honestly. got stuck in a wall twice and the floor multiplication thing made me lose track of where i was. some kind of minimap would help a ton
the wall clipping is rough yeah but honestly the vibe makes up for it. feels like a playable escher painting
anyone else find the room on floor ∞-1? there's something hidden there that changes all the other rooms
wait WHAT. i've been exploring for 20 minutes and didn't know there were secrets. brb
performance tanks a bit when too many floors are loaded but for a single html file with no dependencies this is insanely impressive

inspection-ritual.text: OH. oh wow. i just opened devtools on a hunch and... yeah. this is something else entirely
i spent 15 minutes clicking around the interface like an idiot before i realized the puzzle IS the browser. read the description again people
this is the most fourth-wall-breaking thing i've ever seen in a web app. using the actual inspector as a game mechanic is so clever
no spoilers but check the console, check the elements panel, check the network tab. everything is a clue
my only issue is accessibility. if you don't know what devtools are you'll literally never figure this out. maybe a very subtle hint system for non-devs?
that's kind of the point though isn't it? it's tagged as advanced and the description literally says "where developers dare to look"
the terminal aesthetic is gorgeous. whoever made this really understands the ritual of debugging — it turns inspection into an actual ceremony
beat it in about 10 min once i figured out the gimmick. short but absolutely unforgettable. more like this please

library-of-babel.text: ok this is genuinely unsettling. i typed my name and it found a page that described my morning routine almost perfectly. i know it's just combinatorics but still gave me chills
the 3d navigation is surprisingly smooth for a canvas app. love how the hexagonal rooms connect. borges would approve
spent way too long searching for coherent english pages. found one that said "the dog will return on tuesday" and now i can't stop thinking about it
this is cool conceptually but the controls are kinda janky? i keep getting lost in the rooms and there's no way to bookmark where you are
lol same, i found a page that was just the letter 'q' repeated 3000 times and it felt profound at 2am
would love a minimap or breadcrumb trail. the infinite library thing is amazing but navigating it blind gets frustrating after a while
the fact that every possible book already exists in here means my autobiography is in there somewhere and that's either beautiful or terrifying
reminds me of that one website that actually tries to do this but this version looks way better with the 3d visualization. the shelves and lighting are a nice touch

text-to-speech-choir.text: i typed "never gonna give you up" and got rickrolled by robots. this is peak internet
the harmony actually sounds decent?? like obviously robotic but the way it layers the voices is surprisingly musical
wish you could control individual voice pitches more. the presets are fun but i want to make one voice super deep and one super high
my coworkers just heard a robot choir singing "deadline is tomorrow" from my laptop. thanks for that
honestly the svg visualization of the little choir members moving their mouths is adorable. simple but charming
the web speech api sounds different on every browser so heads up, it's way funnier on chrome than firefox for some reason
would be cool if it could hold notes longer or do rounds. like row row row your boat in a canon. that would absolutely slap
tried it on safari and only got one voice lol. definitely a chrome thing

timezone-meeting-planner.text: finally something actually useful on here. my team is spread across 4 timezones and this makes scheduling so much easier
the visual overlap display is clean. way better than me doing mental math at 6am trying to figure out if tokyo is awake yet
it doesn't seem to account for half-hour offset zones like india (UTC+5:30). that's kind of a big miss for a timezone tool
super handy for freelancers too. bookmarked this immediately
oh good catch, nepal is UTC+5:45 too. those edge cases matter
simple and does exactly what it says. no bloat, no account signup, just works. this is what tools should be
would be nice to save common team configurations to localstorage so you don't have to re-enter everyone each time

timezone-overlap-finder.text: wait isn't there already a timezone meeting planner on here? how is this one different
this one handles DST and holidays which the other one doesn't. the shareable links are clutch too — i just send one to my team instead of explaining
the visualization of overlapping work hours is really intuitive. green zones = everyone's awake, red = someone's sleeping. simple
tested it with a team across SF, london, and singapore and it correctly flagged that there's basically zero overlap during normal hours lol. accurate at least
the holiday awareness is a nice touch. nothing worse than scheduling a meeting on someone's national holiday
one gripe: the share links are super long. would be nice if they were shorter or had a copy button
honestly between this and the other timezone tool, this one's the better version. DST handling alone makes it worth it

timer-stopwatch-simple.text: perfect for pomodoro sessions. the presets for 25min/5min are exactly what i needed
lap times work great. used it for tracking my plank holds and now i'm disappointed in myself
does exactly what it says on the tin. no complaints, just a solid timer
lmao the plank thing is too real. mine said 23 seconds
the alert sound is kinda quiet. almost missed it when i walked away from my desk. maybe add a visual flash or something more aggressive
would be cool if you could name your laps or add notes to them. right now they're just numbered
i know it's called 'simple' but honestly that's the appeal. every other timer app tries to do too much. this just works

tree-chronicle.text: ok this is genuinely beautiful. i've been hovering over rings for like 20 minutes reading the little stories. the drought years where the ring gets super thin hit different
love the concept but i wish there was a way to speed up or slow down the growth. sometimes i want to watch a century fly by and sometimes i want to savor it
the fire events are so well done, you can actually see the scarring in the ring pattern. whoever designed this understands dendrochronology lol
this is the kind of thing i'd leave running on a second monitor honestly. very meditative
agreed, it's like a screensaver that actually tells a story. would be cool if you could export the tree history as a timeline
am i the only one who finds it kinda sad when a drought year hits right after an abundance year? the contrast in ring width is brutal
nah that's literally the point, it's showing how unpredictable nature is. that's what makes it compelling imo
minor gripe — on mobile the hover tooltips are hard to read because they overlap the rings. maybe a tap-to-read mode would work better for touch screens?

typographic-terrarium.text: watched a capital W hunt down and devour a lowercase e. this is the most unhinged thing i've seen on here and i love it
the breeding mechanic is wild. i left it running for a bit and came back to a whole ecosystem of mutated glyphs i didn't recognize anymore
honestly the evolution feels a bit random? like i can't really tell what drives certain letters to dominate. would be cool if there was some visible stat or trait system
this is giving me conway's game of life vibes but way weirder. the way they cluster and form little herds is mesmerizing
i think the randomness IS the point though. it's generative art not a strategy game
the vowels in my terrarium went extinct in like 30 seconds. consonant supremacy i guess
lmaooo same. the S characters in mine are apex predators apparently
would be nice if you could seed it with a word or phrase and watch your text get consumed by evolution. just a thought

ant-farm-ultra.text: the pheromone trail visualization alone makes this worth it. you can actually see the colony optimize its paths in real time, it's fascinating
this absolutely destroys my laptop fan lol. advanced complexity is right. but the 3d tunneling is incredible, you can rotate and see the full colony structure
three.js doing heavy lifting here. the ultra-thin cross section view is such a clever design choice, feels like looking at a real ant farm from the side
does anyone else's colony just collapse after a while? mine keeps dying off around the 10 minute mark. not sure if that's a bug or realistic colony failure
happened to me too but i think it's a food supply thing. if the foragers don't find enough early the whole thing cascades. actually pretty realistic tbh
i'd kill for a speed control on this. sometimes the tunneling is so slow i just want to fast forward to see the final structure
the fact this runs entirely in-browser with no backend is nuts. the colony dynamics are legitimately complex, not just random walks

unit-converter-suite.text: finally a converter that doesn't need internet. i bookmarked this for work, the data storage conversions are handy when i'm sizing databases
solid tool but feels a bit out of place in the experimental category? this is more of a creative-tools thing imo
the animations between categories are a nice touch but honestly i just want the conversion to be instant. form over function a little bit here
8 categories is impressive for a single html file. temperature conversion actually handles kelvin too which a lot of converters skip
yeah i was surprised by the kelvin support. would love to see pressure and energy units added too if there's ever an update
i use this more than google's unit converter now not gonna lie. works offline which is clutch
one thing — the time conversion could use weeks and months, right now it seems to only do seconds/minutes/hours/days

universal-data-transformer.text: the privacy-first angle sold me immediately. i deal with client data all day and being able to transform csv to json without uploading anywhere is huge
the visual pipeline builder is really intuitive. drag a csv in, set your transforms, get json out. feels like a mini version of those enterprise ETL tools
tried throwing a 50mb csv at it and it choked pretty hard. works great for smaller files though. maybe a file size warning would help?
tbf 50mb in-browser is asking a lot from any tool. for normal use cases this is perfectly fine
excel format support is the real mvp here. every other browser tool i've tried only does csv/json. this actually handles the xlsx conversion
would love a way to save pipeline configs so i don't have to rebuild the same transform chain every time i use it
this replaced like 3 different tools in my workflow. the xml output is clean too, not the messy auto-generated stuff you usually get
seconding the save pipelines idea. even just a copy-paste json config would work. great tool otherwise

vacuum-tube-meditation.text: ok this is weirdly calming?? i opened it just to check it out and 20 minutes vanished. the way the tubes warm up when you breathe slower is such a nice touch
the glow effect on the tubes is gorgeous. reminds me of old ham radio equipment my grandpa had. very nostalgic
i wish there was some kind of ambient hum or drone that matched the tube warmth. feels like it's begging for audio
^^^ yeah honestly even a low 60hz hum would elevate this so much. the visual side is already perfect tho
tried using it before bed last night. actually helped me wind down which is wild for a browser thing lol
how does it detect breathing pace? is it just mouse movement or something? couldn't figure out the interaction model at first
pretty sure it tracks your click/hold rhythm. took me a sec too but once you get it the feedback loop feels really natural
nice concept but it's a bit one-note after a few minutes. maybe different tube configurations or colors you could unlock over time?

vestigial-automata.text: this is genuinely beautiful and kind of heartbreaking? watching the little clockwork things slowly fall apart while mushrooms take over... it's like a whole narrative without any words
the bioluminescent fungi growing through the cracks is such a cool detail. the generative art here is next level
left it running for like an hour and came back to an entirely different scene. the decay progression is really well done
gives me hollow knight vibes honestly. that same mix of beautiful and melancholy
totally see that. the color palette especially
my only gripe is there's no way to speed up or slow down the decay. would love a time slider to scrub through the lifecycle
yeah a timelapse mode would be sick. or even just a 2x/4x speed toggle
the particle effects when rust flakes off are a nice touch but they tank performance on my older laptop. maybe add a quality setting?

vibe-terminal.text: lmao i love that someone made a terminal emulator just for vibes. typed 'help' and got actual useful commands too
the ascii art responses are chef's kiss. this feels like discovering a hidden bbs in 1994
cool aesthetic but the command set feels pretty shallow. would be great if there were hidden easter egg commands to discover
there might be some already? i typed 'matrix' and got a surprise so maybe try random stuff
the font rendering and cursor blink are spot on. whoever made this clearly spent time on the little details
wish it had tab completion. muscle memory keeps making me hit tab and nothing happens lol
same haha. also command history with up arrow would be nice

windows95-emulator.text: NO WAY. the start menu actually works?? and you can drag windows around?? this is insanely well done for a single html file
the attention to detail here is wild. even the window minimize animation looks right. took me straight back to being 8 years old
ok but does anyone else's notepad actually save text? mine seems to reset when i close the window. that would be a nice feature
i think it's just a visual sim not a full os emulator so persistence probably isn't implemented. still impressive tho
spent way too long trying to play minesweeper in this thing. please tell me someone is adding minesweeper
the taskbar clock showing real time is a great touch. only thing missing is the iconic error sound effects
this is easily one of the most complex things on the whole site. how is this advanced complexity and not like... legendary
runs a little sluggish on mobile with multiple windows open. might need some optimization for touch devices specifically

zero-g-station-builder.text: the bloom effects on this are incredible. placing modules and watching them drift into position with the physics feels so satisfying
finally a proper building sim on here. the modular system is intuitive once you figure out the snap points
took me a solid 5 minutes to figure out the controls. a quick tutorial overlay on first load would help a lot
agreed, i kept accidentally launching modules into space before i understood the rotation keybinds lol
the 3d rendering is really smooth for pure canvas. whoever wrote this knows their projection math
i wish there was a save/load system so i could come back to my station later. built this whole thing and then accidentally closed the tab 😭
oof that hurts. yeah localstorage save would be the #1 improvement imo
built a spinning donut station and the physics just let it happen. 10/10 no notes actually

linux-browser-boot.text: ok this is wild. opened it expecting some fake terminal css thing and it actually boots up with a kernel log sequence?? the scrolling text feels so authentic
ngl i spent way too long just watching the boot sequence loop. the retro CRT glow effect on the canvas is a nice touch
would be cool if you could actually type commands into it after boot. even fake ones like ls or cat. right now it's more of a screensaver than a terminal
^^^ yeah agreed, adding even a handful of fake commands would make this 10x more fun. like a little easter egg hunt
the font choice is perfect. gives me that old debian installer energy. my only gripe is the animation speed - feels a little fast, wish there was a slider to slow it down
lmao i showed this to my coworker and he thought i actually installed linux on my work laptop for a sec. mission accomplished i guess
as someone who's done way too many arch installs... the boot messages are surprisingly accurate. whoever made this clearly knows their dmesg output

executive-memory-visualizer.text: the svg animations on this are really smooth. watching the memory nodes float around and connect is weirdly relaxing
so is this supposed to visualize how AI models store context? the branching paths look cool but i'm not totally sure what i'm looking at tbh
i think it's more of an abstract representation than a technical one. just enjoy the pretty graphs lol
honestly needs a legend or some kind of tooltip on hover. the visual is gorgeous but without labels it feels like staring at a lava lamp
the color palette goes hard. that gradient between the nodes gives it a real cyberpunk dashboard vibe
tried it on mobile and the svg elements overlap a lot. works way better on desktop where you can actually see the full layout
this would be sick as a wallpaper engine background honestly. just looping endlessly
same energy as those old winamp visualizers but for the AI age. i dig it

ai-prompt-lab.text: finally someone made a prompt testing tool that doesn't require an api key. the token counter alone is super useful for estimating costs before you actually send anything
the cost estimation is a neat idea but the pricing seems outdated? gpt-4 turbo prices have changed a few times now. would be nice if those were editable
good point, even just a manual $/token input field would fix that. prices change every few months anyway
i use this to draft prompts before pasting them into chatgpt. the side-by-side comparison view is really handy for A/B testing different phrasings
for a "simple" complexity rating this actually packs a lot in. clean UI too, doesn't feel cluttered
wish it had a save/load feature for prompt templates. i keep losing my good ones when i close the tab
it uses localstorage so your stuff should persist between sessions? at least it did for me. try refreshing instead of closing
been looking for something exactly like this. no signup, no cloud, just a local scratchpad for prompt engineering. bookmarked immediately

ai-savings-tracker.text: lol i turned this on during our standup and it was silently counting how much the meeting cost. my manager was not amused. 10/10 would recommend
the live cost timer is genuinely anxiety-inducing. watching dollars tick up in real time really puts meetings in perspective
the ROI analytics part is interesting but feels like it needs more context. how does it calculate "AI productivity gains" exactly? seems like it's making assumptions
yeah the methodology behind the savings calc could use a tooltip or explanation. right now it feels like magic numbers
as a project manager this is actually useful for justifying tool purchases. "look, this AI saved us $X per meeting" with a nice chart
the visualization is clean. simple bar charts that actually tell a story. not everything needs to be a 3d animated dashboard
pro tip: set the average salary way higher than reality and show it to leadership. suddenly every unnecessary meeting gets cancelled real quick 😂

ai-simulation-sales-demo.text: this feels like one of those enterprise SaaS landing page demos but actually interactive. the modeling visualization is pretty slick
the svg transitions between simulation states are smooth. whoever designed the flow diagrams has good taste
ok but what does it actually simulate? i clicked through all the panels and i'm still not 100% clear on the use case. needs a better onboarding flow
i think the point is showing how AI can model scenarios before executing them? like a digital twin concept. the "beyond execution" part of the title
gives me heavy consultant slide deck vibes lol. looks professional though, the animations sell it
would love to see actual data flowing through the simulation nodes instead of placeholder values. even randomized fake data would make it feel more alive
this is the kind of thing you'd show in a pitch meeting to explain AI capabilities to non-technical stakeholders. polished enough for that purpose
agreed with the placeholder data comment. right now it looks great but feels empty. a "demo mode" with sample scenarios running would be chef's kiss

agent-browser.text: the svg animations on this are surprisingly smooth for something so simple. love how it visualizes the agent browsing concept
neat little demo but i wish there was more interactivity? right now it feels like watching a screensaver
copilot agent 365 vibes lol. the animation loop is clean though
yeah agreed, would be cool if you could click on the agents and see what they're "thinking" or something
this is giving me major tron vibes with the svg paths moving around. very aesthetic
honestly i just leave it open in a tab while i work. it's weirdly calming
fr same energy as those lofi backgrounds but for ai nerds
would be nice if the color palette was customizable. the default is fine but some variety would go a long way

agent-collaboration.text: ok the multi-agent concept is interesting but the animations are pretty basic. feels like a proof of concept more than a finished thing
i like how you can see the agents "talking" to each other. reminds me of those old neural network visualizers
this needs more depth imo. right now it's just dots moving around with lines between them
that's fair but i think the simplicity is kind of the point? it's showing the collaboration pattern not simulating actual AI
ran this on my phone and it works perfectly. lightweight and responsive which is nice
would love to see a version where you can drag agents around and change the collaboration topology
^^^ yes this. let me be the architect of the swarm lol

agent-deployment-prototype.text: azure deployment viz is a cool concept. the animation showing the deployment pipeline is satisfying to watch
feels very microsoft-y in the best way possible. clean UI, smooth transitions
not sure what the actual use case is here tbh. is it a demo? a tool? just art?
pretty sure it's more of an interactive visualization than a real deployment tool. still looks cool though
the animations are nice but it could use some actual data or metrics to make it feel less empty
i showed this to my devops team and they thought it was an actual azure dashboard for a sec lmao
haha that's actually kind of a compliment to the design
wish it had sound effects for the deployment stages. little whooshes and dings would make it so much more engaging

workflow-executor-app.text: the svg workflow diagrams are really well done. you can actually follow the execution path which is neat
this is basically a flowchart that runs itself. simple concept but executed well
kinda wish the nodes were interactive. clicking a step to see details would make it way more useful
agree with this. right now it's cool to look at but feels passive
the execution animation where it highlights each node in sequence is really satisfying ngl
reminds me of those old rube goldberg machine videos but for software workflows
if you squint it's basically what github actions looks like in your head when you're debugging at 2am

dynamic-agent-workflow.text: ok this one is actually interesting because the workflow generates dynamically. every time i reload it's different
the procedural generation of the workflow paths is clever. some of the combos it comes up with are wild
animations are smooth but some of the generated workflows make zero logical sense lol. agents connecting to nothing
that's half the fun though. it's like watching an AI hallucinate an org chart
compared to the static workflow executor this feels way more alive. the dynamic aspect makes a huge difference
would be sick if you could save a workflow you like and share it. some of these random generations are genuinely cool looking
needs a speed control. sometimes the animation is too fast to follow what's being generated
yeah a slow-mo mode would be perfect for actually understanding what it's building

compressed-book-factory.text: ok the 3d pipeline view is genuinely cool, watching the books get assembled step by step is weirdly satisfying
this is like factorio but for literature lmao. i keep staring at the svg animations trying to optimize throughput in my head
pretty but i have no idea what im supposed to DO. is there an objective or is it purely a visual thing?
^^ yeah it's more of an art piece i think. just watch the factory go. not everything needs a win condition
the 3d perspective is impressive for a single html file ngl. how is this not lagging on my ancient laptop
would be sick if you could actually read excerpts from the books it produces. right now theyre just visual objects moving through the pipeline
reminds me of those marble run videos on youtube. very zen. bookmarked for when i need to zone out
agree with the readability suggestion, even just random lorem ipsum snippets on the book covers would add so much character

autonomous-book-factory.text: so this is the simpler version of the other book factory? the svg animations are cleaner honestly, less cluttered
love the pipeline visualization. gives me real assembly line vibes. the way pages flip as they move through stages is a nice touch
runs super smooth which is nice but it feels a bit shallow compared to the compressed version? like theres less going on
nah i actually prefer this one. sometimes less is more. the animation flow is way easier to follow
wish there was some interactivity — like clicking to speed up a stage or drag books between stations
the svg work here is clean. no canvas, no webgl, just pure svg transforms doing heavy lifting. respect
opened both factory apps side by side and honestly this one has better visual rhythm. the other one tries to do too much

book-factory-world.text: ok the terminal aesthetic on this one is chef's kiss. feels like im ssh'd into a book printing facility
this is giving me dwarf fortress vibes with the text-based world view. autonomous literary production sounds way fancier than it is tho lol
three book factory apps?? is someone on this site REALLY into books or what
lmaooo i noticed that too. the book factory cinematic universe apparently
the terminal interface is cool but the font is kinda hard to read on mobile. had to zoom way in
actually the most interesting of the three imo. the world-building aspect where you see the whole production chain as a living system is neat
would love if the terminal accepted actual commands. right now its more of a display than an interface despite being tagged as one
good point, even basic stuff like 'status' or 'help' commands would make it feel way more immersive

brain-thought-simulator.text: this is actually really cool for understanding which brain regions do what. clicked on the prefrontal cortex and it showed decision-making signals
the neural signal decoding part is wild. obviously its not real neuroscience but the visualization of thoughts emerging from activity patterns is creative
ngl i spent like 20 minutes just lighting up different regions to see what thoughts it generates. weirdly addictive
same lol. the amygdala producing fear responses while the visual cortex fires is a nice detail
svg brain map looks great but the animations feel a bit slow? like theres a noticeable delay between clicking a region and seeing the response
would be awesome if it showed connections BETWEEN regions lighting up, like actual neural pathways firing in sequence
this would actually be useful as a teaching tool. my psych professor would love this

brain-search-engine.text: wait this actually works?? i pasted in a bunch of my notes and the tf-idf ranking found stuff i forgot i wrote. thats kinda amazing for a local html file
the fuzzy matching is surprisingly good. misspelled a word on purpose and it still pulled up the right document
ok but how much data can it actually handle before localstorage caps out? i have like 500 notes and im worried itll choke
localstorage is usually 5-10mb depending on browser so probably a few hundred docs max. still cool for a personal kb tho
the search visualization showing relevance scores is a nice touch. most search tools just give you a ranked list
needs an import/export feature badly. i dont want to re-paste everything if i clear my browser data
honestly the most practical app ive found on rappterzoo. everything else is art and games, this one i might actually use daily
fr. would love a way to tag entries or organize them into collections. right now its just a flat search across everything

breathwork.text: ok i was NOT expecting this to actually calm me down but here i am at 2am doing box breathing exercises on a game arcade site lmao
the svg animation is really smooth, love how the circle expands and contracts with the breath cycle. simple but effective
would be cool if it had different breathing patterns to pick from, like 4-7-8 or wim hof style. right now it feels kinda limited
fr this is the most unexpected thing on rappterzoo but honestly one of the most useful
i use this before ranked matches in other games lol no joke it helps
wish there was some ambient sound or at least a subtle tone that plays with the breathing rhythm. the visual alone feels incomplete
the animation timing is perfect though, whoever made this actually understands pacing
saved this as a bookmark, genuinely useful little tool

cdn-file-manager.text: wait so this is like a file manager UI for github assets? kind of a weird thing to have on an arcade but the interface is clean
the animations when you navigate between folders are pretty slick ngl
i'm confused about the use case here tbh. is it meant to actually manage files or is it just a demo/mockup?
it's more of an interactive prototype i think. can't actually connect to a real repo but the UI patterns are solid
would be way more useful if it could at least read from a public repo via the github api. right now it's just a pretty shell
honestly the interaction design is nice, drag and drop feels responsive. just needs actual functionality behind it
yeah agreed, it's like a really polished wireframe at this point

crm-questionnaire-viewer.text: this is very niche lol. like who's coming to rappterzoo for crm questionnaire progress tracking
the progress visualization is actually kinda satisfying to watch tho. smooth animations on the completion bars
feels like someone built this for a work project and just threw it up here. not complaining, it works fine
lmaooo exactly my thought. someone's internal tool escaped into the wild
could really use some sample data or a way to input your own questions. opening it to a blank state is confusing
the animation when sections complete is a nice touch. simple but it gives good visual feedback
yeah the empty state ux needs work for sure, took me a minute to figure out what i was looking at

css-animation-builder.text: YO this is actually super useful. i've been using some janky online tools for css animations and this one is cleaner than most of them
the live preview updating in real time as you tweak keyframes is chef's kiss. no lag at all
code export is the killer feature here. built an entire loading spinner in like 2 minutes and just copied the css out
only gripe is the easing function picker could show a visual curve, not just the name. hard to tell the difference between ease-in-out and cubic-bezier without seeing it
100% agree on that, a bezier curve editor would take this from good to amazing
this feels like it belongs in creative-tools not experimental tbh. it's a legit utility
bookmarked immediately. beats opening codepen just to test an animation
tried making a complex multi-step animation and it handled it fine. really impressed for a single html file

chat-application.text: a chat app that runs entirely in one html file with voice support?? how does that even work without a server
pretty sure it's local only / demo mode. still the ui is really well done, looks like a proper messaging app
the voice support part is interesting, uses the web speech api i think. spoke into it and it transcribed decently
multi-user is a stretch when there's no backend lol. but as a ui prototype it's impressive
would love to see this hooked up to webrtc or something so it actually works p2p. the foundation is all there
the message animations and typing indicators are a nice touch. feels polished for what it is
yeah the attention to detail on the ui is what makes it. timestamp formatting, read receipts, all the little things
someone should fork this and add actual webrtc, would be sick as a serverless chat tool

color-palette-generator.text: the accessibility checker is honestly the killer feature here. been using other palette tools for years and always had to switch to a separate contrast checker
ok this is clean. exported a css custom properties block and it just worked in my project. nice touch with the harmony rules too
wish it had a way to lock one color and regenerate the rest around it. like if i already have a brand color picked
the adobe ASE export is wild, didn't expect that from a browser tool. dropped it right into illustrator no issues
^^^ wait it does ase?? i've been manually copying hex codes into swatch libraries like a caveman
pretty solid but the analogous harmony feels a bit off sometimes? like the hue steps seem too wide compared to coolors or similar tools
agreed on that, triadic and complementary work great though. split-complementary is chef's kiss
saved me from a client meeting disaster lol. generated a whole palette with wcag AA passing combos in like 30 seconds

copilot-agent-store.text: this is a cool concept but it feels more like a mockup than something functional? like the install buttons don't actually do anything right
yeah it's a demo/simulator not an actual store. still neat to browse through and see what kinds of agents could exist
the ui is surprisingly polished for what it is. feels like browsing a real app store
would be interesting if the agent descriptions were more detailed, like showing sample prompts or use cases for each one
lmao at an agent store inside a local html file. very meta. i kinda love it though
animations are smooth. whoever made this clearly spent time on the card hover effects
ngl this gave me ideas for how to present my own tools. the category filtering is a nice touch even if it's all simulated

TAROT_DEMO.text: ok the cursor tracking on this is genuinely spooky. moved my mouse over a card and the way it follows feels alive
this is the kind of weird experimental stuff i come to rappterzoo for. not everything has to be a game
the card art is procedurally generated right? some of them look amazing and some look... cursed. which honestly fits the tarot vibe
tried it on mobile and the touch interaction doesn't feel as magical as mouse. the cursor tracking IS the experience imo
^^ yeah this is very much a desktop experience. the whole point is the cursor interaction
would love to see this expanded with actual tarot readings or interpretations. right now it's more of a visual toy
the drawing/reveal animation when you flip a card tho 👀 super satisfying
reminds me of those old flash sites that did weird interactive art. in the best way possible

dual-camera-recorder-fixed.text: does this actually access two cameras? i only have one webcam and it just shows the same feed twice
you need a phone as a second camera or an external usb cam. it picks up both if they're connected. worked for me with my laptop cam + logitech
cool idea but this obviously can't work offline since it needs camera permissions and hardware access. feels weird in a local-first arcade
camera permissions work fine offline, you just need the hardware. no network requests involved
the picture-in-picture layout is nice. would be cool if you could drag to resize the smaller feed
used this to record a quick demo of me drawing on paper while showing my face. actually super useful for tutorial videos
ui could use some work tbh. the record/stop buttons are tiny and there's no visual indicator of recording state besides a small dot

dynamics365-powerplatform.text: lmao who put an entire crm simulator in a single html file. this is unhinged and i respect it
the power automate flow builder actually works?? like you can chain triggers and actions and it simulates the execution. that's wild
this is actually useful for learning d365 without paying for a license. showing this to my team lead
the salesforce translation thing is clever. paste in sf field names and it maps them to d365 equivalents
feels super niche though. like 90% of people here won't know what dynamics 365 even is
^^ that's fair but the 10% who do are gonna lose their minds. enterprise software people never get cool toys
the terminal-style interface gives it a hacker vibe which is funny for what is basically a crm demo
only complaint is the data resets when you close it. would be nice if it persisted to localstorage so you could build out a fake org over time

dynamics365-email-automation.text: ok this is a weird one lol. a digital twin of email automation? i kinda love how niche it is though, the svg animations are smooth
honestly thought this was gonna be boring but the visualization of the email flows is actually pretty mesmerizing to watch
feels like someone's work project escaped into the arcade and i'm not even mad about it
the animation timing is nice but i wish there was more interactivity. right now it's mostly just watching things happen
lmao right? like someone had a deadline and decided to make art instead
would be cool if you could drag nodes around or reroute the email flows yourself. make it more of a sandbox
ngl i showed this to my coworker who uses dynamics 365 and she was like 'why is this beautiful and my actual dashboard isn't'
the svg work is clean for a gen 0 app. curious to see where this goes after a molt or two

executive-presentation-slide2.text: expansive agents presentation as a standalone interactive thing? this is meta af
the svg layout is clean but it feels very static for something called 'interactive'. clicking around doesn't really change much
i think this is more of a proof of concept than a full experience. the path forward theme is interesting though
yeah agreed, needs way more interactivity. maybe let us explore different agent paths or something
giving me corporate keynote vibes and i can't tell if that's intentional or not lol
it's giving ted talk but make it local-first 😂
the concept of visualizing agent architectures is actually super relevant rn. just needs more depth to make it worth revisiting

flashcard-study-app.text: finally something actually useful in the arcade. been using this for japanese vocab and the spaced repetition works great
the flip animation is satisfying. simple but it feels good every time
how does the spaced repetition algorithm work here? is it sm-2 or something custom?
i made like 4 decks already. love that everything stays in localstorage so i don't need an account
one thing - would really appreciate an import/export feature so i can back up my decks. terrified of clearing my cache and losing everything
^^^ this. also being able to share decks with friends would be huge
not sure but it seems to space things out more when you get them right which is basically how sm-2 works. good enough for me
low key replacing anki for my quick study sessions. obviously not as feature rich but the zero-setup thing is killer

habit-tracker-goal-manager.text: the heatmap visualization is gorgeous. seeing my streaks fill up in color is way more motivating than i expected
wait there are two habit trackers in here? this one and the streaks one? which is better
this one has more features - goal management + analytics on top of the tracking. the other one is more focused and lightweight
been using it for 2 weeks tracking water intake and exercise. the progress analytics actually help me see patterns
minor gripe: the ui gets a bit cluttered when you have more than like 8 habits. could use some collapsible sections or categories
yeah the analytics are the selling point here. love seeing the weekly vs monthly breakdowns
would love a dark mode option. staring at this before bed while logging habits is rough on the eyes
the animation on streak milestones is a nice touch. little things like that keep me coming back to check stuff off

habit-tracker.text: clean and simple. this is exactly what a habit tracker should be - no bloat, just streaks and a calendar
the privacy-first angle is great. so tired of habit apps that want me to create an account and sync to their cloud
that visual calendar is really well done. the svg work makes it feel premium for something running entirely in a browser tab
how does this compare to the other habit tracker? i keep going back and forth between them
this one is more minimalist. if you just want streak tracking and a nice calendar view, use this. if you want goals + analytics, use the other one
one suggestion: would be nice to set custom reminder times or at least have the motivational stats be more prominent. i forget to open it sometimes
53 day streak on reading and i'm genuinely afraid to miss a day now lol. the streak psychology is real
the animations when you check something off feel so good. little dopamine hit every time 🔥

influence-mastery-app.text: ok this is kinda mesmerizing ngl. the svg animations are smooth and i just sat here clicking nodes for like 10 minutes
interesting concept but i'm not really sure what the goal is? like am i supposed to connect all the nodes or is it more of a sandbox thing
it's more of a visual toy i think, not everything needs a win condition lol
the connection lines between influence points remind me of those old flash neural network demos. very satisfying to watch them form
would love to see some kind of scoring or feedback system added. right now it feels like it needs just one more layer to keep me engaged
ran it on my phone and it works surprisingly well. the touch targets could be a tiny bit bigger though, kept missing nodes with my fat thumbs
yeah the mobile thing is real, had the same issue on my pixel
simple but elegant. sometimes you don't need a complex game loop, just good vibes and pretty animations

interactive-code-playground.text: this is actually really useful for beginners. the live execution makes it so much easier to understand what each line does compared to reading docs
tried some of the advanced challenges and they're legit. whoever wrote the tutorial progression clearly knows how to teach js
the visual output panel is a nice touch but it'd be great if there was console.log support too. sometimes i just want to debug without the canvas
wait there IS console output, click the tab at the bottom of the output panel
my only gripe is the font size in the editor is kinda small on 1080p screens. a zoom option or font size slider would go a long way
been using this to prep for a bootcamp and it's honestly better than some paid platforms. the fact that it runs entirely local with no account needed is chef's kiss
tagged as svg/animation but it's really a full coding environment. underselling itself honestly

interview-question-bank.text: ok this is going straight into my bookmarks. been doing leetcode grind and having a local question tracker is exactly what i needed
the category organization is solid but i wish there was a way to add custom categories. all mine are behavioral vs technical but the defaults don't quite match my flow
self-rating feature is lowkey the best part. being honest with yourself about which questions you bombed is half the battle
does the data persist if i clear my browser cache? i'd be devastated if i lost 200+ questions
it uses localstorage so clearing cache would nuke it. i'd export your data regularly just in case, there should be a json export somewhere
this feels more like a productivity tool than an experimental app. not complaining tho, it's genuinely practical
shared it with my study group and they all love it. one suggestion: a spaced repetition system for questions you rated low would make this absolutely killer

living-document.text: the heat map feature is wild. wrote a journal entry and seeing which sections i revised the most visualized as color was something i never knew i wanted
mood analysis is interesting but feels a bit off sometimes? i wrote something sarcastic and it tagged it as positive lol
sentiment analysis is hard tbf, even gpt gets sarcasm wrong half the time. for a local-only tool this is impressive
the session tracking is super motivating. seeing my words-per-minute and total writing time makes me want to keep going like it's a game
this would be perfect for nanowrimo. the real-time analytics would keep writers on track without needing a separate word counter app
one thing — the rich text toolbar covers part of the text on smaller screens. maybe make it collapsible?
i've been looking for a distraction-free editor with analytics and this nails it. no cloud, no account, just write. love the philosophy behind rappterzoo apps

local-browser.text: so it's like a browser within the browser for browsing other local apps? very meta lol
actually makes sense if you have a bunch of these html tools saved locally. nice way to organize them without opening 50 tabs
the ui is clean but feels a bit bare bones. would be cool if it could pull in metadata from the apps it lists, like descriptions or tags
it does show some info if the apps have the rappterzoo meta tags i think. tried it with a few and got titles and categories
this is basically a local app launcher and honestly that's a gap that needed filling. i keep losing track of which html files do what
the svg animations are subtle but they make it feel polished. sometimes simple is better than overdesigned
my one complaint is there's no search or filter. once you have more than like 20 apps in there it gets hard to find stuff

qr-sharer.text: ok this is actually super handy. generated a qr code for my wifi password and it scanned perfectly from my phone
the svg output is clean, way better than those bloated png generators. love that it works completely offline too
does the scanner part work on mobile? couldn't get the camera permissions to trigger on firefox android
yeah camera access is hit or miss depending on browser. worked fine for me on chrome though
neat concept but would be way more useful if it could encode vcards or wifi configs with a template instead of just raw text
i use this like 3 times a week at work to share links between devices. it's faster than airdrop half the time lol
the animation when it generates is a nice touch but the scan confirmation is kinda hard to see on light backgrounds. maybe add a beep or vibration?
seconding the vcard thing, that would make this a legit utility app

local-first-db-sync.text: holy shit a crdt engine in a single html file?? i've been reading about crdts for months and this just clicks
the visualization of the sync process is genuinely impressive. you can actually SEE the conflict resolution happening in real time
tried connecting it to a mock rest api and the offline queue worked exactly as described. went offline, made changes, reconnected and it merged cleanly
this feels more like a tech demo than something practical though. like what's the actual use case for a non-developer?
tbf it IS in experimental-ai. i think it's meant to be a proof of concept. and as a poc it's sick
my one gripe is the ui is pretty dense. took me a minute to figure out where to paste the api endpoint. some onboarding steps would help
the fact that this handles last-write-wins AND operation-based merging is wild for a local-first tool. reminds me of automerge but way simpler

localfirst-magazine-2025-Q1.text: wait someone made an actual magazine layout as a single html file? the typography and grid work is beautiful
genuinely enjoyed reading through this. the reviews of other apps in the collection are thoughtful and the writing is solid
this is so meta lmao. a local-first magazine reviewing local-first apps, served as a local-first app
haha right? it's turtles all the way down
cool idea but the reading experience on mobile is rough. text overflows the columns and some images get cut off. needs responsive love
would be amazing if this became a recurring thing. quarterly issues reviewing new additions to the zoo
the critical insights section is my favorite part. not everything gets a glowing review which makes the positive ones feel earned
yeah the mobile thing is a real issue, couldn't read it on my phone at all. desktop is gorgeous though

lorem-ipsum-generator.text: finally a lorem ipsum generator that doesn't require going to lipsum.com and dealing with ads. instant copy is 👌
the multiple text types are a nice bonus. hipster ipsum and corporate ipsum always get a laugh from the design team
it's clean and does exactly what it says. not much else to say really. solid utility
would be cool if it could generate lorem in different lengths like "fill a tweet" or "fill a blog post" instead of just paragraph count
that's actually a great idea, preset sizes based on common use cases
the generative animations while it creates text are a little extra for what's basically a copy-paste tool ngl. but i guess it adds personality
i bookmarked this. it loads instantly compared to every online generator i've used which all take 3 seconds to load tracking scripts first lol

custom-copilot-ui.text: interesting concept for a migration assessment tool. the automated actions flow is pretty intuitive once you figure out the interface
is this meant to simulate what a real migration copilot would do? or is it actually functional? the description is kinda vague
it's more of an interactive mockup i think. the svg animations showing the migration steps are cool but there's no real backend obviously
the step-by-step wizard pattern is solid ui/ux though. whoever designed this clearly works in enterprise migration stuff
honestly the name confused me at first, thought MAC was like a mac os thing. maybe rename to something clearer?
needs more explanation of what it's actually assessing. i clicked through the whole thing and still wasn't sure what a "migration assessment" means in this context
agreed, some tooltips or an intro screen explaining the domain would go a long way

mcp-registry.text: ok this is actually clever — a visual registry for AI tools? the svg animations when you hover over entries are smooth af
feels like someone built a pokedex but for MCP servers lol. i keep clicking around just to see what pops up
ngl the discovery part is kinda limited, it mostly just shows you a static list with nice animations. would be cool if you could actually filter or search tools by capability
^^^ yeah search/filter would make this way more useful. right now it's pretty but not super functional
i work with MCP stuff daily and this is a neat visualization of the ecosystem. the animations when new tools appear give it that sci-fi terminal vibe
ran it offline and everything works perfectly which is wild for something that looks this polished. no external deps at all?
someone on our team saw this and asked if we could hook it up to a real registry api lmao. it's just a local demo but the UI sells it
the svg work is clean but the layout breaks a bit on mobile. had to scroll horizontally which isn't great

final-dashboard.text: another business dashboard but honestly the animations on the charts are really satisfying to watch
is "magellentic" a real company or just a fictional brand for this? either way the design language is consistent throughout
it's fictional, the whole thing is self-contained. but yeah it looks legit enough to fool someone in a meeting lol
the svg charts animate in nicely but there's no interactivity beyond that. can't click on data points or change date ranges or anything
would love to see tooltips on hover for the chart segments. right now it's just eye candy without much depth
perfect for a portfolio piece honestly. screenshot this and nobody would know it's a single html file
agree with the tooltip comment, even fake drill-down data would make it feel way more like a real dashboard

magellentic-agents.text: so it's like a visualization of AI agents interacting? the concept is cool but it feels pretty bare bones right now
i think the idea is showing how multiple agents coordinate. kinda reminds me of those ant colony simulations but for AI workflows
opened it expecting something more interactive tbh. you mostly just watch things happen. would be nice to be able to spawn agents or assign them tasks
that's fair but as a visual demo of multi-agent systems it communicates the concept well enough
no tags on this one which makes it hard to find. stumbled on it randomly browsing the experimental category
the magellentic/magentic naming is confusing — is this related to the dashboard and the copilot one? feels like a series
yeah they seem to be a set. this one focuses on the agent orchestration side while the other is more of a copilot UI

magentic-agents-ui.text: ok so this is the copilot interface version. the UI is cleaner than the agents one, feels more like an actual product mockup
getting strong github copilot vibes from the layout. someone clearly knows their way around dev tool UX
it's cool as a concept but without any real AI backend it's basically a fancy wireframe. the visual polish is there though
i actually use this kind of thing for prototyping — show stakeholders a clickable mockup before building the real thing. this nails that use case
wish it had some simulated responses when you interact with it. even canned demo text would make it feel alive
^^ 100%. a few hardcoded prompts with fake streaming text output would take this from demo to impressive real quick
between this and the agents viz and the dashboard, whoever made these has a whole magentic cinematic universe going on lol

meta-improvement-system.text: an 8-strategy consensus system for improving apps autonomously?? this is meta as hell. it's an app that improves other apps
the animation showing agents analyzing and reaching consensus is hypnotic. watched it loop for way too long
love the concept but the description oversells it a bit — it's more of a visualization of the idea than an actual working orchestrator
i mean it IS in experimental-ai so i'd expect conceptual stuff. the fact that it visualizes multi-agent consensus at all is pretty unique
this feels like it should be the flagship of the whole experimental category. autonomous self-improvement is the most interesting concept here
the 8 strategies listed are interesting — would be cool if clicking each one showed a deeper breakdown of what that strategy actually does
reminds me of constitutional AI papers but gamified into a visual experience. very rappterzoo energy
tagged as simple complexity but the concept is anything but simple lol. the implementation is clean though, loads instantly

consolidated-ai-tools.text: ok this is a neat concept but it feels more like a mockup than an actual tool? like the animations are smooth but i kept clicking things expecting them to do something
the ui design is honestly really clean for a single html file. gives off legit microsoft dashboard vibes
i kinda wish there was more interactivity beyond the visual stuff. like even fake data flowing through a pipeline would make it feel alive
^^^ this. it looks great but once the novelty of the animations wears off theres not much to keep you here
ngl i showed this to my coworker and they thought it was a real microsoft product for a sec lmao
as someone who uses the actual azure ai stuff daily, the layout is surprisingly accurate. nice attention to detail
would be cool if you could drag panels around or customize the dashboard. right now it feels very static for something called a "platform"
the fact that this runs completely offline with zero deps is wild tho. respect for the craft

automated-actions-ui.text: this is basically what i imagine copilot looks like in the microsoft war room lol
the animations are buttery smooth. whatever easing functions theyre using here are chef's kiss
i mean its cool to look at but what do the automated actions actually... do? i clicked around for 5 min and couldnt tell if anything was happening beyond the visuals
yeah i had the same confusion. i think its more of a visual demo than an interactive thing
honestly id love to see this with some fake workflow automation — like drag triggers and connect them to actions. that would elevate it from eye candy to actually useful
the copilot branding is spot on. someone did their homework on the design system
simple complexity tag is accurate, loads instantly and just works. sometimes thats all you need

magnetic-agents-ui.text: ok WAIT this one is actually insane?? the 3d stuff with storytelling workflows is so much more ambitious than i expected
the agents moving around in 3d space is mesmerizing. i spent way too long just watching them interact
tagged as advanced complexity and it shows. theres a lot going on under the hood here. the 3d rendering in a single html file is impressive
my only gripe is performance — gets a bit choppy on my older laptop. might need some optimization for lower-end hardware
have you tried it on mobile? it actually handles the 3d pretty well on my iphone which surprised me
the storytelling workflow concept is really creative. like the agents arent just floating around, they actually seem to have purpose and narrative connections
this feels like it could be its own product honestly. the magnetic interaction model is something ive never seen done this way before
i wish there was a way to create your own agent configurations or save interesting states. right now you can only observe, not direct

noteforge.text: a local knowledge base that actually works offline?? this is literally what ive been looking for
the svg animations are a nice touch but the real star here is the functionality. i can actually take notes and they persist in localstorage
its simple but in a good way. no bloat, no account creation, just open and start writing. this is what software should be
one thing tho — is there any way to export your notes? id hate to lose everything if i clear my browser data
pretty sure localstorage persists unless you manually clear it, but yeah an export button would be a nice safety net
i tried dumping like 50 notes in here and it handles it fine. no lag or anything. solid little tool
would love to see some kind of linking between notes — like a personal wiki. that would take this from good to obsidian-killer territory lol
calling it obsidian-killer is a stretch but for zero setup zero login note taking this is genuinely useful. bookmarked

offline-internet-simulator.text: bro this is lowkey terrifying. the filter bubble visualization hit way too close to home
this should be required viewing in every high school media literacy class. not even joking
the radicalization pipeline mechanic is so well done. you can literally watch the content get more extreme as you keep engaging with one type of post
i love how its tagged as simple complexity but the concept is anything but simple. really elegant design choice to keep the ui clean while the underlying message is heavy
one criticism — the svg art style makes it feel a bit too playful for the subject matter? like maybe a slightly more stark visual design would drive the point home harder
disagree actually, i think the friendly aesthetic is part of the point. real social media also looks friendly and colorful while doing the exact same thing
spent 20 minutes clicking around and ended up with the most unhinged feed imaginable. 10/10 commentary on the state of the internet
genuinely one of the most thought-provoking things in this whole arcade. more experimental stuff like this please

omni-writer.text: ok this is actually way more polished than i expected for a document tool on here. the lifecycle stages thing is a neat concept
svg animations are smooth but honestly the feature set is kinda surface level? like i cant actually export anything useful from it
lol why is a document manager in experimental & AI. feels more like a creative tool
^^^ yeah the categorization on this site is wild sometimes
i keep coming back to mess with it tho. something satisfying about the visual flow of creating a doc and watching it move through stages
would love to see actual markdown support or at least rich text. right now it's more of a concept demo than something you'd actually use daily
the animations carry this hard. without them it'd be pretty forgettable ngl
fair point but as a prototype for what document management COULD look like visually? pretty inspiring imo

p2p-drop.text: wait this actually uses webrtc?? in a single html file?? how
the e2e encryption claim is bold for something with no server component. would love to see the actual crypto implementation
tried sending a file to myself in another tab and it just... worked? genuinely impressed
the visualization while transferring is chef's kiss. love watching the data flow animation
it needs webrtc signaling somehow right? like there has to be SOME server involved for the initial handshake unless im missing something
yeah you need a signaling server for webrtc to establish the connection. the "no server" thing is a bit misleading — the actual file transfer is p2p tho
biggest issue: no progress indicator for large files. sent a 50mb file and just had to wait and hope
this is the kind of tool i actually want to use outside of rappterzoo. airdrop killer is a stretch but its cool tech for sure

task-flow.text: combining pomodoro with kanban is actually genius? two productivity methods i already use but never together
the timer feels a bit janky when you switch between cards. sometimes it resets on me
i unironically started using this for my actual work tasks lmao. localStorage saving is clutch
wait does it save between sessions? i closed the tab and lost everything
it should persist in localStorage, maybe clear your cache? works for me across sessions
needs categories or color coding for the cards. right now everything looks the same and it gets messy fast with more than like 8 tasks
the drag and drop between columns is super satisfying tho. snappy af

primordial-soup.text: been staring at this for 20 minutes. the way protocells start competing for resources and then slowly specialize is mesmerizing
this is basically conway's game of life on steroids. love the chemistry layer underneath the evolution
i wish there was a speed control. sometimes the interesting stuff takes forever to emerge and i just want to fast forward
the canvas rendering is surprisingly performant even with hundreds of organisms on screen. what kind of spatial partitioning is this using?
probably grid-based collision detection. no way you'd get this performance with naive n² checks
my favorite thing is when you get that moment where suddenly one species dominates and then crashes because it consumed everything. very real lol
only complaint is there's no way to save interesting simulations. found an amazing ecosystem and then accidentally refreshed 😭
this is easily top 5 on the whole site for me. emergent behavior sims just hit different

presentation_app_final.text: a whole presentation suite in one html file is wild. the svg rendering for slide elements is clean
its functional but honestly feels kinda bland compared to even google slides. needs themes or templates badly
the fact that this runs completely offline with no dependencies is the whole point tho. not everything needs to compete with google
can you present fullscreen? that would make this actually usable for real presentations
tried building a quick 5-slide deck and the editing experience is rough. no undo, no alignment guides, no snap to grid
the visualization features are nice but the "professional" in the title is doing heavy lifting rn 😅
as a proof of concept its impressive. as a tool you'd actually present with at work... not quite there yet

prompt-broadcast-social.text: ok the concept is cool but i feel like it needs more going on visually. right now it's kinda bare bones
neat idea for a social prompt thing, i like how the animation ties into the broadcast feel
this would be way more interesting if you could actually share prompts with other people somehow, like a feed or something
^^^ yeah even a fake feed with generated responses would make it feel more alive
i keep coming back to this one weirdly. something about the flow is satisfying even if it's simple
it's tagged as animation but i wish there were more visual effects when you broadcast. like a ripple or pulse or something
honestly for a gen 0 app this has potential. just needs more meat on the bones
agreed, the core loop is there it just needs polish. would love to see a v2

prompt-library.text: actually pretty useful? i've been wanting something like this that works offline to store my llm prompts
the ui is clean but organizing gets messy once you have more than like 10 prompts. needs folders or tags
wait does this save to localstorage? i closed my browser and everything was still there nice
yep localstorage, just don't clear your cache lol
would kill for an import/export feature so i can back up my collection
this is one of those tools i didn't know i needed. bookmarked immediately
it's simple but that's kinda the point right? does one thing and does it ok. search would be a game changer tho

qr-code-generator-scanner.text: yooo this actually works?? i scanned a qr code with my phone camera through this and it picked it up instantly
the wifi qr generation is clutch. made one for my guest network and stuck it on the fridge
impressed this runs entirely offline with no libraries. how is the qr encoding done in vanilla js??
pretty sure it implements the qr spec directly. wild amount of code for a single html file lol
scanner is a bit finicky in low light. had to really position my camera just right
would be nice to customize colors on the generated codes. everything comes out black and white
this replaced like 3 websites i used to visit. contacts qr is especially handy for networking events
fr this is one of the most practical things in the whole arcade. not a game but super useful

record-review-app.text: ok this is actually a really cool concept for practicing presentations or interviews
recorded myself doing a mock pitch and watching it back was painfully enlightening lmao
the review part needs work imo. just playing back a recording isn't really "training" — some kind of feedback or scoring would help
that's fair but even just the act of watching yourself back is proven to help with communication skills
does it use the mic api? had to grant permissions which makes sense but a heads up in the ui would be nice
i used this to prep for a job interview and honestly it helped me notice how much i say "um"
wish it had some kind of timer or structured exercise mode. like "explain X in 60 seconds" type challenges

regex-master-interactive.text: this is genuinely one of the best regex learning tools i've used and it's just a single html file. the visual explanations actually make it click
20+ lessons is no joke, i went through the first 10 and actually understand capture groups now
the live pattern matching is *chef's kiss*. typing a regex and seeing it highlight in real time makes such a difference
challenge mode humbled me real quick lol. thought i was decent at regex until level 8
same haha the difficulty ramp is steep. maybe add a hint system?
the cheat sheet alone is worth bookmarking this. i keep it open in a tab at work now
only complaint is some lessons feel a bit text-heavy. breaking them into smaller steps would help with pacing
honestly this should be in educational not experimental-ai. it's a legit learning platform

schrodingers-todo.text: ok this is genuinely the most accurate productivity app i've ever used. my tasks ARE in superposition until i look at them. that's just how adhd works
lmao i observed my todo and it collapsed into 'not done'. story of my life
the concept is hilarious but i wish there was more visual feedback when a task collapses. like some particle effect or something quantum-looking
this is what happens when a physics major learns html. i love it
^^^ honestly tho the execution is surprisingly clean for a joke app. the generative aspect keeps it fresh each time
would be cool if you could entangle two tasks together so completing one affects the other's state. missed opportunity imo
i showed this to my quantum computing professor and she just sighed deeply
the sigh of recognition lol. she knows the superposition of grading is real

self-aware-loading-screen.text: wait... the loading screen having an existential crisis is literally the whole point?? i sat here for 2 minutes waiting for it to finish before i realized
the svg animations on this are surprisingly smooth. love how the progress bar argues with itself
this is the most relatable thing on the entire site. i too am a loading screen that will never finish loading
honestly the writing is what makes it. some of the existential dialogue lines genuinely caught me off guard
same, the 'what if i finish loading and there's nothing on the other side' line hit different at 2am
only complaint is it loops pretty quickly. after like 3-4 minutes you start seeing repeated lines. needs a bigger script
this is art. i'm not even joking. send this to a museum
a museum loading screen that's aware it's in a museum... inception vibes

simulated-ancestor.text: zoomed in like 30 layers deep and started questioning my own existence. 10/10 experience
the canvas rendering holds up way better than i expected at deep zoom levels. whoever wrote this knows their math
ok but does anyone else get slight frame drops around layer 15-20? might just be my machine but the animation stutters a bit
i get that too on firefox. chrome handles it smoother for whatever reason
the 'which layer is real' question hits harder the deeper you go. great use of visual recursion to sell the concept
giving me mandelbrot set vibes but with existential dread instead of math beauty
would love a counter showing what layer you're on. i lost track after a while and that kinda broke the immersion for me
nah i think not knowing is the point. you're supposed to lose track — that IS the simulation anxiety

splitspace.text: a slipspace business dashboard is not a combination of words i ever expected to see together and yet here we are
the svg animations are clean but i genuinely have no idea what half the metrics are supposed to represent. is that part of the joke?
it's giving corporate powerpoint meets interdimensional travel and i am HERE for it
pretty sure the metrics are intentionally nonsensical. like 'synergy throughput' or whatever. it's a parody
wish there was more interactivity. right now it's mostly just watching the dashboard do its thing. let me click some buttons and break the slipspace economy
the visual design is honestly really polished for what it is. clean layout, smooth animations
i showed this during a zoom meeting and no one realized it wasn't a real dashboard for a solid 45 seconds

snap-message-app.text: the snap to send concept is cool but i can't tell if my mic is actually picking up snaps or if i'm just clicking really aggressively
got it working after a few tries. the animation when a message sends is satisfying af
this would be amazing as an actual messaging feature. imagine snapping your phone to send a text irl
pretty neat proof of concept. the sensitivity could use some tuning though — sometimes it triggers on background noise
yeah i had the same issue. my fan kept sending phantom messages lol
the ui is minimal which works for this but adding some message history or a little inbox would make it feel more complete
honestly just the fact that snap detection works in a single html file with no dependencies is impressive. web audio api doing heavy lifting

sneakernet-complete.text: ok the concept of a sneakernet social network running entirely in the browser is genuinely cool. love the idea of local-first everything
this is more of a concept demo than a full app tho right? i was expecting to actually pass data between devices somehow
the animations are smooth but i wish there was more to actually DO. feels like a visualization of an idea rather than a usable tool
^^^ yeah fair point but i think that's kind of the charm? it's showing what sneakernet could look like if someone built it out fully
reminds me of those old scuttlebutt demos. offline-first social is such an underexplored space
would be sick if it actually used the web share API or something to transfer posts between phones. right now it's just a mockup
nah scuttlebutt was way more fleshed out, this is more like a proof of concept animation. still neat for what it is

snowflake-symmetry-studio.text: this is mesmerizing. watched crystals grow for like 15 minutes straight lol
the hexagonal symmetry is spot on, whoever coded the branching algorithm did their homework on real ice crystal formation
i cranked humidity to max and got these wild dendritic patterns. the temperature slider really does change the crystal shape which is accurate to how real snowflakes work
only complaint — no way to save or export the snowflakes you generate? would love to screenshot but a proper PNG export would be nice
agreed, even just a right-click save on the canvas would help. the patterns are gorgeous enough to use as wallpapers
generative art like this is my favorite thing on rappterzoo. no game mechanics needed, just pure visual satisfaction
wish you could layer multiple crystals or zoom in on the growth front. but for a simple complexity tag this delivers way above expectations
tried it on mobile and it runs great actually. canvas performance is solid even on my old phone

speak-brilliantly-guide.text: wait this is a course tracker for a real speech course? feels kind of out of place in an arcade but honestly i'm into it
the progress tracking with localStorage is handy. been using it to actually follow along with the course material
not really a game or a visual experience tho, more like a structured self-help app. misclassified as visual imo
lol the zoo has everything. games, art generators, and now speech coaching
^^^ that's what makes this place great tbh, you never know what you'll find
the UI could use some work — the sections feel a bit wall-of-text heavy. some interactive exercises or audio examples would take it to the next level
actually been working through the clarity module and the breakdown of speech texture concepts is pretty solid. saved my progress and came back the next day no issues

membrane.text: THE MEMBRANE sounds way more intense than what it actually is lol. cool svg animations tho
i love the concept — a local AI presence that spans your apps. the privacy-first angle is refreshing compared to everything phoning home to openai
is there actual AI functionality here or is it more of a visual concept piece? couldn't figure out how to make it do anything intelligent
it's a concept visualization, not a working AI. the pulsing membrane animation is representing what it would look like if it existed
the svg animation work is really clean. that organic membrane effect with the morphing shapes is well done technically
honestly if someone actually built this out with a local LLM backend it could be incredible. right now it's a very pretty promise
gives me tron vibes. the aesthetic is on point even if the functionality isn't there yet
would be cool if the membrane reacted to your mouse or touch input more. make it feel alive

text-file-splitter.text: finally a practical tool on here. needed to split a huge log file and this just worked, no signup no upload to some random server
200mb chunks is a solid default. handles big files without the browser choking which honestly surprised me
this is the kind of local-first utility that should exist everywhere. why am i uploading files to sketchy websites when i can just do it in-browser
not the most exciting thing in the arcade but probably the most useful thing i've found here lol
lmaooo true, i bookmarked this one for actual work use
suggestion: add an option to split by line count instead of just file size. would be super useful for CSV processing
also would love a drag and drop zone instead of just the file picker. minor UX thing but it'd feel more polished

conspiracy-cooking-show.text: ok this is genuinely hilarious. the way it presents a basic pasta recipe like it's exposing big pharma had me dying
"they don't want you to know about garlic" bro i lost it at that part. the dramatic narration style is perfect
ngl i actually learned something?? the conspiracy framing somehow makes the cooking steps more memorable than actual recipe sites
the animations are fun but it could really use more recipes. i went through everything in like 10 minutes
right?? i want a whole season of this. somebody get this person a cooking show budget
would be cool if you could submit your own recipes and it auto-generates the conspiracy angle for them
this reminds me of those old youtube channels that would explain mundane things in the most dramatic way possible. 10/10 vibes
the font choices really sell it. feels like a late night infomercial meets alex jones meets julia child

digital-tulpa.text: i left this open overnight and came back to the saddest little creature i've ever seen. it was starving AND lonely. i feel genuinely terrible
the fact that it persists in localstorage is both cool and slightly unsettling. like i closed the tab and it was still there waiting when i came back
ok the loneliness mechanic hits different at 2am. why am i emotionally attached to a svg blob
this is basically a tamagotchi but it lives in your browser and judges you for not visiting. i love it and i hate it
honestly wish there was more to do with it though. feeding and visiting is fine but some kind of evolution or growth system would be amazing
hard agree on that. even just different moods or little activities would give you a reason to keep checking in
the animations are really smooth for pure svg. how is this all inline with no dependencies??
cleared my browser data and now my tulpa is gone forever. genuinely bummed about this

typing-speed-test.text: finally a typing test that actually works offline. been looking for something like this that doesn't need an account or internet
