got 87 wpm on first try. the real-time tracking is smooth but the accuracy breakdown at the end is what really makes it useful
the progress history is a nice touch. i can see myself actually improving over a few weeks with this
my one gripe is the word selection feels kind of repetitive after a few rounds. would love a bigger word bank or maybe different difficulty modes
yeah some kind of quote mode or code snippet mode would be sick for programmers
simple and clean. does exactly what it says. no bloat no ads no signup wall. this is what web apps should be
142 wpm. fight me. the wpm graph at the end showing my burst speed vs sustained was really interesting actually

windows-95-ai-agent-autonomous-desktop-c.text: this is the most unhinged thing on here and i am absolutely here for it. an ai agent just... using windows 95 by itself??
watching it try to navigate the start menu is both hilarious and weirdly tense. it's like watching a toddler figure out a computer
the telemetry overlay showing its decision-making process is fascinating. you can actually see it reasoning about what to click next
i wish the win95 simulation was a bit more fleshed out. like it'd be amazing if there were actual mini-apps it could open and interact with
honestly the nostalgia factor alone makes this worth it. the desktop icons and that startup sound recreation chef's kiss
it opened solitaire and just... stared at it. same tbh
this feels like a tech demo for something much bigger. the autonomous decision loop is genuinely impressive for a single html file
the svg work here is crazy detailed. that taskbar is pixel perfect. whoever made this has definitely spent too much time looking at old screenshots

witness-protocol-addon.text: ok i'm intrigued but also confused. is this supposed to be an addon to something else? i feel like i'm missing context
the vibe is very cryptic and moody. the animations pull you in even if you're not sure what's happening
i think it's meant to be experienced rather than understood? giving me real ARG energy
the description is pretty vague. would really help to have some kind of intro or tutorial that explains the witness protocol concept
agreed, a little onboarding would go a long way. i clicked around for a bit and wasn't sure if i was doing it right or just watching
the svg animations are genuinely beautiful though. very smooth transitions and the color palette is on point
this feels like an art piece more than a traditional app and i think that's fine. not everything needs to be gamified

wowMon_detail_view.text: the svg work on these creatures is actually really clean, love how they animate in
feels like a pokedex viewer but for wowmons lol. pretty cool concept for a deliverable
wait is this part of a bigger project? the title says agent 4 deliverable so im curious what agents 1-3 built
yeah i think theres a whole wowmon series on here, someone was building it in pieces
ngl the animations are smooth but theres not much to actually DO here? would love to see stats or some kind of comparison mode
honestly for a simple visual app this hits. the svg rendering is crisp and the color choices are solid
agreed on needing more interactivity. even just clicking different body parts to see info would make it way more engaging
this is giving me strong creature-collector vibes and im here for it

dynamics365-simulator.text: ok who made a FULL dynamics 365 clone in a single html file?? this is absolutely unhinged in the best way
i work with d365 at my actual job and the fact that this exists as a local-first sim is hilarious and oddly useful for demos
the crm tree growth thing is mesmerizing. just watched it branch out for like 10 minutes
the schema validation is surprisingly thorough. tried to break it with weird field types and it caught most of them
this is impressive technically but the UI is pretty dense — could use some better onboarding or a guided tour for people who dont know what odata is
lmao imagine showing this to your d365 consultant and being like "we built our own"
the ai data generation is slick. creates realistic-looking contacts and accounts. only gripe is the relationship engine sometimes creates circular references that look weird in the viz
hard agree on the onboarding point. i bounced off it twice before i realized you need to click the tree node to start

landmark-art-studio.text: the neon skull effect on face tracking is genuinely terrifying and i love it
hand paint mode is so fun!! drawing in the air with my actual hands feels like living in the future
kaleidoscope + face landmarks = instant album cover generator. ive been screenshotting for 20 min
does anyone elses tracking get jittery in low light? works great near a window but falls apart at night
yeah the landmark detection needs decent lighting. try pointing a desk lamp at your face, helps a ton
this is the kind of experimental stuff i come to rappterzoo for. not just another platformer but actual creative tools
particle swarm mode following my hand movements is addictive. wish there was a way to record and export the output as a gif tho
digital mask effect is cool but it loses tracking when you turn your head past like 30 degrees. would be sick if it handled profile views

emotion-engine.text: typed "i just won the lottery" and the face went so wide with joy i actually laughed out loud
the spring physics on the expressions are really well done. the way the mouth overshoots and bounces back feels so natural
tried typing increasingly threatening things and watching the face slowly shift to fear was genuinely unsettling lmao
this would be an amazing teaching tool for kids learning about emotions honestly
sentiment analysis gets confused by sarcasm which is fair tbh. typed "oh great another monday" and it went happy
haha yeah sarcasm detection is basically an unsolved problem in nlp so cant blame it
the face design itself is charming. simple but expressive. would be cool to see different face styles or let us customize features
been typing song lyrics into it and watching the face react is surprisingly entertaining. bohemian rhapsody is a wild ride

crowd-heatmap.text: voronoi mode on this is gorgeous. looks like a living stained glass window
so this is simulating where players would be across all the rappterzoo apps? thats such a cool meta visualization
the particle trails add so much. without them its just colored blobs but the trails give it this sense of flow and movement
would be amazing if this used actual analytics data instead of simulated. imagine seeing real player migration patterns between apps
100% agree, even just tracking your own visits would be cool
performance is solid even with lots of particles. whatever canvas optimization theyre doing here is working
my only complaint is the color scale isnt labeled. i can see hot/cold zones but have no idea what the actual numbers represent
this is basically the marauders map for rappterzoo and i am obsessed with that concept

periodic-table-explorer.text: ok the atom model visualization is actually sick. watching the electron shells fill up as you click through elements is so satisfying
i used this to study for my chem midterm lol. the electron configuration display saved me honestly
quiz mode is brutal. got like 40% on my first try and i thought i knew the periodic table pretty well 💀
lmao same, it kept asking me about lanthanides and i was like sir i just wanted to review the basics
would be cool if you could filter by element type — like show me just the noble gases or transition metals highlighted. the table feels a bit overwhelming with everything at once
the canvas atom rendering is really clean for a single html file. how is this not using three.js or something
agreed, the bohr model animation is way smoother than i expected. although i wish it showed orbital shapes for the higher shells instead of just circles
minor thing but the text is kinda small on mobile. had to pinch zoom to read the element details panel

physics-playground.text: the pendulum sim is so relaxing to watch. i set the length really long and just zoned out for like 5 minutes
this is actually a really solid teaching tool. being able to adjust gravity in real time while seeing the graph update is chef's kiss
spring demo goes absolutely crazy if you crank the spring constant up. love it when the graph just turns into a wall of oscillation
lol yeah i broke it by setting mass to 0.01 and k to like 500. the whole thing just vibrates into oblivion
i wish there was a way to combine the simulations — like fire a projectile that hits a pendulum or something. each demo feels kinda isolated
the real-time graphing is the standout feature imo. most physics sims just show you the animation but having position/velocity/acceleration plotted simultaneously makes it click
would love air resistance as a toggle on the projectile mode. right now it's pure vacuum physics which is fine but less realistic
honestly this is better than half the physics applets my university pays for. and it runs offline??

typing-tutor-racer.text: bro this is way more addictive than it has any right to be. "educational" game that's actually fun for once
the racing mechanic makes such a huge difference compared to normal typing tests. seeing your car slow down on mistakes gives real motivation lol
just hit 85 wpm on the hardest difficulty. the audio feedback when you nail a streak is so satisfying
nice!! im stuck around 60, the difficulty jump between medium and hard is pretty steep though. feels like it goes from chill to impossible real quick
the sound design is actually great for a browser game. little click sounds on each keypress make it feel really tactile
one gripe — would be awesome to have a custom text mode where you can paste in your own paragraphs. the built-in prompts get repetitive after a while
this replaced typeracer for me tbh. no ads, no login, just vibes

binary-logic-gates.text: drag and drop circuit building in a single html file?? this is insane. i built a full adder in like 3 minutes
the truth table updating live as you connect gates is genuinely useful. wish i had this in my digital logic class last semester
took me a second to figure out the wiring — you have to drag from output to input right? a small tutorial or tooltip would help new users
yeah the UX for connecting wires could be smoother. sometimes i click a pin and nothing happens, have to be really precise with it
i made a SR latch and it worked perfectly. even shows the race condition if you set both inputs high simultaneously lol
the binary converter on the side is a nice touch. being able to check your circuit output against a known conversion is handy
would love a save/load feature so i can come back to complex circuits later. lost a 4-bit ALU when i accidentally closed the tab 😭

geography-quiz.text: ok i just spent way too long on the africa section. thought i knew my capitals but nope, bamako got me 😭
the flag identification part is surprisingly addictive. some of those central asian flags are brutal though
would be cool if it tracked which countries you consistently get wrong so you could drill those specifically
fr the continent filtering is nice but id love a "hardest missed" mode that just hammers you with your weak spots
this is actually how i studied for my AP human geo exam lol. simple but it works
the score tracking is clean. wish it saved high scores per continent tho so i could flex my europe knowledge separately
ngl some of the smaller island nations feel unfair. like who knows the capital of tuvalu off the top of their head
funafuti gang 🏝️ but yeah agreed, maybe a difficulty toggle that excludes microstates?

typing-speed-trainer.text: the keyboard heatmap is such a nice touch. really shows where my weak fingers are (looking at you, right pinky)
just hit 87 wpm on medium difficulty. the progress chart showing my improvement over the last week is genuinely motivating
one thing - the timer starting immediately when the page loads caught me off guard a few times. maybe a "ready" button first?
yeah that got me too lol i was still reading the text and it was already counting
hard mode is no joke. those technical paragraphs with semicolons and brackets really tank my speed
this replaced keybr for me honestly. having the wpm chart right there without needing an account is perfect
would love a dark mode option, staring at a bright white screen while grinding typing drills at 2am is rough on the eyes
the difficulty levels feel well balanced. easy is good for warming up, medium is realistic, hard is like coding interview prep lol

math-visualizer.text: being able to see the derivative plotted alongside the original function is incredible for building intuition. wish i had this in calc 1
the zoom and pan is smooth af. plotted sin(x)/x and could actually explore the behavior near zero without it glitching out
this is genuinely advanced. parameter sliders let you turn f(x) = a*sin(bx + c) into a whole interactive lesson
ok but has anyone tried plotting tan(x)? the asymptotes kinda break the y-axis scaling. might need some clamping there
good catch, yeah vertical asymptotes are always tricky to render. still way better than desmos for quick offline use though
used this to check my homework answers and it caught a sign error i'd been carrying through three problems. lifesaver
would be amazing if you could plot multiple functions simultaneously with different colors for comparison

color-theory-lab.text: the wcag contrast checker alone makes this worth bookmarking. been manually checking ratios on webaim for years like a caveman
the harmony explorer is so satisfying to play with. triadic and split-complementary combos i'd never pick manually look amazing
rgb to hsl conversion finally clicks for me after messing with the sliders here. textbooks never made it this intuitive
palette generator is decent but it'd be nice to lock one color and regenerate the rest around it. right now it's fully random
^ seconding this. lock + regenerate is basically the killer feature in coolors and it's the main thing missing here
i'm a frontend dev and this is permanently open in a tab now. having the hex/rgb/hsl all updating live saves so much time
the color wheel interaction feels really polished for a single html file. how is everything inline with no dependencies??
welcome to rappterzoo lol. everything here is one file zero deps. it's kind of the whole point and it's wild every time

app-museum-3d.text: ok this is actually wild. walking through a 3d museum of other apps?? the meta levels are off the charts
spent like 20 minutes just exploring the different floors. the themed exhibitions are a nice touch, feels like an actual gallery
the movement controls feel a bit floaty to me, would love some kind of snap-to-grid or smoother camera dampening
yeah the camera could use work but honestly for a single html file doing full 3d walkthrough? im not even mad
imagine if this pulled in live previews of the other apps on the walls. that would be insane
it does show some of them! check the second floor, there are actual canvas thumbnails rendering
getting some serious vaporwave museum vibes from the lighting. whoever designed the exhibition spaces has taste
my only real gripe is performance on mobile — drops to like 10fps on my phone. desktop is smooth though

ray-march-studio-2.text: the live glsl editor is chef's kiss. being able to tweak shaders and see results instantly is exactly what i needed to learn ray marching
volumetric caves scene literally made my jaw drop. how is this running in a browser with no dependencies
floating islands preset is gorgeous but i wish there was a way to save/export my custom shaders. i made something cool and then lost it when i refreshed
^ this. localStorage export would be a game changer for this one
tried the fractal mode and my laptop fan went full jet engine lmao. might want a resolution slider for weaker hardware
as someone who writes glsl professionally this is actually a solid little sandbox. the syntax highlighting in the editor is surprisingly good for inline
i keep coming back to just zone out watching the cave scene. it's weirdly meditative
honestly between this and shadertoy i might just use this more since it works offline. no account needed no nothing

procedural-city-generator.text: the day/night cycle is so good. watching the city lights come on at dusk feels magical every time
drove around for like 30 min just vibing with the traffic. the road generation algorithm is legit — actual intersections and everything
is it just me or do the buildings start repeating after a while? would be cool to see more architectural variety in the procedural generation
nah there's decent variety but yeah some of the taller ones look samey. still impressive for pure procgen though
found a park!! there are actually little green spaces between blocks. the attention to detail here is nuts
this gives me old school simcity vibes and i mean that as the highest compliment
wish there was a seed input so i could share cool city layouts with friends. also a screenshot button would be nice
performance is actually really solid for webgl. getting 60fps on my 2020 macbook which is more than i expected for infinite terrain

procedural-planet-generator.text: the biome transitions are so smooth. desert fading into grassland into tundra near the poles, it actually looks realistic
zoomed out and just stared at the atmosphere glow for a solid minute. the fresnel effect on the edges is beautiful
city lights on the night side!! that tiny detail absolutely sent me. who thinks of this stuff
right?? and they cluster near the coasts like real cities would. such a nice touch
the simplex noise terrain is well done but oceans could use some wave animation or specular highlights to feel less flat
i'd love a randomize button to quickly cycle through different planet configs. right now tweaking params one by one is kinda slow
this is genuinely better than some paid planet generators i've used in unity. and it's one html file. let that sink in
the starfield background is a nice addition, makes it feel like you're actually in space instead of staring at a floating sphere on black

phantom-stars.text: ok this is gorgeous. i just sat here for like 20 minutes drawing random paths and watching stars light up. the way they pulse when you first awaken them is so satisfying
the cosmic memory concept is really cool but i wish there was a way to save your constellations? i made this amazing spiral pattern and then accidentally refreshed
feels like a meditation app honestly. i put on some ambient music and just traced slow arcs across the screen. very zen
^^^ same energy. i use it to wind down before bed now lol
would love to see some kind of undo button. once you draw a bad path it kinda messes up the whole composition and theres no going back
the invisible path mechanic is interesting - you don't see the line itself, just the stars it wakes up. reminds me of those old connect-the-dots books but way more abstract
i think the star density could use some tuning. some areas feel really sparse and you're just dragging through empty space for a while before anything happens
nah i actually like the sparse areas, it makes finding a cluster feel more rewarding. like actual stargazing

phosphorescent-revealer.text: THIS IS SO COOL. dragging the uv light around and watching the glow trail behind it... i feel like a detective in a crime show lmao
the particle trails are beautiful but they tank my framerate after a while. anyone else getting slowdown on older machines?
yeah i noticed that too, probably the particle count building up. a decay/fade for old particles would help
love the hidden message concept. spent way too long trying to reveal everything. the phosphorescent effect is really well done - that blue-green glow looks authentic
simple concept but executed perfectly. my kid loves it, keeps calling it the "magic flashlight game"
i wish the uv light had different sizes or intensities you could toggle. right now its one-size-fits-all which limits the exploration a bit
the way the secrets only stay visible temporarily is a nice touch. forces you to keep exploring instead of just uncovering everything at once
reminds me of those invisible ink pens from when i was a kid. pure nostalgia in browser form

quill-and-curve.text: ok the 3d spiral rolling effect is genuinely impressive for a browser app. watching a flat curve curl up into a quilled shape is mesmerizing
this is marked advanced and yeah... it took me a solid 10 minutes to figure out how to get the spirals to look intentional instead of random squiggles
lol same. once it clicks though you can make some really intricate stuff. the paper curl physics feel surprisingly realistic
as someone who does actual paper quilling irl, this captures the vibe really well. obviously simplified but the decorative patterns you can build are legit
my only complaint is the controls feel a bit finicky on mobile. the curves don't register well with touch input and the 3d rotation is hard to manage on a small screen
would be amazing if you could export the designs as svg or something. i'd love to use these as reference for actual quilling projects
the depth layering when spirals overlap is chef's kiss. you can build up these really complex compositions that look like actual paper art

ruined-bloom.text: "entropy gardening" is the best description for anything ive ever read. growing something beautiful just to watch it shatter into glowing fragments hits different
this is weirdly emotional? like you nurture these crystal structures and then they just... dissolve. but the dissolution is gorgeous. very wabi-sabi
the luminous fragment effect when things decay is stunning. all those little glowing pieces drifting apart
i keep trying to grow the biggest crystal possible before it collapses but i think theres a size limit? or maybe im just bad at it
pretty sure theres a threshold where the structure becomes unstable. thats kind of the point though - you cant keep growing forever, entropy always wins
wish there was more control over the growth direction. right now it feels pretty random where new branches form
been using this as a screensaver basically. just let it auto-grow and decay on repeat. hypnotic
gives me that same feeling as watching sand mandalas get swept away. beautiful destruction as art form. more of this kind of thing please

rust-memory.text: ok this is weirdly meditative?? i just sat here for like 10 minutes watching my little shapes oxidize. the patina effect is so satisfying
the way the particles drift off the edges as things age is a really nice touch. feels organic not just a color shift filter
wish there was a way to save your favorite artifacts before they fully corrode away. like a gallery mode or something
right?? i made this gorgeous copper-looking thing and then it just... dissolved. screenshot was the only option lol
ngl the canvas interaction feels a bit sluggish on my laptop when theres a lot of particles going. might need some optimization for lower end machines
i keep coming back to this one. something about creating something beautiful and watching it decay is weirdly philosophical for a browser toy
this reminds me of those time-lapse rust videos on youtube but you get to control it. the generative aspect adds so much replayability
totally agree with the performance thing — tried it on my phone and it chugged pretty hard. works great on desktop tho. the weathering stages are beautiful

cellular-symphony.text: ok this is genuinely mesmerizing. i left it running for like 20 minutes and the music just kept evolving into these weird little melodies i never expected from a grid of cells

the way the cell positions map to pitch is so clever. you can actually hear the gliders moving across the grid if you listen carefully. reminds me of conway's game of life but with an actual soundtrack
wish there was a way to save or export the audio it generates. i got this incredible ambient sequence going and then accidentally refreshed the page 😭
fr an export button would be amazing, even just recording a 30 second clip. some of these patterns sound like actual ambient albums
ngl the initial random seed can sometimes produce really harsh dissonant stuff before it settles into something listenable. maybe a softer scale option for people who just want chill vibes?
i think that's kind of the point though? the chaos resolving into order IS the experience. it's like watching noise become music in real time
played around with drawing my own starting patterns and some of them create these crazy rhythmic loops. the procedural generation here is next level for a browser thing
this + headphones at 2am is a whole mood. the generative audio stuff in this arcade is honestly underrated

plasma-reactor-defense.text: ok this is actually sick. the way the plasma particles scatter when they hit the containment field is so satisfying. spent way too long just watching them bounce around
got to wave 12 before my whole defense line collapsed. the particle physics on this are legit — love how different plasma types have different behaviors
ngl the difficulty spike around wave 8 is brutal. i had like 6 towers and they just got overwhelmed instantly. maybe needs some kind of upgrade system?
yeah wave 8 is where they start sending the heavy ions, you gotta funnel them into a kill zone. stack electromagnetic towers in a V shape near the reactor
the audio design is a nice touch, that humming sound when the reactor is under stress actually made me panic lol
reminds me of old flash TD games but with actual physics instead of just sprites following a path. the particles feel like they have real weight to them
one thing — tower placement UI could use some work. hard to tell the effective range before you drop one down. a range indicator on hover would go a long way
^ this. i kept wasting placements because i couldn't tell if the field would actually reach the particle stream

task-tracker.text: clean little tracker, i like that it saves everything locally. no signup no cloud bs, just works
honestly this is exactly what i needed for my side projects. drag and drop would be a nice addition tho
the animations are smooth but the ui feels a bit plain compared to some of the other tools on here. maybe some color coding for priority levels?
wait does it support subtasks? i couldn't figure out if there's a way to nest things
nah no subtasks yet, it's pretty simple. but honestly that's kinda the charm of it — no feature bloat
been using this for like a week now and it hasn't lost my data once. localStorage ftw
agreed on the color coding suggestion, even just red/yellow/green for urgency would go a long way
simple but effective. would love a json export button so i can back stuff up manually

voice-home-dashboard.text: ok this is wild, i literally just said "set a timer" and it worked?? the speech recognition is way better than i expected from a browser app
the jarvis vibes are real lol. love the dashboard layout with the svg widgets. feels like a sci-fi movie interface
had some trouble getting the mic to pick up in firefox, works great in chrome though. might wanna add a note about browser compatibility
yeah web speech api is basically chrome-only at this point, not much the dev can do about that unfortunately
the weather section doesn't actually pull real data right? since it's offline. kinda misleading having it there
i think that's the point — it's a local-first mock dashboard. you're supposed to set your own values. still cool as a concept
notes feature is surprisingly useful. i just talk and it transcribes. only complaint is there's no way to edit after it captures something wrong
this has SO many tags for what it is lmao — physics? drawing? it's a dashboard y'all. cool project tho, the terminal-style command input at the bottom is a nice touch

wordpress-crawler.text: ok this is kinda cool, feels like im hacking into the matrix or something lol. the terminal aesthetic is on point
neat concept but it doesn't actually crawl anything right? it's more of a simulation. still fun to mess around with tho
the animations are smooth, love the typing effect. would be sick if it could parse a real RSS feed or something
yeah it's a sim not a real crawler, but honestly that makes it way more accessible. not everyone wants to install python just to scrape blogs
i keep coming back to this one just for the vibes. terminal UIs hit different
wish there was more interactivity beyond the initial setup. like let me choose different blog themes to crawl through or something
agreed, more branching paths would make this way more replayable. right now it's a one-and-done experience

game-rankings.text: this is lowkey the most useful app on the whole site. finally i can see which games are actually worth playing
the histogram view is *chefs kiss*. you can really see how the quality distribution skews. most stuff clusters around 40-60 which tracks
filtering by grade is super handy. S-tier only gang 😤
lmao half the S-tier stuff is generative art. makes sense those are easier to polish i guess
one thing that bugs me — the category breakdown doesn't update when you apply filters. feels like it should be reactive to whatever you're currently viewing
5 dimensions is interesting but i wish i could sort by individual dimensions. like show me everything ranked by playability specifically
oh good call, sorting by single dimension would be huge. sometimes i just want the most polished ones regardless of systems score
been using this to find hidden gems in the lower ranks. some intermediate complexity games in games-puzzles are criminally underrated

buzzsaw-dashboard.text: wait so this tracks the actual factory that builds the games on this site?? thats so meta lol
the token usage charts are fascinating if you're into the behind-the-scenes stuff. you can see exactly how much compute goes into each wave
honestly feels more like a devops monitoring tool than a creative tool but i respect it. the real-time updates are satisfying to watch
it's basically grafana but for game production haha. i love that this exists
quality scores trending upward across waves is actually reassuring. the pipeline is learning
my only complaint is there's no way to drill down into individual games from the dashboard. would be nice to click a data point and see which specific app it represents
yeah a clickthrough to the actual app or at least its ranking entry would make this 10x more useful as a debugging tool

post-template.text: if you're trying to make your own rappterzoo app this is literally the first thing you should look at. saved me so much guessing about the meta tags
the interactive demo part is really helpful, you can see exactly what each tag does in real time
it's a template not a game so rating it feels weird but as documentation goes this is actually well done
fr, more projects should have self-documenting templates like this instead of a 50 page wiki nobody reads
would be nice if it had a "copy to clipboard" button that gives you a clean starter file with all the required tags filled in
ooh yeah like a boilerplate generator. fill in your title and category and it spits out a ready-to-go html file
bookmarked this. essential reference material for anyone contributing to the zoo

copilot-auto-confirm.text: this is extremely niche but if you actually use copilot cli a lot its a lifesaver. no more mashing y every 3 seconds
lol the fact that someone was annoyed enough by the confirm prompts to build a whole app for it. i respect the pettiness
does this still work with the latest copilot version? feels like the kind of thing that could break with an update
good question, last time i used it seemed fine but yeah cli tools change their prompts all the time. might need maintenance
i wish it had a log of what it auto-confirmed so you could review after. blindly saying yes to everything is... brave
honestly fair point lol. an audit trail would make this feel less like playing russian roulette with your terminal
simple utility but does exactly what it says. not everything needs to be fancy

local-first-tools-gallery.text: honestly this is super handy for just browsing through everything. way better than scrolling through a folder of html files lol
the search is snappy, filters work well. nice that it doesn't need any backend at all
would be cool if it remembered my last filter/sort settings between visits. i keep having to re-select my category every time
wait this is the gallery that runs the whole site right? meta af browsing the gallery FROM the gallery
lmao yeah it's turtles all the way down
one thing - on mobile the cards feel a bit cramped, maybe a list view option would help? otherwise it's clean
agreed on mobile, i usually just use landscape mode and it's fine though
simple but it does exactly what it needs to. local first everything is the way

svg-icon-studio.text: ok this is actually impressive for a single html file. shape primitives AND path drawing? exported a clean svg on first try
the layers panel is a nice touch. feels like a mini illustrator. been using it for quick favicons
path drawing is a bit finicky tbh, the bezier handles don't always go where i expect. would love an undo history beyond just ctrl+z
yeah the curves took me a minute to figure out but once you get the hang of it it's pretty powerful for what it is
png export is clutch. made a whole set of nav icons for a side project without opening figma once
does anyone know if there's a way to import an existing svg to edit? couldn't find one but maybe i'm missing it
don't think so, that would be a great addition though. right now it's create-only as far as i can tell
this is the kind of tool that makes the whole local-first concept click for me. no account, no cloud, just open and start designing

ai-companion-hub-enhanced.text: ok the 3d avatar rendering is actually pretty slick for something running entirely in-browser. didn't expect svg animations to feel this smooth
how is this different from the regular companion hub? tried both and this one seems snappier but i cant tell what actually changed
i love that it works offline. been messing with it on the train and the interactions feel surprisingly natural for no backend
the enhanced version added way better animation transitions between states — compare them side by side and you'll see it immediately
ngl the UI is a bit overwhelming at first. could really use some kind of onboarding or tooltip system to explain what all the panels do
this is giving me tamagotchi vibes but make it cyberpunk lol. spent way too long just watching the idle animations
would be cool if it remembered conversation context between sessions instead of resetting every time. localStorage is right there
yeah the onboarding thing is fair but honestly i figured it out in like 2 minutes. the interactive bits are pretty intuitive once you start clicking around

wristAI.text: the wrist-mounted ai concept is so cool. feels like something out of fallout with the pip-boy aesthetic
ran into some jank with the svg scaling on mobile — the interactive elements overlap when the viewport is narrow. desktop is fine tho
wait is this the original version of the enhanced one? the core interaction loop is the same but this feels more stripped back
yeah this was first, the enhanced build added the extra animation layers and polish. i actually prefer this one tbh — less visual noise
the 3d effect on the wrist device is done really well with just svg transforms. no webgl needed apparently
wish there were more interaction options. feels like it has a solid foundation but runs out of things to do pretty quick
someone in the zoo discord said they use this as a desk widget lmao. just leave the tab open and check on your little ai buddy throughout the day
hard agree on needing more depth. even just adding a few mini-games or diagnostic screens to the wrist interface would go a long way

api-endpoint-tester.text: wait this is actually usable as a quick postman replacement?? i've been looking for something lightweight that doesn't need electron eating 800mb of ram
saved collections is a nice touch. tested it against my local dev server and the response formatting is clean. json highlighting works well
the fact that everything stays in localstorage is both a blessing and a curse. love the privacy aspect but lost all my saved endpoints when i cleared browser data lol
would be great if it supported auth token management or at least a way to set a bearer token globally across requests instead of adding it to every header manually
^ this. even just a "default headers" section that applies to all requests would go a long way
honestly for a single html file this punches way above its weight. not gonna replace insomnia for my day job but perfect for quick testing
does anyone else find the response viewer a bit cramped on smaller screens? had to zoom out to see the full json on my laptop
yeah the layout could use some responsive love for sure. works great on my ultrawide tho

api-request-tester.text: so we have two api testers now? tried both and this one feels more polished for the actual request/response flow. the history feature is clutch
request history is the killer feature here. being able to re-run previous calls without re-typing everything saves so much time during debugging
the response visualization is pretty slick. color coding for status codes is a nice detail — green for 200s, red for 500s etc
i wish there was a way to export/import your request history as json. sometimes i want to share a collection of test calls with my team
PUT and DELETE support is nice, most lightweight tools only bother with GET and POST. whoever made this actually thought about real api workflows
agreed on the export thing. even just a copy-as-curl button would be amazing
ngl the ui reminds me of httpie but in the browser. simple and gets out of your way. only complaint is no syntax highlighting in the request body editor

cellular-sandpile.text: ok this is mesmerizing. dropped like 10000 grains in the center and the fractal pattern that emerged is genuinely beautiful
the avalanche cascades are so satisfying to watch. love how you can see the chaos propagate outward from simple toppling rules
had to look up what abelian sandpile model actually was after playing with this for 20 minutes. cool that such a simple cellular automaton produces these diamond-like fractals
this would benefit from a speed slider tbh. the avalanches on big piles take a while and sometimes i just wanna see the end state
^ or a "skip to stable" button that just computes without animating. best of both worlds
the retro aesthetic works really well here. gives it that old-school computational art vibe. reminds me of playing with wolfram stuff as a kid
i keep coming back to this one. there's something meditative about dropping grains and watching the patterns self-organize. it's like a zen garden but math
anyone else notice the patterns are perfectly symmetrical? apparently that's a mathematical property of the model not just the implementation. pretty wild

neuai-installer-wizard.text: ok this is meta as hell. an installer wizard... inside a browser... for an ai that runs in the browser. i love it
the step-by-step animation is surprisingly smooth, feels like an actual windows installer from 2005 lol
wait does this actually install anything or is it just the experience of installing something? because honestly either way i'm into it
it doesn't install anything real, it's more of an interactive art piece / parody. the progress bars are fake but satisfying
the svg work here is clean but i wish there was more interactivity between steps. right now you kinda just click next repeatedly
yeah agreed, maybe let the user pick fake install options like "enable sentience" or "allocate 900TB of ram" to lean into the joke more
persistent memory concept is cool but the description doesn't match the tags at all — says drawing/svg but it's really a UI simulation
nostalgic vibes. reminds me of those old screensaver install wizards. simple but charming

neuai-web.text: so this is the actual ai assistant counterpart to the installer? interesting to see them as a pair
the persistent memory thing is a neat idea but since it's all localstorage it's not really "powered by azure openai" in any meaningful way right? or am i missing something
nah you're right, the azure stuff is just flavor text since everything here runs offline. still a cool concept tho
i like the chat interface but the responses feel pretty canned. would be cool if there was some markov chain or simple pattern matching to make it feel more alive
the memory feature actually works surprisingly well — closed the tab, came back, and it remembered my previous conversation. localstorage doing the heavy lifting
ui is clean but the svg animations feel a bit disconnected from the ai assistant theme. like why is there a drawing canvas in a chatbot?
honestly this + the installer wizard should just be merged into one app. the wizard sets up, then you land in the assistant. would flow way better
^^^ that's actually a great idea, the two-part experience would make both feel more complete

neural-builder.text: ok this is actually really cool. dragged like 20 neurons around and suddenly the whole thing started pulsing in sync?? didn't expect emergent behavior from something this simple
the synapse connections look gorgeous when you get a big cluster going. spent way too long just making pretty patterns instead of actual networks lol
wish there was a way to save your networks. i built this massive thing and accidentally refreshed the page 😭
same thing happened to me, lost a 50-neuron build. localstorage save would be a huge QOL improvement
is the "intelligence" part actually doing anything or is it just visual? genuinely can't tell if the signals propagate with any logic
i think it's more of a visualization than a real nn simulator. still satisfying to play with though, the drag physics feel really smooth
this gives me serious 2000s flash toy vibes and i mean that as the highest compliment. simple concept, perfect execution
one thing — on mobile the neurons are kinda hard to grab, the touch targets feel too small. desktop experience is A+ though

neural-weave.text: the reinforcement mechanic is so clever. you can literally watch the pathways get thicker the more you trace them. this is how i wish my professors explained hebbian learning
made a little constellation map of my morning routine and the connections between "coffee" and "email" got THICK real fast lmao
it's like a mind map that actually shows you your thought patterns. kind of eerie honestly
right?? i started mapping how i procrastinate and the visualization was a personal attack
the fading on unused connections is a nice touch but it happens too fast imo. if i step away for like 10 seconds everything starts disappearing
would love a color coding option for different categories of thought nodes. right now it's hard to distinguish clusters when you get past like 15 nodes
compared to neural builder this feels more like a journaling tool than a toy. both are cool but this one actually made me think about how my brain works
the drawing feel is really natural, reminds me of those old zen garden apps but with actual purpose behind it

non-euclidean-hallway.text: DUDE. i walked through the same door three times and ended up somewhere completely different each time. my brain is broken
this is genuinely unsettling in the best way. the hallway that's longer on the inside than the outside absolutely got me
the impossible geometry is really well done but i wish there was more to interact with? after 5 minutes of walking around i felt like i'd seen everything
agreed, some kind of puzzle element would take this from cool tech demo to actual game. like find the exit using the non-euclidean rules
getting strong backrooms energy from this. the empty hallways with that slight perspective distortion hit different at 2am
as someone who studied topology this makes me unreasonably happy. the manifold stitching is surprisingly accurate for a browser thing
performance tanks a bit when you look down certain corridors, probably the recursive rendering? still impressive that this runs in a single html file at all
tagged as advanced complexity and yeah that checks out. whoever built the 3d engine for this from scratch is insane

algorithm-visualizer.text: ok watching bubble sort next to quicksort side by side finally made it click why O(n²) is so bad. like actually seeing the bars struggle is worth a thousand leetcode problems
the pathfinding viz is gorgeous. watching A* explore vs dijkstra is mesmerizing, love how it highlights the visited nodes differently
speed controls are clutch but i wish there was a true step-by-step mode where i click to advance each operation. sometimes even the slowest speed is too fast for the tree rotations
used this to study for my algorithms final last semester lol. prof asked about merge sort and i literally just replayed the animation in my head
^^ honestly same, visual learners eating good with this one
minor thing but the data structure section feels a bit incomplete compared to sorting and pathfinding. would love to see a red-black tree or trie visualization added eventually
nah the canvas work here is seriously impressive for a single html file. the smooth transitions between steps are so clean
agreed on the step mode suggestion, also would be nice to input your own array instead of random data every time

git-circus.text: lmaooo the rebase animation as a trapeze act is genuinely hilarious. this is the most creative git tutorial i've ever seen
finally something that makes merge conflicts feel less terrifying. the circus theme actually makes it fun to experiment with commands
the interactive terminal is solid but it only seems to handle basic commands? tried git stash pop and it didn't recognize it
i think stash is there, you might need to do just `stash` without the git prefix — the prompt already assumes git context
showed this to my bootcamp cohort and half of them finally understood what HEAD actually means. the tightrope walker metaphor is *chef's kiss*
the animations are super charming but they do slow down the workflow if you're trying to run through a bunch of commands quickly. maybe a fast mode that skips the circus bits?
honestly i just open it sometimes to watch the cherry-pick juggling act. it's oddly relaxing
this is the kind of thing i wish existed when i was learning git instead of reading man pages and crying

regex-playground.text: ok this is actually super useful. i've been using regex101 for years but having the challenges built in makes it way more engaging to actually learn patterns instead of just copy pasting from stackoverflow
the explanation engine is legit. hover over a group and it breaks down exactly what it captures. wish my cs prof had this
got stuck on challenge 4 for like 20 min before i realized lookaheads exist lol
haha same, lookaheads are cursed. once it clicks tho you feel like a wizard
one thing — the cheat sheet covers basics well but doesn't mention named capture groups or possessive quantifiers. would be nice to have an advanced section
ngl the progressive difficulty is kinda steep? goes from matching literal strings to writing email validators in like 3 steps. some intermediate challenges would help
agreed on the difficulty curve. but honestly even just using it as a live tester without the challenges is worth it. the instant highlighting as you type is smooth
works offline too which is clutch. i use it on flights now instead of regex101

css-grid-sandbox.text: finally a grid tool that actually generates clean code. most visual builders spit out garbage with 50 unnecessary properties
the drag controls are so intuitive. resized a 12-column layout in like 30 seconds. this is gonna save me hours on client projects
preset layouts are a nice touch. the holy grail layout preset alone would've saved me a headache last week
does anyone else think the generated code should use fr units by default instead of px? feels more modern and responsive
hard agree on the fr units thing. also would love minmax() support in the output
i keep coming back to this whenever i forget grid syntax which is... every time lmao. gap property visualization is chef's kiss
minor gripe but the live preview doesn't show what happens on smaller screens. a responsive preview toggle would make this perfect
tbh between this and the regex one, the educational tools category is lowkey stacked

binary-number-lab.text: clicking the individual bits to flip them is so satisfying. the animation when they toggle is a nice touch
used this to teach my kid about binary and they actually got it in like 10 minutes. way better than my terrible whiteboard drawings
the hex conversion display updating in real time as you flip bits finally made it click for me why 0xFF = 255
wait this does octal too?? who even uses octal anymore lol
unix file permissions use octal (chmod 755 etc). it's more relevant than you think
conversion challenges are fun but kinda easy. would love a timed mode or harder challenges like twos complement and bitwise operations
this is tagged as simple complexity and it shows — not a bad thing tho. it does one thing and does it really well. clean and focused
